questions.text: A 24-year-old woman commits suicide by jumping into the village lake. Which of the following is not associated with the death of this woman?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario shows a case of freshwater drowning where death is rapid, occurring within four to five minutes. Hence, the statement that death occurs within 8-10 minutes is incorrect.

When a person drowns in freshwater, 2.5 L or more may be inhaled in 3 minutes, increasing blood volume by 50%. It leads to hypervolemia and hemodilution. Hemodilution leads to hemolysis, myocardial hypoxia, hemoglobinuria, marked hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia. Freshwater denatures the protective surfactant that lines the alveolar wall.

Pulmonary surfactant (lipoprotein) gets inactivated, and, alveoli collapse, lung compliance decreases, which results in a severe ventilation-perfusion mismatch. If the person survives, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) may result. Severe hypotension may occur during and after the initial resuscitation period. 

In freshwater drowning, the following are seen which results in death in 3-5 minutes:

  • anoxia
  • a disturbed sodium-potassium ratio producing arrhythmias
  • ventricular tachycardia 
  • fibrillation.
In cases of seawater drowning, hypernatremia and myocardial anoxia are seen. Seawater being hypertonic to plasma causes a fluid shift from the blood to alveoli causing pulmonary oedema. A net decrease in blood volume causes hemoconcentration and a fall in blood pressure. This hemoconcentration in seawater drowning causes increased viscosity of blood and myocardial anoxia leading to heart failure. Hyperkalemia is not seen in seawater drowning because RBCs get shrunken in contrast to freshwater drowning. Death occurs after about 8 to 10 minutes in the case of seawater drowning.

questions.text:
An obese female patient has been recently diagnosed with coronary artery disease and hypertension. She is started on atorvastatin. Addition of which of the following medications would increase the risk of statin-induced myopathy?
  1. Gemfibrozil
  2. Niacin
  3. Colesevelam
  4. Ritonavir
questions.solution:
Gemfibrozil, niacin, and ritonavir when added to atorvastatin can increase the risk of statin-induced myopathy.

Statins are hypolipidemic drugs that act by competitively inhibiting the enzyme HMG-CoA reductase. They are well tolerated. However, they can cause notable side effects such as myopathy and liver injury. They occur commonly when statins are concurrently given with nicotinic acid, gemfibrozil, or CYP3A4 inhibitors:

  • Macrolide antibiotics (erythromycin/clarithromycin)
  • Ketoconazole
  • Cyclosporine
  • HIV protease inhibitors (Ritonavir)
  • Warfarin
  • Digoxin
  • Azole antifungals
  • Amiodarone

Gemfibrozil belongs to the fibrate group of drugs that inhibits the hepatic uptake of statins by the organic anion transporter OATP1B1. It prevents the metabolism of statins, thereby increasing their bioavailability. Hence, the risk of toxicity increases.

Colesevelam is a bile-acid binding resin. It does not cause myopathy with statins.

 

Related Pearl: Metabolism of drugs

  • Protease inhibitors
  • Statins
  • Benzodiazepines
  • Amiodarone
  • Estrogen
  • Erythromycin

questions.text: A 40-year-old man who is a known case of hypertension presented with multiple episodes of hematuria and loin pain. Angiography showed an anterior communicating artery (ACA) aneurysm. The ultrasound abdomen is shown below. What is the best management of the given condition?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario with an aneurysm and USG showing a cystic appearance of the kidney is suggestive of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). The best management would be tolvaptan and long-term dialysis.

Management of ADPKD includes non-pharmacological methods by increasing fluid intake to prevent renal stone formation and to reduce the growth of cyst by depressing ADH release.

Pharmacological methods include using analgesics, ACE inhibitors, and ARBs to control blood pressure and slow the cyst growth, and tolvaptan(V2 receptor antagonist) to reduce pain and slow the decline in renal function.

Surgical decompression may be required only in cases of very large cysts causing persistent pain and infected cysts. If nephron-sparing surgery isn't possible, nephrectomy is indicated.

More than half of the patients require long-term peritoneal dialysis or hemodialysis or kidney transplant.

questions.text: An elderly male patient was brought to the hospital with complaints of palpitations and dizziness. His vitals are stable, and the ECG shows the following. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
In the given ECG, the presence of narrow-complex regular tachycardia and P-waves occurring after QRS complexes, known as retro P waves or pseudo-r' waves (especially prominent in lead V1) point to a diagnosis of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). In this patient, the next step would be the administration of IV adenosine.

PSVT is an arrhythmia characterized by a sudden onset and offset with rapid ventricular response. It includes atrioventricular nodal reentry tachycardia, junctional tachycardia, and AV reentry tachycardia.

Initial management of PSVT is by vagal maneuvers such as carotid massage, Valsalva maneuver, and breathing against pressure in a syringe. Vagal maneuvers increase the parasympathetic discharge, thus slowing down the conduction through the AV node and terminating the arrhythmia. Carotid sinus massage is avoided if the patient has a carotid bruit. 

If this method is ineffective, intravenous adenosine is used. It can terminate the majority of PSVT episodes by blocking the conduction at the AV node. If adenosine is also ineffective in terminating the arrhythmia, IV β blockers (esmolol, metoprolol) and IV non-DHP calcium channel blockers (verapamil and diltiazem) are used. Note that IV adenosine (option B) is preferred over β blockers and non-DHP CCBs (options A and D) for terminating PSVT because of its rapid onset, excellent success rate, and minimal negative inotropic effect.

Electrical cardioversion (option C) is done if the patient is hemodynamically unstable or if PSVT does not respond to any of the other methods mentioned above.

questions.text: A patient who was in a road traffic accident and sustained an open fracture of the femur one hour ago was transfused with 3 units of PRBC. Two hours later, he developed hypotension, hypoxia, dyspnea, and bilateral interstitial infiltrates on chest x-ray. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI).

TRALI is a sudden onset of respiratory failure resulting from the transfusion of donor fresh frozen plasma and platelets that contain high-titer of anti-HLA antibodies. These antibodies bind recipient leukocytes and aggregate in the pulmonary vasculature, releasing mediators that increase capillary permeability. 

The pathogenesis involves a two-hit hypothesis:

  • Priming event - increased sequestration and sensitization of neutrophils in the microvasculature of the lung
  • Second hit - the aggravating factor (most commonly MHC class II  antibodies) present in the transfused blood product activates the primed neutrophils

TRALI is a severe fatal complication of blood transfusion. The implicated donors are frequently multiparous women. Recipients with a history of pre-existing lung diseases, smoking, chronic alcohol use, mechanical ventilation and cancer surgeries are at increased risk of developing TRALI. 

The recipient develops symptoms of hypotension, fever, hypoxia and signs of noncardiogenic pulmonary edema, including bilateral interstitial infiltrates visible on the chest x-ray.

Treatment is supportive, and patients usually recover without sequelae. The incidence of TRALI has been reduced by choosing males and nulliparous women as donors.

Other options:

Option A: Anaphylaxis is characterized by dyspnea, hypotension, rash, and stridor due to bronchospasm, and pulmonary edema and chest infiltrate are not seen.

Option C: Transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO) is caused by rapid or excess transfusion of red cell preparations or plasma products. This condition is characterized by dyspnea, systolic hypertension, and cardiogenic pulmonary edema causing bilateral infiltrates on chest x-rays (elevated brain natriuretic peptide). It can be prevented by administering the transfusion slowly and treated with diuretics if necessary.

Option D: Hemolytic transfusion reaction may present with fever, chills, hypotension, tachycardia, dyspnea, chest and back pain, hemoglobinuria, and hemoglobinemia. In the most severe cases, DIC, acute renal failure, shock, and death may occur.

questions.text: Identify the part that differentiates a dark-field microscope from a light microscope.
questions.solution:
The condensor lens, which is marked C, differentiates a dark-field microscope from a light microscope.

The image given below shows a light microscope and its parts.

 

Dark-field microscopy improves the contrast by using a special condenser called dark-field condenser. Compared to a light microscope, reflected light is used instead of transmitted light, without letting any ray of light fall directly on the objective lens. The dark field condenser has a central circular stop illuminating the object with a cone of light. Light rays falling on the object are reflected or scattered onto the objective lens, making the object appears self-luminous against a dark background. The contrast gives an illusion of increased resolution.

Very slender organisms such as spirochetes which are not visible under ordinary illumination, can be clearly seen under the dark field microscope.

questions.text:
Which of the following is not associated with CRISPR-Cas9?

CRISPR- Clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats
questions.solution:
CRISPR-Cas9 is not associated with post-translational modification.

Clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats-associated gene 9 or CRISPR-Cas9 is a DNA editing/gene regulatory system. It involves two essential components, Cas9, an endonuclease that causes a double-stranded DNA break, allowing modifications to the genomic DNA to be made; and a synthetic single guide RNA or sgRNA responsible for guiding Cas9 to its target.

CRISPR-Cas9 is a tool used in modifying gene expression by above mentioned mechanism. It can be used to introduce breaks and bring out repairs in DNA by non-homologous end joining. After creating the same breaks, an RNA with complementary base can be added to silence the expression and knocking out the desired gene.

FELUDA is CRISPR-Cas9 based test to detect the genomic sequence of SARS-CoV-2 virus and is used as quicker, cheaper and effective alternative to RT-PCR.

Many proteins are synthesized as precursor pro-proteins that require modifications before attaining biologic activity. Many of the posttranslational modifications involve the removal of amino terminal amino acid residues by specific aminopeptidases, addition of hydroxyl and other groups by specific enzymes. CRISPR is a used for modification at transctiption or translational level and not a tool of post translational modification.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presented with amenorrhea for the past 4 months. On performing a USG, you notice the presence of twin gestation with a characteristic appearance as shown in the image below. You would identify the type of twin gestation as _________.
questions.solution:
The given USG image depicts the T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation.

In monochorionic diamniotic gestation, the twins are separated by thin amniotic membranes with no intervening chorion. At the point where the amnions meet the placenta a T sign is formed. It is best seen in the latter part of the first trimester or the beginning of the second trimester.

Below is an image of T sign:

In dichorionic gestation, the twins are separated by amniotic membranes and an intervening chorion. So, a thicker twin peak sign or lambda (λ) sign is formed at the point at which the amnions meet the placenta. It is best seen in the first trimester.

Below is an image of lamba sign:

Related Pearl: Twinning

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient diagnosed with Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome is on treatment with procainamide. Which of the following statements is not true regarding the drug?

choices.text: Procainamide is used in the management of  ventricular tachycardia.
N-acetyl procainamide lacks the sodium channel–blocking property.
Long-term usage can cause drug-induced lupus erythematosus.

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement is that it has α-adrenergic-blocking activity. It is not an alpha-blocker.

Procainamide belongs to the class IA of antiarrhythmics. It has the property of blocking sodium and potassium channels.

It is metabolized in the liver to N­-acetyl­ procainamide (NAPA). NAPA has no Na+ channel-blocking property but can block the potassium channels and prolongs repolarization. Procainamide is used in the acute treatment of  Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome with atrial fibrillation. It can be used in the acute and chronic treatment of atrial fibrillation (AF), ventricular fibrillation (VF), and tachycardia (VT).

Long-term therapy of procainamide can cause drug-induced lupus erythematosus. It resolves on the cessation of therapy or on treatment with only the metabolite N-acetyl procainamide. Torsades de pointes occurring in procainamide toxicity.

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding hemophilia A, except ______.

choices.text: It is seen more in males

questions.solution:
The false statement regarding hemophilia A is that mucosal bleeding is commonly seen. While moderate to severe forms may present with mucosal bleeding, it is not a common finding of hemophilia A and points more to the diagnosis of platelet disorders or von Willebrand disease.

Hemophilia A is an X-linked recessive disorder. It occurs due to a deficiency of clotting factor VIII which causes inadequate thrombin generation and thus the inability to form a tight fibrin clot to support the platelet plug.

Symptoms include easy bruising, intramuscular hematomas, hemarthroses, hematuria, and bleeding from minor traumatic lacerations of the mouth can persist for hours or days. Retroperitoneal hemorrhages can accumulate large volumes of blood and may cause a hypovolemic shock.

Laboratory findings in hemophilia A:

  • Factor VIII - reduced
  • Partial thromboplastin time (PTT) - prolonged
  • Platelet count- normal
  • Bleeding time- normal
  • Prothrombin time- normal

Based on the percent activity of specific clotting factors, hemophilia is classified into:

Severity The activity of a specific clotting factor
Severe <1%
Moderate 1-5%
Mild >5%

Mild cases of hemophilia are treated by the administration of desmopressin acetate. Moderate to severe cases need the replacement of deficient clotting factors (factor VIII in hemophilia A). Monoclonal antibody emicizumab can restore activated factor VIII activity in patients with hemophilia.

questions.text: What is the most common drawback of the given device?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a metered-dose inhaler (MDI). The most common side effect of this device is drug deposition in the oropharynx. 

Most material inhaled using this device will be swallowed and absorbed, entering systemic circulation after undergoing the first-pass effect in the liver. Some drug will also be absorbed into the systemic circulation from the lungs.

The use of a large-volume spacer will reduce the amount of drug deposited in the oropharynx, thereby reducing the amount swallowed and absorbed from the GI tract, thus limiting the systemic effects of the drug.

The given image shows the use of spacer with MDI:

 

Spacers reduce the velocity and size of particles entering the upper airways. This reduces the amount of drug that impinges on the oropharynx and increases the proportion of the drug inhaled into the lower airways.

Spacer devices are useful in delivering inhaled drugs to small children, as young as 3 years of age, who are not able to use a pMDI (pressurized MDI), as seen in the image below:

 

Pressurized metered-dose inhalers: Drugs are propelled from a canister in the pMDI with the aid of a propellant. These devices are convenient, portable, and typically deliver 50–200 doses of the drug.

Dry powder inhalers: Drugs may also be delivered as a dry powder using devices that scatter a fine powder dispersed by air turbulence on inhalation. Children less than 7 years of age find it difficult to use a DPI. DPIs have been developed to deliver peptides and proteins, such as insulin, systemically but have proved to be problematic because of the consistency of dosing.

The given image shows various types of dry powder inhalers:

 

Nebulizers: Two types of nebulizers are available. Jet nebulizers are driven by a stream of gas (air or oxygen), whereas ultrasonic nebulizers use a rapidly vibrating piezoelectric crystal and thus do not require a source of compressed gas.

The nebulized drug may be inspired during tidal breathing, and it is possible to deliver much higher doses of the drug as compared to pMDI. Nebulizers are therefore useful in treating acute exacerbations of asthma and COPD, for delivering drugs when airway obstruction is extreme (e.g., in severe COPD), for delivering inhaled drugs to infants and small children who cannot use the other inhalation devices, and for giving drugs such as antibiotics when relatively high doses must be delivered.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is not true for glycogen metabolism?
  1. Acetyl Co-A is a prime substrate to start gluconeogenesis.
  2. Glucose-6-phosphate inhibits glycogenolysis.
  3. Pompe disease is both a glycogen and lysosomal storage disorder.
  4. High insulin:glucagon ratio decreases glycogenesis.
questions.solution:
The false statements regarding glycogen metabolism are 1 and 4.

Acetyl coenzyme A is a common product of carbohydrate, protein, or fat catabolism. Statement 1 is false because it cannot give rise to a net synthesis of glucose (or glycogen) because of the irreversible nature of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex, which converts pyruvate to acetyl CoA. It can only be used to produce ketone bodies.

Glycogen is a storage form of glucose and a number of enzymes and substrates tightly regulate its synthesis. Statement 4 is false because the increase in insulin and glucose-6-phosphate following a meal activates glycogen synthase, the rate-limiting enzyme in glycogenesis by dephosphorylation. Thus, high insulin:glucagon ratio increases glycogenesis.

An increase in glucagon or epinephrine causes the phosphorylation of enzymes, making glycogen synthase inactive. Glycogen breakdown occurs by glycogen phosphorylase which is activated by phosphorylation. Glycogen synthase and phosphorylase are reciprocally regulated.

Statement 2 is true. Active phosphorylase A, which phosphorylates and activates the glycogen phosphorylase enzyme, is allosterically inhibited by ATP and glucose-6-phosphate. Thus, glucose-6-phosphate leads to the inhibition of glycogenolysis.

Statement 3 is true. Impaired breakdown or synthesis of glycogen leads to a variety of disorders. Pompe's disease (type 2 glycogen storage disease) occurs due to α-1,4-glucosidase (acid maltase) deficiency. It is the only glycogen storage disease that is a lysosomal storage disease and causes lysosomal glycogen accumulation in cardiac, skeletal, and smooth muscle cells. The clinical symptoms of Pompe disease are hypotonia (floppy infant), skeletal muscle weakness, hepatomegaly, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, and macroglossia.

questions.text: A gross specimen of the colon obtained from a 14-year-old boy is shown below. Which of the following statements is false about this pathology?

choices.text: It occurs as a result of a defect in the DNA mismatch repair mechanism.
At least 100 polyps are needed to make the diagnosis.
Prophylactic colectomy is done for patients with APC mutations.
It is associated with congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium.

questions.solution:
The gross specimen in the image shows the presence of multiple polyps in the colon, along with an area suspicious of colorectal carcinoma. Multiple polyps in the colon of a 14-year-old boy make familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) the likely diagnosis.

FAP is an autosomal dominant disorder that is caused by mutations of the adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) gene and not due to defects in the DNA repair mechanism. Defects in DNA mismatch repair genes result in hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer, MYH-associated polyposis, and some sporadic colon cancers.

Familial adenomatous polyposis, as the name suggests, is an inherited disorder presenting with numerous colorectal adenomatous polyps. It is an autosomal dominant disease caused by mutations in the APC gene, which is a regulator in the Wnt signaling pathway. At least 100 polyps are required to make a diagnosis of FAP. 

Patients are usually teenagers and multiple polyps are visible in the colon during sigmoidoscopy. It is associated with a variety of extraintestinal manifestations including congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigmental epithelium. Colorectal adenocarcinoma occurs in almost all cases before the age of 50. 

Prophylactic colectomy is recommended in patients with APC gene mutations. The surgeries used are colectomy with ileorectal anastomosis (IRA), restorative proctocolectomy with an ileal pouch-anal anastomosis (RPC), or total proctectomy and end ileostomy. The first 2 surgeries are preferred in young patients as it avoids a permanent stoma. 

Note- FAP along with brain tumors is called Turcot syndrome. FAP along with multiple osteomas, skin, and soft tissue tumors is called Gardner syndrome.

Related Pearl: Features of Familial Adenomatous Polyposis

Gastrointestinal manifestations:

  • Colon and rectum: Multiple adenomatous polyps usually >100
  • Gastric and duodenal polyps are present
  • Gastric polyp: fundal gland polyp, gastric adenoma
  • Duodenal polyp usually in the ampullary region: Adenomatous and premalignant

Extraintestinal manifestations

  • Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE) is seen. It is detected by indirect ophthalmoscopy.
  • Epidermoid cysts
  • Desmoid tumors in the abdomen
  • Osteoma in the skull, mandible, and tibia
  • Brain tumors
  • Tumors of the thyroid, adrenal, liver, pancreas, gallbladder, and bile duct

questions.text:
Match the following:
A. Hypertensive emergency 1. BP of 200/140 mmHg along with papilledema
B. Hypertensive urgency 2. BP of 162/104 mmHg despite taking three antihypertensive agents, including a diuretic
C. Malignant hypertension 3. Alteration in mental status, nausea, headache, and a BP of 190/130 mmHg
D. Resistant hypertension 4. BP of 188/120 mmHg without any target organ damage
questions.solution:
The correctly matched options are A-3, B-4, C-1, D-2 as shown below:

A. Hypertensive emergency 3. Alteration in mental status, nausea, headache, and a BP of 190/130 mmHg 
B. Hypertensive urgency 4. BP of 188/120 mmHg without any target organ damage
C. Malignant hypertension 1. BP of 200/140 mmHg along with papilledema
D. Resistant hypertension 2. BP of 162/104 mmHg despite taking three antihypertensive agents, including a diuretic

Severe hypertension (grade 3) is generally defined as blood pressure ≥180/110 mmHg. Hypertensive emergency, hypertensive urgency, and malignant hypertension are all forms of severe hypertension.  

Option A: The patient has a BP >180/120 mmHg along with symptoms of hypertensive encephalopathy. This is an example of a hypertensive emergency as there is severe hypertension with signs or symptoms of hypertensive-mediated organ damage (HMOD). 

Option B: The patient has BP >180/110 mmHg and no end-organ damage. This is a case of hypertensive urgency. Target organ damage is absent in hypertensive urgency butpresent in a hypertensive emergency. 

Option C: The patient has a BP >180/120 mmHg along with papilledema. This is a case of severe hypertension associated with fundoscopic changes (flame hemorrhages, papilledema), which is suggestive of hypertensive-mediated organ damage (HMOD). This is an example of hypertensive emergency, which is also known as malignant hypertension.

Option D: The patient has BP >140/90 mmHg despite taking three or more antihypertensive agents, including a diuretic. This is a case of resistant hypertension, and it is more common in patients aged >60 years than in younger patients. Resistant hypertension may be related to pseudohypertension (high office blood pressure and lower home blood pressure), nonadherence to therapy, and identifiable causes of hypertension including obesity and excessive alcohol intake.

Note: Options 1 and 3 can be correctly matched with either option A or C.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man was referred for infertility evaluation. On examination, he was tall with a lack of body hair. Gynecomastia and micropenis were also noted. Karyotyping analysis revealed an XXY karyotype. Which of the following statements is not true about the condition?

choices.text: Levels of follicle-stimulating hormone are reduced

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Klinefelter's syndrome. In this condition, the follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) levels are elevated. 

The clinical features include:

  • Eunuchoid body habitus - elongated body and long legs (increased length between the soles and the pubic bone)
  • Absence of secondary sexual characteristics - lack of body and facial hair, deep voice
  • Small atrophic testes
  • Micropenis
  • Gynecomastia
  • Lower IQ, but no mental retardation

The following hormonal variations are seen in these patients:

  • Elevated FSH
  • Elevated estradiol
  • Low testosterone
  • Insulin resistance - increased incidence of type 2 diabetes

Patients with Klinefelter syndrome are at a higher risk for:

  • Male breast cancer (20x more common than in normal males)
  • Extragonadal germ cell tumors
  • Autoimmune diseases - systemic lupus erythematosus

questions.text: According to its mechanism of action, sumatriptan is a _____.
questions.solution:
Sumatriptan is a 5-HT1B and 5-HT1D receptor agonist. The pharmacological effects of the drug are limited to the 5HT1 family of receptors.

The activation of 5HT1B/1D receptors causes constriction of intracranial blood vessels and restores blood flow to the brain. It also acts by preventing vasoactive peptide release.

Side effects are coronary vasospasm, mild paresthesia, and serotonin syndrome (in combination with other 5-HT agonists).

Repeated attacks of headache lasting 4-72 h in patients with a normal physical examination with no other reasonable cause for the headache, and

At least 2 of the following features:

  • Throbbing pain
  • Aggravation by movement
  • Moderate or severe intensity

Plus at least 1 of the following features:

  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Photophobia and phonophobia

questions.text:
Which of the following is a feature of asthma?

FEV1: Forced expiratory volume in 1 sec; FVC: Forced vital capacity.

choices.text: Bronchodilator response (to inhaled β-agonist): Improvement in FEV1 ≥12%
No day to day variation in FEV1
Exercise challenge leads to worsening in FEV1 ≥5%

questions.solution:
Bronchodilator response (to inhaled β-agonist): Improvement in FEV1 ≥12% is a feature of asthma.

The following lung function abnormalities are seen in childhood asthma:

  • Spirometry showing airflow limitation:
    •  Low FEV1 (relative to the percentage of predicted norms)
    •  FEV1:FVC ratio <0.80 (Option C)
  • Bronchodilator response (to inhaled β-agonist): Improvement in FEV1 ≥12% and ≥200 mL (Option A)
  • Exercise challenge: Worsening in FEV1 ≥15% (Option D)
  • Daily peak flow or FEV1 monitoring: day-to-day and/or A.M.-to-P.M. variation ≥20% (Option B)

questions.text: You are monitoring a 45-year-old female patient in the postoperative ward. Her 24-hour urine output is 1.5 mL/min, serum creatinine is 1.0 mg/dL, and urine creatinine is 60 mg/dL. What is the patient's creatinine clearance rate?
questions.solution:
The creatinine clearance in this patient is 90 mL/min.

Creatinine clearance is defined as the volume of plasma from which creatinine is completely removed by the kidney in a given amount of time (usually minutes).

The formula used to calculate creatinine clearance (CCr) is:

 UCr × V ⁄ PCr  where,

UCr - Urine creatinine (mg/dL)

PCr - Serum creatinine (mg/dL)

V - Urine volume (mL/min)

Note: The creatinine clearance is usually expressed in mL/min; hence, the preferred unit of urine volume is mL/min, which is calculated based on the 24-hour urine volume. While calculating, ensure that both the urine creatinine and serum creatinine have the same units (either mg/dL or mg/mL).

In the given question,

UCr = 60 mg/dL

PCr = 1.0 mg/dL

V  = 1.5 mL/min

Substituting the values given in the question, we get:

Creatinine clearance =  UCr × V ⁄ PCr ,

= (60 x 1.5)/1

= 60 x 1.5

= 90 mL/min

Creatinine is a by-product of muscle metabolism and is cleared from the body fluids almost entirely by glomerular filtration. Therefore, the clearance of creatinine is used to assess GFR.

questions.text:
Which of the following conditions will you not diagnose as toxic epidermal necrolysis?

A. Purpuric macules and erosions affecting 25% of body surface area, including mucosa

B. Purpuric macules and erosions affecting 8% of body surface area, including mucosa

C. Purpuric macules and erosions affecting more than 35% of body surface area, including mucosa

D. Purpuric macules and erosions affecting more than 40% of body surface area, including mucosa
questions.solution:
Toxic epidermal necrolysis is not diagnosed in options A and B as they are characterized by erosions affecting less than 30% of the body surface area.

Stevens-Johnson syndrome and toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) are severe mucocutaneous reactions, usually to drugs, characterized by blistering, epithelial sloughing, and necrosis. The blisters will develop on top of target lesions or macular lesions with significant involvement of the mucosal layer. The two terms describe phenotypes within a severity spectrum, where SJS is the less extensive form and TEN is the more extensive.

Based on the type of cutaneous lesion and extent of maximal epidermal detachment, the disease is classified as follows:

Common drugs that can cause SJS/TEN:

  • Allopurinol

  • Anti-epileptics - phenobarbital, phenytoin, carbamazepine, lamotrigine
  • Antibiotics - penicillins, cephalosporins, sulfamethoxazole, sulfasalazine, nevirapine

Mycoplasma pneumoniae is the most common bacterial infection associated with the development of SJS and TEN, especially in children.

questions.text: Identify the organism below that causes effacement and attachment of intestinal cells.
questions.solution:
Attachment and effacement lesions on intestinal cells are caused by enteropathogenic Escherichia coli (EPEC).

E. coli is the second most common cause of diarrhea in the pediatric age group. Rotavirus is the most common cause. EPEC causes watery diarrhea which is self-limiting.

EPEC adheres to the mucosal cells of the small bowel and causes loss of microvilli (effacement). This leads to the formation of filamentous actin pedestals or cuplike structures and occasionally may cause entry of the EPEC into the mucosal cells.

 Pathogenicity requires the presence of two important factors:

  •  Bundle-forming pilus encoded by plasmid containing EPEC adherence factor (EAF).
  •  Chromosomal locus of enterocyte effacement (LEE) pathogenicity island.

questions.text: A patient underwent total laryngectomy for laryngeal cancer. Identify the modality of voice production involved in the device shown in the image given below.
questions.solution:
The modality of voice production shown in the given image is the electrolarynx.

The electrolarynx produces vibrations that are transmitted through the skin towards the throat. The sound generated is converted into low-pitch speech by the vocal tract—palate, tongue, and teeth. The advantages are that is easy and quick to learn, while the disadvantages are that the voice is monotonous and requires constant occupation of one hand.

Other options:

Tracheoesophageal prosthesis (option A) - The exhaled air from the trachea is diverted to the oesophagus via a device that connects the trachea and oesophagus. It has a one-way valve, which prevents food from entering the trachea. A variety of tracheoesophageal prostheses are available, including the Provox, Blom-Singer, and Panje devices.

 

Oesophageal speech (option D) - The patient is trained to swallow air and slowly release it into the pharynx. 6-10 words can be spoken in a rough manner before re swallowing the air.

A transoral pneumatic device (option B) is an artificial larynx used in those who fail to learn oesophageal speech. The vibrations generated in a rubber diaphragm are carried by a plastic tube into the back of the oral cavity. Here the sound is converted into speech by modulators. It uses expired air from the tracheostome to vibrate the diaphragm.

questions.text:
The reaction complex similar to one given below is present in which of the following enzymes?
  1. Pyruvate dehydrogenase
  2. α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase
  3. Succinate dehydrogenase
  4. Branched-chain ketoacid dehydrogenase
questions.solution:
The multienzyme complex that catalyzes oxidative decarboxylation reactions is present in 1,2 and 4.

The given pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH) complex is a multienzyme complex that is associated with the inner mitochondrial membrane. It catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA which enters the citric acid/Kreb’s cycle. It has 5 cofactors

Enzyme components of PDH complex                        Co-factors
Pyruvate dehydrogenase (E1) Thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP)

The other three multienzyme complexes that catalyze oxidative decarboxylation reactions are

  • α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase in the citric acid cycle.
  • Branched-chain ketoacid dehydrogenase is involved in the metabolism of leucine, isoleucine, and valine.

This can explain why a deficiency of thiamine causes reduced energy production.

Succinate dehydrogenase transfers reducing equivalents directly to the electron transport chain using riboflavin and is not analogous to the PDH complex.

questions.text: You are attending to a patient who is in labor. You can see the biparietal diameter of the fetal head stretching the vulval outlet. As the contraction gets over, the head remains in that position without recessing back. What do you expect to happen next?
questions.solution:
The biparietal diameter of the fetal head (maximum diameter of the head) stretching the vulval outlet and not recessing after the end of contraction is known as crowning. Extension is expected to happen next.

The mechanism of labor refers to the positional changes of the presenting part required for the fetus to travel through the pelvic canal during labor.

In normal labor, the most common presentation is cephalic and the presenting part is the vertex. The vertex enters the pelvis with the sagittal suture in the transverse pelvic diameter. The fetus generally enters the pelvis in the left occipitotransverse position.

The specific cardinal movements of labor are:

  • Engagement is the mechanism by which the biparietal diameter (in occiput presentation) passes through the pelvic inlet.
  • Descent is a continuous process that is completed with the expulsion of the fetus.
  • Flexion of the head occurs as soon as the descending head meets resistance from the pelvic floor/pelvic walls/cervix. With this movement, the chin is drawn closer to the fetal thorax, and the appreciably shorter suboccipitobregmatic diameter replaces the longer occipitofrontal diameter
  • Internal rotation is the mechanism by which the occiput gradually turns away from the transverse axis. Crowning occurs after internal rotation when the vulval outlet is stretched by the maximum diameter of the head and there is non-recession of the head after the contraction is over.
  • Extension- with progressive distension of the perineum, the head extends out in order as occiput, anterior fontanelle, brow, nose, mouth, and chin.
  • External rotation/restitution is the visible passive movement of the delivered head by which it untwists its neck and regains a transverse position.
  • Expulsion is the process by which the anterior shoulder is followed by the posterior shoulder and the rest of the fetal body is delivered.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true about the anterior border of the structure marked?

1. It is a part of the lesser omentum.

2. It is a derivative of the ventral mesentery.

3. It is clamped to prevent bleeding from hepatic veins and inferior vena cava.

4. Its contents are the hepatic artery, hepatic vein, and common bile duct.
questions.solution:
Statements A and B are true about the hepatoduodenal ligament. 

The structure marked in the given image is the epiploic foramen. The hepatoduodenal ligament, which is formed by the thickened free right margin of the lesser omentum (Statement 1), forms the anterior boundary of the epiploic foramen. Lesser omentum develops from the ventral mesogastrium (Statement 2) and the part of it between the liver and the duodenum is called the hepatoduodenal ligament.

Within this free border lies the following structures (Statement 4):

  • Bile duct (anteriorly on the right)
  • Hepatic artery (anteriorly on the left)
  • Portal vein (posteriorly) 

The Pringle maneuver is performed when there is excessive bleeding from the liver. In this maneuver, the hepatoduodenal ligament is occluded with a vessel loop or vascular clamp. This helps to stop the blood flow from the hepatic artery and portal vein (Statement 3). Hence, if bleeding continues even after performing this maneuver, that means that the source of the bleeding must be the hepatic vein or inferior vena cava.

The epiploic foramen is a vertical slit of about 3 cm behind the free right border of the lesser omentum. It connects the lesser sac to the greater sac. The pearl summarizes the various relations of the foramen.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with painful menses and pain during intercourse. She has not conceived despite having unprotected intercourse for the past 2 years. Per vaginal examination reveals tenderness in the lateral fornices. On bimanual examination, a normal-sized nulligravid uterus is felt. A speculum examination reveals bluish-puckered spots in the posterior fornix. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient’s painful menses (dysmenorrhea), pain during intercourse (dyspareunia), lateral fornicial tenderness, bluish spots in the posterior fornix, and infertility suggest endometriosis.

Endometriosis is the presence of endometrial tissue at a site outside the uterine cavity. It is found in ectopic sites such as the ovary, pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligaments, appendix, pelvic lymph nodes, lower segment cesarean section (LSCS) scar endometriosis, umbilicus, and lung.

Endometriosis can present as blue or red powdered burned lesions on the cervix or posterior vaginal fornix, scarring around the tissue (puckered look). Other features include chocolate cysts causing left/right lower quadrant pain, pain during defecation, chronic pelvic pain and infertility, right lower quadrant pain, and cyclical hemoptysis.

Laparoscopy is the gold standard modality for the diagnosis and treatment of endometriosis. 'Powder-burn' - puckered black spots, red vascular, bluish, blackish cysts, chocolate cysts, and dense adhesions in the pelvis, as well as yellow-brown peritoneal fluid, can be seen on laparoscopy.

For minimal disease medical management with NSAIDs and oral contraceptive pills are given if associated menstrual complaints are present. OCPs inhibit gonadotropin release and decrease the menstrual flow. For moderate to severe diseases oral progestogens, GnRH agonists or danazol that antagonize estrogenic effects on the endometrium causing endometrial atrophy are used.

Surgery is preferred in infertile women because hormonal treatment would delay pregnancy. Endometrial deposits are destroyed by electrocautery/laser and resection of endometrioma can be done. Laparoscopic uterosacral nerve ablation (LUNA) to control pain .Total hysterectomy with bilateral oophorectomy is a definitive and most effective therapy for women with endometriosis who do not wish to retain fertility.

Option A- Chronic pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) closely mimics endometriosis in its symptoms and signs. Both conditions produce pelvic pain, congestive dysmenorrhea, menorrhagia, and sterility. The uterus is retroverted and fixed. But in chronic PID, thickened and slightly tender fornices or a tubo-ovarian mass is noted and speculum finding as seen in the patient described above is not seen in chronic PID.

Option B - Rectocele is a form of genital prolapse seen frequently in menopausal women, especially those with a history of pelvic floor injury or multiparity. Patients present with varying degrees of prolapsed mass per rectum that needs splinting for a satisfactory bowel movement. 

 Option C - Adenomyosis, a condition seen frequently in elderly women (Aged> 40 years), is characterized by endometrial islands in the wall of the uterus, leading to a symmetrically enlarged uterus (not more than 14 weeks size). Usual presenting features include menorrhagia and progressively increasing dysmenorrhea. Per vaginal exam findings are normal.

Related Pearl: Endometriosis

Sites of Endometriosis:

  • Pelvic endometriosis: Pelvic peritoneum, the pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligament.
  • Rectovaginal endometriosis.
  • Ovarian endometriosis.
  • Chocolate cyst of the ovary.
  • Other sites—appendix, pelvic lymph nodes.
  • Metastatic— lungs, umbilicus, scar endometriosis.

One pathology review revealed that endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Examination findings in endometriosis:

  • Abdomen: Cystic swelling, fixed and tender.
  • Pelvis: Cystic tender mass.
  • Vaginal examination: Fixed, tender, retroverted uterus. Tenderness in the lateral fornices (indicative of endometriosis even if no mass).
    • Speculum inspection of the Posterior fornix: Bluish/blackish puckered spots on speculum, tender to touch. The presence of puckered spots is pathognomonic of endometriosis.
    • Posterior Fornix Palpation: Uterosacral ligaments & pouch of Douglas feel thickened and shotty with multiple small palpable nodules. This is called the cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient involved in a road traffic accident was brought unconscious to the emergency room. CT brain reveals the following findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is subdural hemorrhage (SDH). The above clinical scenario and the plain computed tomography (CT) scan shows a concavo-convex-shaped hematoma on the left side suggestive of an acute subdural hematoma (SDH).

Acute SDH results from the accumulation of blood between the arachnoid membrane and the dura. The tearing of a bridging vein from the cerebral cortex to the dural sinuses is the most common cause of acute SDH.

On head CT scan, acute SDH appears as a hyperdense, crescent-shaped (concavo-convex) lesion as seen in this question.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with a history of blunt trauma to the pelvis was diagnosed with urethral rupture. Imaging revealed an injury to the bulbar urethra below the perineal membrane. The extravasated urine is likely to get accumulated in ________.
questions.solution:
Injury to the bulbar urethra below the perineal membrane leads to the accumulation of urine in the superficial perineal pouch.

The rupture of the urethra below the urogenital diaphragm will result in extravasation of urine into the superficial perineal pouch, penis, and scrotum in males and labia majora in females, and the anterior abdominal wall.

The superficial fascia of the abdomen is divided below the umbilicus into a superficial fatty layer (fascia of Camper) and a deep membranous layer (fascia of Scarpa). Scarpa's fascia is continuous with the membranous layer of the superficial perineal fascia (Colles' fascia). 

Colles' fascia is attached to fascia lata (the deep fascia of the thigh) along the Holden's line that extends from the pubic tubercle laterally for 8 cm. Extravasated fluid cannot pass into the medial thigh below Holden's line due to the firm attachment of Colles' fascia to the fascia lata. 

 

Contents of superficial perineal pouch: 

  • Corpora cavernosa and corpus spongiosum
  • Three muscles – the ischiocavernosus, bulbospongiosus and superficial transverse perineal
  • The greater vestibular glands (Bartholin’s glands) in females and duct of bulbourethral glands in males.
  • Arteries: Branches of perineal artery (Posterior scrotal and Transverse perineal arteries) and Branches of artery of penis (Artery to bulb, urethral artery, deep artery of penis and dorsal artery of penis)
  • Nerves: Long perineal nerve, Branches of perineal nerve (Posterior scrotal, Nerve to bulb and Muscular branches)
  • Clitoris in female
  • Urethra in male

 

Other options - 

Option A: Deep perineal pouch encloses the space between the endopelvic fascia and the perineal membrane and includes the following contents:

  • Membranous urethra
  • Muscles: Sphincter urethrae and deep transverse perinei muscles
  • Nerves: Dorsal nerve of penis and muscular branches of the perineal nerve
  • Vessels: Artery of penis
  • Glands: Bulbourethral glands in males

Thus, any injury to urethra in this pouch can lead to the accumulation of urine in the deep perineal pouch. It can even spread upwards into the extraperitoneal space around the bladder and prostate and into the anterior abdominal wall. 

Option C: Space of Retzius, also known as the retropubic space is an extraperitoneal space located posterior to the pubic symphysis and anterior to the urinary bladder. 

Option D: Pouch of Douglas, also known as the rectouterine pouch in females, or rectovesical pouch in males, is the most dependent part of the peritoneal cavity in the erect position. Any infection or fluid collection tends to get accumulated in this dependent region.

questions.text:
Which among the following statements are true regarding gastric hormones?
  1. Secretin stimulates pancreatic enzymes
  2. Gastrin inhibits gastric acid secretion
  3. Gastric inhibitory peptide (GIP) inhibits insulin release
  4. Motilin stimulates gastric motility
  5. Cholecystokinin (CCK) inhibits gastric emptying
questions.solution:
The correct statements are 4 and 5.

Secretin is secreted by the S cells of the duodenum. Its primary function is to promote the secretion of bicarbonate-rich pancreatic juice by the ductal cells of the pancreas and duodenum. This secretion is poor in enzymes.

Gastrin is secreted by G cells of the antrum, duodenum, and jejunum. It stimulates gastric acid secretion and mucosal growth.

Gastric inhibitory peptide (GIP) or glucose-dependent insulinotropic peptide is secreted by K cells of the duodenum and jejunum. It stimulates insulin release and inhibits gastric secretion. 

Motilin is secreted by M cells of the duodenum and jejunum. It stimulates gastric and intestinal motility.

Cholecystokinin (CCK) is secreted by I cells of the duodenum, jejunum, and ileum. It stimulates pancreatic enzyme secretion, pancreatic bicarbonate secretion, gallbladder contraction, and growth of the exocrine pancreas. It also inhibits gastric emptying.

questions.text:
Match the following microscopic findings to the disease conditions in which they are seen.
Microscopic findings Lung disease
1. Coal-laden macrophages  A. Silicosis
2. Golden-brown fusiform rods  B. Hypersensitivity pneumonitis
3. Non-necrotizing granulomas  C. Anthracosis
4. Nodules of whorled collagen fibers D. Asbestosis
questions.solution:
The correct match is Option 2: 1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A.

Anthracosis/ coal workers' pneumoconiosis is a pulmonary condition seen in coal miners. It is caused due to the phagocytosis of the inhaled carbonaceous pigment by the alveolar or interstitial macrophages and its subsequent accumulation in the connective tissue spaces. With continued exposure, lung tissue undergoes progressive massive fibrosis. The upper lobes and upper zones of the lower lobes of the lungs are commonly involved.

Microscopic features consist of coal-laden macrophages, black pigment, and dense collagenous interstitial fibrosis (in advanced stages), as shown in the image below.

 

Asbestosis occurs due to the inhalation of crystalline hydrated silicates (asbestos). It is characterized by diffuse parenchymal interstitial fibrosis. It usually begins in the lower lobes of the lungs. Other asbestos-related diseases include pleural plaques, recurrent pleural effusions, lung carcinoma, and mesothelioma.

Hallmark microscopic findings are golden brown, fusiform or beaded rods called asbestos bodies, as shown in the image below. These are formed when the asbestos fibers phagocytosed by the macrophages are coated by iron-containing proteinaceous material derived from phagocyte ferritin. Pleural plaques of dense collagen that may be calcified are the most common manifestation of asbestos exposure. They involve the anterior and posterolateral aspects of the parietal pleura and the diaphragmatic domes.

 

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis is an immunologically mediated granulomatous disease that occurs in response to continuous exposure to inhaled organic antigens (mold, hay dust, bird proteins, thermophilic bacteria in air-conditioning units). Pathological changes in response to such exposures are mediated by the CD4+ and CD8+ T-lymphocytes (type IV hypersensitivity reactions) and proinflammatory chemokines.

Microscopic findings include interstitial pneumonitis (lymphocytes, plasma cells, and macrophages) and non-necrotizing granulomas, as shown in the image below. Chronic disease gives rise to obliterative bronchiolitis and honeycombing.

 

Silicosis occurs due to inhalation of crystalline silicon dioxide (silica) as seen in individuals employed in concrete work and sandblasting. Macrophages incorporate inhaled silica particles, thereby activating and releasing inflammatory mediators (IL-1, IL-8) that cause fibroblast recruitment. Subsequently, collagen is deposited in the interstitium. Upper lung zones and hilar lymph nodes are commonly involved.

Microscopy reveals coalescent nodules of whorled collagen fibers surrounded by a peripheral zone of silica-laden macrophages, as shown in the image below. As the disease progresses, these nodules coalesce into scars. Sometimes, thin sheets of calcification can occur in hilar lymph nodes, giving an eggshell appearance.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient came with complaints of excessive lacrimation. Ocular examination showed an abnormality similar to what is shown below. Which of the following organism is likely to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
The above image shows Herbert's pits. This finding is seen in trachoma, which is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, more specifically the trachoma inclusion conjunctivitis (TRIC) serovars A, B, Ba, C. 

Trachoma is a form of chronic infective conjunctivitis and is one of the leading causes of blindness. It has an ‘active’ inflammatory stage and a ‘cicatricial’ chronic stage.

The active inflammatory stage is more prevalent in children and presents with nonspecific symptoms of ocular irritation, foreign body sensation, and discharge (often mild symptoms). Examination findings at this stage show: 

  • Conjunctival follicles contain Leber cells (multinucleated lymphocytes)
  • corneal Herbert's follicles (similar to conjunctival follicles)

Cicatricial chronic stage is seen in middle age. And when the chronic infection with sequelae sets in, the patient complains of pain, lacrimation, photophobia, and later blurring, and finally loss of vision. Conjunctiva shows concretions (whitish deposits of inspissated mucus in depressions called glands of Henle). Corneal signs include: 

  • Herbert pits (pitted scars in the limbal which are remnants of healed Herbert follicles)
  • corneal opacity is seen in later stages.

There can be associated trichiasis ( when at least one eyelash rubs the eyeball) and entropion.

At present WHO grading with 'FISTO' is in use.

Trachoma is treated according to the WHO classification using the SAFE strategy (Surgery, Antibiotics, Facial hygiene, and Environmental improvement). Azithromycin is the antibiotic of choice, and surgery involves the correction of trichiasis and entropion. In case of significant corneal scarring, penetrating keratoplasty is done.

Related Pearl: WHO classification of trachoma (FISTO)

WHO grading of trachoma

  • TF = trachomatous inflammation (follicular): five or more follicles (>0.5 mm) on the superior tarsal conjunctiva.
  • TI = trachomatous inflammation (intense): diffuse involvement of the tarsal conjunctiva, obscuring 50% or more of the normal deep tarsal vessels; papillae are present
  • TS = trachomatous conjunctival scarring: easily visible fibrous white tarsal bands
  • TT = trachomatous trichiasis: at least one lash touching the globe
  • CO = corneal opacity sufficient to blur details of at least part of the pupillary margin

Related Pearl: WHO Programme to Control Trachoma: SAFE Strategy

  • S—Surgery: Trichiasis and entropion correction surgery → 3° prevention.
  • A—Antibiotics: Oral azithromycin, topical 1% tetracycline, topical 1% azithromycin → 2° prevention
  • F—Facial hygiene → 1° prevention.
  • E—Environmental cleanliness → primordial prevention

The strategy depends on the prevalence of trachoma follicle in children (aged 1–9 yrs)

  • >10% → Mass antibiotic treatment at the community level and FE measures
  • 5 to 10% → Targeted antibiotic treatment (affected families) and FE measures
  • < 5% → FE measures

questions.text: A Brazilian tourist who has traveled to India on vacation presents with lesions on his chest and back. The lesions are shown below. On examination, no oral or mucosal lesions are found. Acantholytic cells are seen on the Tzanck smear. A histopathological sample is sent for further examination. Which type of blister is present in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the lesions seen in a Brazilian patient and acantholysis on Tzanck smear, without oral or mucosal lesions is highly suggestive of pemphigus foliaceus. It is characterized by a subcorneal blister.

Pemphigus foliaceus is a benign form of pemphigus, an inflammatory blistering disorder, that is endemic in Brazil and occurs sporadically in other geographic regions. This is a form of a subcorneal blister, where the stratum corneum forms the roof of the bulla. It is caused by autoantibodies that result in the dissolution of intercellular attachments within the epidermis. There is no involvement of the mucosal epithelium in pemphigus foliaceus but is rarely affected.

Lesions are most common on the scalp, face, chest, and back. Bullae are superficial and mainly present as areas of erythema and crusting. These represent superficial erosions at sites of blister rupture.

Other options:

Suprabasal blisters: A portion of the epidermis, including the stratum corneum, forms the roof. They are seen in conditions such as pemphigus vulgaris.

Subepidermal blisters: The entire epidermis separates from the dermis. They are seen in conditions such as bullous pemphigoid.

Junctional blisters: These are blisters at the basal lamina. This type of blister is seen in conditions such as junctional epidermolysis bullosa, bullous pemphigoid, and toxic epidermal necrolysis.

questions.text: The brain CT scan of a 42-year-old man shows multiple calcifications and two cystic lesions in the brain parenchyma with surrounding edema. Stool examination reveals round eggs as shown in the image below. Which of the following statements is not correct regarding this condition?

choices.text: It occurs primarily due to ingestion of larva.
It can be seen in vegetarians
Scolex has four suckers and one rostellum with hooks.
Man can be a definitive or intermediate host.

questions.solution:
The CT scan with multiple punctate calcifications and cystic lesions in brain tissue suggests neurocysticercosis caused by Taenia solium. It primarily occurs due to the ingestion of eggs from contaminated sources and not larvae.

T. solium mainly causes two forms of infection in humans:

  • Intestinal taeniasis- Adult tapeworms in the intestine. It results when raw or undercooked meats containing the cysticerci are ingested. Intestinal taeniasis may be asymptomatic with the passage of proglottids in the feces.
  • Cysticercosis- Larva forms in the tissues. It results from the ingestion of food or water contaminated with eggs or by auto-infection from the eggs that are laid in the intestine. In cysticercosis, the cysticerci are most commonly detected in the brain, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), skeletal muscle, subcutaneous tissue, or eye.

The adult worm has a scolex with four suckers and a rostellum with hooks. As eggs are present in contaminated food or water, neurocysticercosis can occur even in vegetarians. Since humans carry larvae or eggs or both, they are considered both intermediate and definitive hosts. 

Neurocysticercosis is the most common form of cysticercosis, presenting with seizures, and symptoms of increased intracranial pressure including headache, nausea, vomiting, vision changes, dizziness, ataxia, or confusion. Papilledema may develop secondary to hydrocephalus.  

Diagnosis is by fecal examination showing eggs of Taenia. Biopsy of the brain or spinal cord lesion showing parasite or fundoscopic visualization of subretinal cysticercus can be done. Imaging could demonstrate a scolex within a cystic lesion, cystic lesions with or without enhancement (e.g., ring enhancement), nodular calcifications, focal enhancing lesions, or multilobulated cystic lesions in the subarachnoid space.

Treatment of intestinal T. solium infection is by a single dose of praziquantel. Neurocysticercosis is treated with anti-epileptic drugs, anticysticidal drugs like albendazole or praziquantel, and steroids given before anticysticidal therapy.

questions.text: A neonate is brought with increased irritability, poor feeding, and 2 episodes of seizures. A lumbar puncture was done to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following is true about the diagnosis?

choices.text: One of the common organism causing this in neonates produces CAMP factor.
Neisseria meningitidis is a common cause of this disease in neonates.
If Listeria is suspected as the cause, third generation cephalosporins must be added to empirical treatment.
In Haemophilus influenzae cases, close contacts receive ceftriaxone for prophylaxis.

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of increased irritability, poor feeding, and 2 episodes of seizures in a neonate and a lumbar puncture being done to confirm the diagnosis is suggestive of neonatal meningitis. One of the common bacterial cause of meningitis in neonates is Streptococcus agalactiae (group B streptococci), which produces the CAMP factor.

Option B: The common bacterial causes of neonatal meningitis are Escherichia coli > Group B streptococci and Listeria monocytogenes. 

Option C: If Listeria is suspected as the cause, ampicillin must be added to empirical treatment as it is not susceptible to cephalosporins. Neonatal listeriosis can be predominantly septicemic early-onset neonatal disease (<5 days) and a predominantly meningitic late-onset disease (>5 days).

Option D: In Haemophilus influenzae cases, rifampin is indicated as prophylaxis for all members of the household or close-contact group, including the index patient, if the group includes children <48 months old who are not fully immunized. The need for prophylaxis has greatly decreased because many children are now protected by prior immunization. Prophylaxis is not recommended for pregnant women.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presented with symptoms of pain, swelling, and morning stiffness in both hands and feet for 4 months. Which of the following is the most specific antibody that would be helpful to distinguish this condition from other joint disorders?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is suggestive of a diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis. Anti-citrullinated peptide antibody (Anti-CCP) is the most specific antibody that can be used to distinguish rheumatoid arthritis from other forms of arthritis.

Rheumatoid arthritis is the most common chronic inflammatory disorder characterized by symmetric polyarthritis. Clinical features occur due to underlying inflammation of the tendons, joints, and bursae. Patients present with symptoms of early morning stiffness lasting for more than an hour which decreases with physical activity. Small joints of the hands and feet are the most commonly involved joints. Monoarticular, oligoarticular, and polyarticular joint involvement can occur. 

The most frequently involved small joints of the hands are wrists, proximal interphalangeal joints (PIP) and metacarpophalangeal joints (MCP).

Rheumatoid factor and anti-CCP antibodies are antibodies of significance. IgM, IgG, and IgA are the various isotypes found in the sera of patients with rheumatoid arthritis. Rheumatoid factor is a non-specific antibody. It can be positive in other conditions such as Sjogren's syndrome, mixed cryoglobulinemia, systemic lupus erythematosus, and chronic inflammatory infectious disorders.

Anti-CCP antibodies have 95% specificity if tested positive. RF and anti-CCP antibodies also have prognostic significance. Anti-CCP antibodies positivity is associated with increased value for predicting worse outcomes.

Other minor antibodies that are positive in rheumatoid arthritis are anti-nuclear antibodies (ANA), and antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA).

Option C: Antineutrophil antibodies (ANCA) are positive in active granulomatous polyangiitis and microscopic polyangiitis. They are known as ANCA-associated vasculitis.

questions.text: Which of the following visual field defects demonstrates a lesion in the optic radiation in the temporal lobe?
questions.solution:
Image 3 (Superior quadrantanopia) demonstrates a lesion in the optic radiation in the temporal lobe.

Superior quadrantanopia in image 3 (pie in the sky) is seen in patients who have an injury to the optic radiations, which pass through the temporal lobe. They are also known as Meyer’s loop.

Image 1: Bilateral hemianopia occurs due to a defect in the optic tract.

Image 2: Inferior quadrantic hemianopia (pie on the floor) defect is due to the involvement of superior fibers of the optic radiations – Baum’s loop. It is seen in parietal lobe lesions.

Image 4: Right contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing occurs due to a defect in the visual cortex in the occipital lobe.

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text:
In a town, there were 1000 live births in a period of 6 months. During the same period, 12 women died due to the following causes. What is the maternal mortality ratio?

Sepsis - 3

Road traffic accidents - 2

Obstructed labor - 2

Postpartum hemorrhage - 3

Snake bite - 2
questions.solution:
This town's maternal mortality ratio (MMR) is 800 per 100,000 live births.

Maternal mortality refers to deaths during pregnancy or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, from causes related to pregnancy. Excluding the deaths from traffic accidents and snake bite, the total number of maternal deaths is 8.

MMR = (Number of maternal deaths in a given year / Number of live births in the same area and year) x 1,00,000 (or 1000).

Hence, MMR = 8 x 100000/1000 = 800 per 100,000 live births.

Related Pearl: Maternal Mortality Ratio

Maternal death is defined as the death of a woman while pregnant or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of the duration and site of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes.

The main global causes of maternal deaths are severe bleeding, indirect causes (anemia, malaria, heart diseases), infections, unsafe abortions, eclampsia, obstructed labor, and other direct causes like ectopic pregnancy, anesthesia-related complications, etc.

In India, the most common causes of maternal deaths are hemorrhage (leading cause), sepsis, obstructed labor, hypertensive disorders, etc.

questions.text: The given chest x-ray findings can be caused by all of the given conditions, except _______.
questions.solution:
The above chest x-ray is typical of pneumoperitoneum. Acute intestinal obstruction does not cause pneumoperitoneum. 

The x-ray in the question shows free air beneath both the domes of the diaphragm. Perforation of bowel viscus in any part of the gastrointestinal tract can cause pneumoperitoneum. Laparoscopy-induced and peritoneal dialysis are the iatrogenic causes and are usually managed conservatively. 

An intestinal obstruction would show multiple dilated loops on an x-ray with possible air-fluid levels. When the obstruction becomes severe and there is a perforation on chronic obstructive lesions, pneumoperitoneum may occur.

Small bowel obstruction shows -

  1. Valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) 
  2. Step-ladder or concertina effect.

Irregular haustrations are characteristic of large intestinal obstruction.

questions.text: Identify the chart given in the picture below.
questions.solution:
The chart given in the picture is the early treatment diabetic retinopathy study or ETDRS chart.

ETDRS chart presents a series of 5 letters of equal difficulty on each row, with standardized spacing between letters and rows. It consists of a total of 14 lines having 70 letters. It is also used to test visual acuity. An image of the ETDRS chart is given below.

Other options:

Option B: The Snellen chart is used to test visual acuity. Visual acuity is the eye's ability to discriminate between two points.

A picture of the Snellen chart is given below.

Option C: The Pelli-Robson contrast sensitivity letter chart consists of letters of constant size but decreasing contrast. It is viewed by the patient from a distance of 1 meter until the lowest resolvable group of three letters on the chart is reached. It is used to measure contrast sensitivity, a measure of the ability to distinguish an object against its background.

An image of the Pelli-Robson chart used in the middle east is given below.

Option D: Hess chart is used to diagnose and monitor patients with incomitant strabismus by assessing a binocular single vision field. In its interpretation, a smaller chart indicates the eye with the paretic muscle and a larger chart indicates the eye with an overacting muscle.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman has difficulty hearing for the past few months. The findings of audiometry of the affected ear are shown below. The other ear is normal. Which of the following results of tuning fork tests is consistent with the audiometric findings?
questions.solution:
The given audiogram is suggestive of left-sided mixed hearing loss. Weber lateralizing towards the right is consistent with the audiogram findings. 

Interpretation of the audiogram:

  • Blue color indicates left ear.
  • › indicates BC (bone conduction) and the threshold is >25 dB. Hence BC is abnormal → sensorineural pathway is abnormal.
  • × indicates AC (air conduction) and the threshold is >15 dB. Hence AC is abnormal → conductive pathway is abnormal
  • Both AC and BC are abnormal. It indicates a sensorineural hearing loss.
  • In addition, the air-bone gap is present which implies conductive hearing loss.
  • Hence interpreted as left mixed hearing loss.

Tuning fork tests in left-sided mixed hearing loss:

  • Rinne negative in the left ear (affected ear) and positive in the right (normal ear).
  • Weber lateralized towards the right (normal) side.

The primary component tested by Weber’s test is bone conduction by placing the tuning fork on the glabella. In pure conductive hearing loss, webers will lateralize to the affected ear. This is due to the cochlea of the affected ear being shielded from external sounds due to discontinuity in the conducting pathway.

In pure SNHL, webers will lateralize to the healthy ear due to the inability of the cochlea of the affected ear to transmit signals. In mixed hearing loss, both the conducting pathway and the cochlea are affected; the sound will lateralize to the healthy ear giving results similar to SNHL.

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

Sensorineural hearing loss Both AC and BC are abnormal and no air-Bone gap
Mixed hearing loss Both AC and BC abnormal and air-bone gap present

Early stages of Meniere's disease (lower frequencies affected first) Upsloping or ascending audiogram
Congenital hearing loss and cochlear otosclerosis (mid-frequency hearing loss) U-shaped or trough-shaped or cookie bite shaped audiogram

questions.text: A patient presents with dry nocturnal cough, dyspnea, and wheezing.  The eosinophil count is markedly increased, along with high levels of serum IgE and filarial antibodies. Following treatment with diethylcarbamazine, he developed pruritus, rash, lymphadenopathy, fever, and hypotension. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario given above is suggestive of tropical pulmonary eosinophilia, which is a manifestation of occult filariasis. Following treatment with diethylcarbamazine (DEC), a severe allergic reaction, known as the Mazzotti reaction, may occur. 

Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia presents with low-grade fever, weight loss, and pulmonary symptoms like a dry nocturnal cough, dyspnea, and wheezing. There is a rise in the eosinophil count, IgE, and filarial antibodies. Diethylcarbamazine is the drug of choice for filariasis (option D) and is given orally.

Mazzotti reaction occurs due to the release of antigens from the death of microfilariae and is not an allergic response to DEC(Option C).  It presents as pruritus, rash, lymphadenopathy, fever, and hypotension occurring after the administration drug. The Mazzotti reaction if develops is treated symptomatically with antipyretics, antihistamines, and antihypotensive agents and can be prevented by using steroids.

A Jarisch–Herxheimer reaction is a transient clinical phenomenon that occurs in patients infected with spirochetes like syphilis, leptospirosis, Lyme disease, and relapsing fever, who are treated with antibiotics. The reaction occurs within 24 hours of antibiotic therapy. It generally manifests as fever, chills, rigors, nausea and vomiting, tachycardia, hypotension, flushing, myalgia, and exacerbation of skin lesions. It is an acute, self-limiting condition.
