questions.text: A baby assessed at 5 minutes after birth had a pink body, with blue extremities and irregular gasping respiration. The heart rate was 40 beats/min, and there was a grimace, with some flexion of extremities. Which of the following statements is true regarding the score calculated from the given information?

choices.text: Infant appears to be in satisfactory condition.
Additional scores should be assigned every 5 min for up to 20 min.
It is an evidence of asphyxia or proof of an intrapartum hypoxic event.

questions.solution:
The APGAR score is a practical method of evaluating infants immediately after birth at 1 and 5 minutes. The APGAR score in this baby is 5 and additional scores should be assigned every 5 min for up to 20 min is the correct statement.

In this baby

  • Color: Blue extremities - score 1
  • HR <100 beats/min - score 1
  • Grimace - score 1
  • Some flexion of extremities - score 1
  • Irregular respiration - score 1

Thus, the total score is 5.

The most appropriate expansion of Apgar is appearance, pulse, grimace, activity, and respiration. 

  • Scores of 7 to 10 are considered reassuring (Option A).
  • Scores of 3 to 7 at 5 minutes require continued recording at 5-minute intervals up to 20 minutes.
  • Critically low scores are 3 and below and require immediate resuscitation (Option B).

Apgar scores should not be used to determine the need for resuscitation or to guide the steps of resuscitation but rather should be done at sequential time points after birth to reflect how well the infant is responding to resuscitation. Apgar score alone should not be interpreted as evidence of asphyxia or proof of an intrapartum hypoxic event (Option D).

Related Pearl: APGAR score

questions.text: A 52-year-old male patient with renal insufficiency presented with reduced urine output, pedal edema, headache, and a BP of 160/90 mmHg. Chlorthalidone was started for the patient. What is the likely mechanism of the drug used?
questions.solution:
Chlorthalidone is a thiazide-like diuretic that acts by inhibiting the Na-Cl symport situated in the apical membrane of the distal convoluted tubules of the kidney.

It is among the first choice of drugs used in the management of hypertension. They have a longer half-life than thiazide-type diuretics and result in better 24-h control of arterial blood pressure.

Other uses:

  • Edema associated with congestive heart failure, liver cirrhosis, chronic kidney disease, and nephrotic syndrome
  • Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus
  • Kidney stones caused by Ca2+ crystals

Side effects include hypokalemia, erectile dysfunction, carbohydrate intolerance, hyperuricemia, dyslipidemia, and increased risk of sudden cardiac death.

Other options:

Option A: Aliskiren is the only direct renin inhibitor and is effective in treating hypertension.

Option C: Calcium channel blockers are widely used as antihypertension. They include 3 subgroups: dihydropyridines, e.g. amlodipine phenylethylamine (verapamil) and benzothiazepine (diltiazem) are equally efficacious antihypertensives, but dihydropyridines are mainly used.

Option D: Prazosin is a selective α1 antagonist. It does not impair carbohydrate intolerance, has a favorable effect on lipid profiles, and relieves urinary symptoms in males with prostatic hypertrophy. However, it is generally not used as a first-line agent in hypertension as it can cause fluid retention.

questions.text: Choose the wrongly matched option.

choices.text: Purkinje cells - Stimulatory to the deep cerebellar nuclei
Granular cells - The only excitatory neurons in the cerebellar cortex

questions.solution:
Purkinje cells - Stimulatory to the deep cerebellar nuclei is the wrongly matched option. The Purkinje cell has flask-shaped cell bodies, and the axons of these cells are the only efferents of the cerebellar cortex. They are inhibitory to the deep cerebellar nuclei.

Option B: The Golgi cells are GABAergic inhibitory neurons that lie in the innermost granular layer.

Option C: The molecular layer is the outermost layer, and it contains stellate cells and basket cells.

Option D: The granule cells form the only excitatory neurons in the cerebellar cortex.

The layers of the cerebellum are shown in the image below.

Related Pearl: Layers of the cerebellar cortex

The cerebellar cortex is divided into 3 layers. They are:

  • Molecular layer - It is the outermost layer. It contains stellate cells and basket cells. They receive excitatory input from the parallel fibers and form inhibitory synapses on the Purkinje cells. It contains many myelinated and unmyelinated nerve fibers giving it a pale appearance in H and E staining.
  • Purkinje layer - It is the middle layer. It contain flask-shaped cell bodies of Purkinje cells. Their dendrites pass into the molecular layer. The axons of the Purkinje cells passes through the granular layer into the white matter and synapses with the cerebellar nuclei.
  • Granular layer - It is the innermost layer. It contains the cell bodies of the granule cells as well as Golgi cells. It receives excitatory input from the mossy fibers. They end on the dendrites of the granule cells and these complexes are called glomeruli. The axon from the granule cells travels to the molecular layer and bifurcates in a T-shape. These branches form the T and are called parallel fibers. These parallel fibers form excitatory synapses with the Purkinje cells. The granule cells form the only excitatory neurons in the cerebellar cortex. Golgi cells receive input from parallel fibers and mossy fibers. They send inhibitory output to the granule cells.

Neurotransmitters released:

  • Stellate, basket, Golgi and Purkinje cells- GABA
  • Granule cells - Glutamate

The only output from the cerebellar cortex is inhibitory from the Purkinje cells to the deep cerebellar nuclei.

questions.text: A patient presented with severe chest pain. He has a history of fever, fatigue, shortness of breath, and palpitations. ECG showed no changes. On auscultation, no abnormality was detected. An endomyocardial biopsy was performed, and Dallas criteria were used to establish the diagnosis. Which of the following biopsy slides corresponds to this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This clinical picture appears to mimic MI, but the patient has a history of fever and no abnormal findings on auscultation and ECG. Also, Dallas criteria were used to establish the diagnosis. The clinical scenario is therefore suggestive of myocarditis, and Image A shows the histologic findings of myocarditis.

Myocarditis is characterized by an interstitial inflammatory infiltrate associated with focal myocyte necrosis.

Viruses are the most common causes among infectious causes of myocarditis. Endomyocardial biopsy is the gold standard for the diagnosis and it shows diffuse, mononuclear, lymphocytic infiltration as shown above. 

The Dallas criteria are used for the diagnosis of myocarditis on the basis of the findings of endomyocardial biopsy. 

They are treated with supportive management. 

Other Options:

Option A: Picture B shows irreversibly injured myocytes with contraction bands—intensely eosinophilic intracellular “stripes” composed of closely packed sarcomeres; these bands are suggestive of reperfusion injury after MI. The image is given below.

Option B: Picture D shows massive myocyte hypertrophy and myofiber disarray (haphazard disarray of bundles of myocytes and contractile elements in sarcomeres within cells), which are characteristic of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. The image is given below.

Option C: Picture C shows hyaline eosinophilic deposits in the heart suggestive of amyloidosis, which can be confirmed by Congo red staining. The image is given below.

Match the following cytokines with their functions:
1. IL- 4   A. Hematopoiesis
2. INF- β  B. Activation of macrophages
3. IL- 12    

C. Stimulation of IgE production
4. IL- 3   D. Antiviral activity
questions.solution:
The correct match of cytokines and their functions is as follows:

1. IL- 4   C. Stimulation of IgE production
2. INF- β  D. Antiviral activity
3. IL- 12    

B. Activation of macrophages
4. IL- 3   A. Hematopoiesis

 

Cytokines are soluble proteins. In response to various stimuli, they are produced by hematopoietic and nonhematopoietic cells. Cytokines are of 6 types. They are interferons, interleukins, tumor necrosis factor, transforming growth factor, colony-stimulating factor, and growth factor

Interleukin 4 - They act on resting B cells and play an important role in B cell differentiation, production of IgE, and stimulating mast cells. They are significant in allergies.

(INF) Interferon-β is produced by fibroblasts is a potent antiviral cytokine 

Interleukin 12 - These cytokines activate macrophages which in turn provide protection against intracellular microbes. They play an important role in chronic autoimmune inflammatory diseases.

Interleukin 3 - It is a growth factor for bone marrow stem cells. It stimulates hematopoiesis and is therefore known also as the multi-colony-stimulating factor (multi-CSF).

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with rashes in palms and soles?
questions.solution:
The rash of Rickettsia prowazekii causing epidemic typhus does not involve palms and soles.

R. prowazekii is transmitted by feces of human body louse. It starts as fever, chills, and a characteristic rash appearing on the fourth- fifth day, starting on the trunk and spreading over the limbs but sparing the face, palms, and soles.

Rocky mountain spotted fever (RMSF) caused by Rickettsia rickettsii transmitted through the bite of dermacentor tick (hard tick). Patients present with fever, headache, myalgia, and centripetally distributed rashes over palms and soles. 

The drug of choice for both the above rickettsial infection is doxycycline. 

Other options: 

Option A: Coxsackie virus causes hand-foot-and-mouth disease, which is characterized by oral and pharyngeal ulcerations and a vesicular rash of the palms and soles that may spread to the arms and legs.

Option C: Treponema pallidum causes syphilis. It is a sexually transmitted disease. The primary lesions are painless ulcers with a clean and hard base found intrarectal, perianal, or oral. The secondary stage is characterized by red maculopapular rash that can be found anywhere on the body, including the hands and feet, and moist, pale papules (condylomas) in the anogenital region, axillae, and mouth. In the tertiary stage, granulomatous lesions (gummas) are seen in the skin, bones, and liver, along with the involvement of CNS and CVS.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man is diagnosed with diabetes mellitus type 2. He says that he does not prefer injections. He had 1 episode of pancreatitis 3 years back and has a history of colon cancer in his family. He also has been diagnosed with heart failure and has been taking medications. Which of the following drugs can be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
Glimepiride can be given to this patient. It belongs to the class called sulfonylureas.

Sulfonylureas act by closing the ATP-sensitive K channels in the beta-cells of the pancreas. This closure causes cell membrane depolarization and the release of insulin. They are readily absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract and therefore can be given orally. Important sulfonylureas are glimepiride, glipizide, glyburide, etc.

Important adverse effects are hypoglycemia, vomiting, cholestatic jaundice, agranulocytosis, and aplastic and hemolytic anemias. They can also cause a disulfiram-like reaction. They should be used with caution in pregnancy, lactation, and significant hepatic or renal insufficiency (for the older forms).

Other options

Option A- Pioglitazone belongs to a class of thiazolidinediones. It activates the peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor γ (PPARγ) and increases insulin sensitivity. Apart from weight gain, it also causes edema and fluid retention. It increases the plasma volume and is therefore unsuitable for heart failure patients.

Option B- Exenatide is a glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) receptor agonist. It stimulates insulin secretion, inhibits glucagon release, delays gastric emptying, reduces food intake, and normalizes fasting and postprandial insulin secretion. It is given subcutaneously. It can also cause pancreatitis, and therefore is not used in patients with a history or risk of developing pancreatitis.

Option D- Teduglutide is a glucagon-like peptide-2 (GLP-2) analog. It enhances the growth of intestinal mucosa. It is used in the treatment of short bowel syndrome and not diabetes mellitus. It is administered parenterally and discontinued in patients with active gastrointestinal malignancy.

questions.text: A student was asked to record ECG by using bipolar limb leads. The below image shows the arrangement of the bipolar electrodes and the potentials recorded across lead I and lead II. What is the potential recorded across lead III?
questions.solution:
According to Einthoven’s law, the potential recorded across lead III is +0.7 mV.

Einthoven’s Law: Einthoven’s law states that if the ECGs are recorded simultaneously with the three limb leads, the sum of the potentials recorded in leads I and III will equal the potential in lead II.

Lead I potential + Lead III potential = Lead II potential

Lead III = Lead II – Lead I = (1.2-0.5) = +0.7 mV.

Note: Einthoven's triangle is an imaginary triangle drawn around the area of the heart. It is formed by the arrangement of three bipolar limb leads (the two arms and left leg).

questions.text: A 1-year-old male child is brought with abdominal distension, recurrent pain, nausea, and vomiting. The vomitus was bilious, and the child had stiffened and pulled his legs up to the abdomen. Past history is insignificant. An ultrasound revealed the finding shown in the image. What could be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of abdominal distention, recurrent abdominal pain, bilious vomiting, and the USG showing the doughnut sign (target sign) and pseudokidney sign are all suggestive of an intussusception.

Intussusception occurs when a portion of the alimentary tract is telescoped into an adjacent segment. The most common location of intussusception is ileocecal. 

The majority of cases of intussusception in children are idiopathic in nature. It can be seen in infants during the weaning period following the introduction of new food, vaccination, or upper respiratory tract infection. The currently approved rotavirus vaccines are associated with a slightly increased risk of intussusception.

Clinical features include sudden, cramping abdominal pain associated with “currant jelly” stools and a palpable mass on physical examination. During the cramping episodes, the child may stiffen and pull the legs up to the abdomen. Between attacks, the child may appear comfortable. Normal bowel movements will stop as the obstruction progresses and become associated with bilious emesis and increasing abdominal distention. 

USG findings in intussusception include:

  • Target sign (also known as the doughnut sign)- The appearance is generated by concentric alternating echogenic and hypoechogenic bands. The echogenic bands are formed by mucosa and muscularis whereas the submucosa is responsible for the hypoechoic bands.
  • Pseudokidney sign is seen in the longitudinal section of the bowel. The edematous bowel resembles renal parenchyma.

Treatment is mainly by hydrostatic reduction of intussusception by enema. It should be done immediately after the diagnosis.

Other options:

Option A: Acute gastroenteritis in children manifests as vomiting and/or diarrhoea, fever, abdominal pain, and anorexia. The most common cause of gastroenteritis in children is a viral infection, with the etiologic agents being rotaviruses, noroviruses, enteric adenoviruses, caliciviruses, astroviruses, and enteroviruses.

Option B: Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis presents with non-bilious vomiting that is projectile in nature and usually affects male infants between 2 and 8 weeks of age and is rarely seen after 13 weeks. An olive-shaped mass is palpable in the right upper quadrant. A test feed shows visible gastric peristalsis.

Option D: Hirschsprung's disease usually presents in the neonatal period with symptoms of delayed passage of meconium, abdominal distension, and bilious vomiting; later, in adult life, it usually manifests as severe chronic constipation. It is characterized by the congenital absence of intramural ganglion cells in the distal large bowel.

questions.text: On examination of cranial nerve reflexes, a patient is found to have a loss of light reflex, accommodation reflex, and gag reflex. Damage to the structures passing through which foramen can be ruled out?
questions.solution:
Damage to the hypoglossal nerve passing through the hypoglossal canal can be ruled out.

The afferent nerve for the gag reflex is the glossopharyngeal nerve, while the efferent nerve consists of both the glossopharyngeal (to the stylopharyngeus muscle) and vagus. Both these nerves pass through the jugular foramen and damage to them may be the cause for loss of gag reflex.

For both the light and accommodation reflex, the afferents run through the optic nerve and efferents run through the oculomotor nerve. The optic nerve passes through the optic canal and the oculomotor nerve passes through the superior orbital fissure. Hence damage to either of these may be responsible for the loss of light and accommodation reflex.

The hypoglossal nerve passing through the hypoglossal canal supplies the intrinsic muscles of the tongue and palsy of this leads to deviation of the tongue towards the paralyzed side.

Which of the following epithelia are correctly matched with their site?
Option Epithelium Site
A Transitional epithelium Prostatic urethra
B Stratified squamous epithelium Membranous urethra
C

Pseudostratified columnar epithelium with stereocilia

 Epididymis
D Ciliated columnar epithelium Fallopian tube
questions.solution:
Options A, C, and D are correctly matched.

Pseudostratified columnar epithelium lines the membranous urethra.

The following are various parts of the urethra in males and their lining epithelium:

  • Pre-prostatic & Prostatic urethra - Transitional epithelium
  • Membranous urethra - Pseudostratified columnar epithelium
  • Penile/ Spongy urethra - proximally, Pseudostratified columnar; distally, stratified squamous.

The epididymis contains pseudostratified columnar epithelium with stereocilia which help to increase the surface area for absorption.

The ciliated columnar epithelium is found in most of the respiratory tract, the uterus, and the uterine tube (oviduct), efferent ductules of the testis, parts of the middle ear and auditory tube; the ependyma lining the central canal of the spinal cord and the ventricles of the brain.

questions.text: Which of the following pairs of the condition and the type of joint involved is wrongly matched?

choices.text: Bouchard nodes, Heberden nodes - Hinge joint
Hill-Sachs lesion with bony Bankart lesion - Ball and socket joint
Unhappy triad of O Donoghue - Condylar joint

questions.solution:
Podagra - Saddle joint is the wrongly matched option.

Podagra refers to gout involving the first metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joint, which is commonly known as the big toe joint. Gout in this joint causes swelling, redness, heat, and tenderness. The MTP joint is an ellipsoid synovial joint, not a saddle joint. Saddle joints, like the carpometacarpal joint of the thumb, allow for more complex movements but are not involved in podagra.

Option A: Bouchard nodes of the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints and Heberden nodes of the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints are manifestations of osteoarthritis. PIP and DIP are both uniaxial hinge joints.

Option B: Hill-Sachs lesion with bony Bankart lesion is seen in recurrent anterior dislocation of the shoulder. The shoulder joint is a ball and socket synovial joint. Detachment of the labrum and capsule from the anterior rim of the glenoid is called a Bankart lesion, while an indentation on the posterolateral aspect of the humeral head due to the humeral head being forced against the anterior glenoid rim is called the Hill–Sachs lesion

Option D: Unhappy triad of O Donoghue of the knee refers to an injury of the medial meniscus, medial collateral ligament, and anterior cruciate ligament. The knee is a condylar synovial joint.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl presented with high-grade fever, and recurrent infections of her mouth and skin. Oral examination shows significant gingivitis and periodontitis. Postnatal history is significant for delayed umbilical cord separation. Identify the likely etiology of the patient's condition.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of the diagnosis as leukocyte adhesion defect 1 (LAD-1) and the etiology is defective CD11/CD18 integrin.

The clinical scenario of high-grade fever and recurrent skin and upper respiratory tract infections with a history of delayed umbilical cord separation in a child is suggestive of leukocyte adhesion defects. Gingivitis and periodontitis are hallmarks of LAD-1. 

Leukocyte Adhesion Defects are autosomal recessive disorders of innate immunity characterized by recurrent infections in the presence of neutrophilic leukocytosis. LAD-1 is caused due to defective leukocyte adhesion because of mutations in the beta chain of CD11/CD18 integrins. As a result, neutrophils cannot adhere to intracellular adhesion molecules ICAM-1 and ICAM-2 expressed on endothelium and transmigrate through the vessel wall. The few neutrophils that do transmigrate fail to recognize microorganisms opsonized by complement iC3b. This results in defective phagocytosis and recurrent infections. 

Clinical features of LAD-1: 

  • Recurrent infections of the skin, upper respiratory tract, lower intestinal tract, and genital mucosa.
  • History of delayed umbilical cord separation.
  • Gingivitis and periodontitis are hallmarks of LAD-1. 
  • Classical signs of inflammation are absent.
  • Lab work shows significant neutrophilic leukocytosis >25000/mm3.

Allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation is the treatment of choice in LAD-1.

Other options:

Option A - Defective LYST protein causes Chédiak-Higashi syndrome. It is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. It is characterized by progressive neutropenia, neutrophil granules, occult-cutaneous albinism, rotary nystagmus, recurrent infections, peripheral neuropathy with ataxia, and prolonged bleeding time. High-dose ascorbic acid can be given in a stable state and allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation is indicated in the accelerated phase.

Option B - Defective Sialyl-Lewis X receptor causes LAD-2. Neutrophils rolling and tethering are affected. Clinical features are similar to LAD-1 but neurological defects, craniofacial dysmorphism, and the Bombay blood group are unique to LAD-2. Patients with LAD-2 respond to fucose supplementation.

Option C - Defective Kindlin 3 causes LAD-3. Chemotaxis, adhesion, and superoxide formation are affected. It is characterized by Glanzmann thrombasthenia-like bleeding disorder with other clinical features similar to LAD-1. Management is similar to LAD-1.

questions.text: The neonate of a rural woman has the condition shown in the image below. The neonate was healthy for the first 2-3 days after birth, following which he developed progressive difficulty in taking feeds. She had a normal delivery at home but had not received any antenatal care. The possible cause is _________.

choices.text: Inhibition of presynaptic release of inhibitory neurotransmitter
Inhibition of post-synaptic release of inhibitory neurotransmitter
Inhibition of presynaptic release of excitatory neurotransmitter
Inhibition of post-synaptic release of excitatory neurotransmitter

questions.solution:
The cause of tetany is the inhibition of presynaptic release of inhibitory neurotransmitter.

The given image shows a neonate with opisthotonus, and progressive difficulty in taking feeds indicates lockjaw. The history indicates that the mother was not vaccinated during pregnancy. All these features are suggestive of neonatal tetanus.

Clostridium tetani produces an exotoxin tetanospasmin. It is a plasmid-coded, heat-labile toxin, which enters the motor nerve endings of glycinergic interneurons and γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA) secreting neurons. The toxin peptide degrades synaptobrevin, a protein required for the attachment of neurotransmitter vesicles on the presynaptic membrane before its release. The motor neurons are not inhibited as the release of the inhibitory neurotransmitters glycine and GABA is blocked. This causes hyperreflexia, muscle spasms, and spastic paralysis result.

Blockade of action of neurotransmitters at post-synaptic terminal is a mechanism of strychnine poisoning presenting similar to tetany.

Inhibition of presynaptic release of excitatory neurotransmitters (acetylcholine) is seen in Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following modes of activation is most commonly found in RAS proto-oncogenes?
questions.solution:
Point mutations of the RAS gene family constitute the most common type of abnormality involving proto-oncogenes in human tumors.

RAS proto-oncogene:

  • The 3 RAS genes in humans (HRAS, KRAS, and NRAS) are the most common oncogenes in human cancer.
  • RAS oncogenes code for a family of proteins called GTP-binding (G) proteins, which are involved in transmitting signals within cells (cellular signal transduction).
  • When RAS is 'switched on' by incoming signals, it subsequently switches on other proteins, which ultimately turn on genes involved in cell growth, differentiation, and survival.
  • Mutations in RAS genes can lead to the production of permanently activated RAS proteins. As a result, this can cause unintended and overactive signaling inside the cell, even in the absence of incoming signals. Because these signals result in cell growth and division, overactive RAS signaling can ultimately lead to cancer.

questions.text: During fetal development, the ascent of the horseshoe kidney from the pelvis is prevented as it gets trapped under an artery. Which of the following regions are supplied by this artery?

choices.text: From the esophagus to the duodenum (till ampulla of Vater)
Duodenum (from ampulla of Vater) to proximal 1/3rd of the transverse colon
Distal 2/3rd of the transverse colon to sigmoid colon
Distal 1/3rd of the transverse colon to anal canal above the pectinate line

questions.solution:
The inferior mesenteric artery prevents the ascent of the horseshoe kidney and provides blood supply to the hindgut. The hindgut extends from the distal 1/3rd of the transverse colon to the anal canal above the pectinate line.

The horseshoe kidney is usually found at the level of the lower lumbar vertebrae. Its ascent is halted by the root of the inferior mesenteric artery. The connecting isthmus of the horseshoe kidney may be present either in front or behind the aorta and the inferior vena cava.

questions.text: An elderly male patient presented with painless, gross hematuria. He was evaluated for the same, and a cystoprostatectomy was done. The gross specimen image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image of the cystoprostatectomy specimen shows a large, fungating growth from the bladder wall involving the entire bladder with the two lobes of the prostate not being much affected. The most likely diagnosis is bladder carcinoma. 

Painless, gross hematuria is the most common symptom that is indicative of a bladder carcinoma until proven otherwise. Subsequent clots and urinary retention can occur. Increased frequency and discomfort during urination may be seen. It can lead to pelvic pain due to extravesical spread, loin pain due to hydronephrosis, and suprapubic pain if the nerve is involved.

Depending upon the depth of invasion, bladder carcinoma is divided into 3 groups:

  • Flat, non-invasive carcinoma in situ (CIS)
  • Non-muscle invasive bladder cancer - does not invade detrusor muscle but can invade lamina propria. It accounts for 70% of cases.
  • Muscle-invasive bladder cancer - invades the detrusor muscle.

Diagnosis and staging are done by cystoscopy and resection of the tumor. A bimanual examination should be performed after the resection of the tumor. Complete urinary tract imaging is required using contrast computed tomography (CT) or magnetic resonance (MR) urography.

Management:

  • Non-muscle invasive bladder cancer - Endoscopic resection and intravesical instillations of mitomycin C/ epirubicin, immunotherapy with regular intravesical instillations of Bacille Calmette-Guerin (BCG)
  • Muscle invasive bladder cancer - Radical cystectomy along with urinary diversion procedure and lymph node dissection +/- neoadjuvant chemotherapy

Other options: 

Option A- Leukoplakia is squamous metaplasia of the bladder characterized by white particles (keratin) in the urine. Diffuse leukoplakia of the bladder is pre-malignant and can lead to squamous cancer of the bladder. It has to be assessed by cystoscopy and localized areas may be resected.

Option C- Prostate carcinoma presents with symptoms only during advanced disease. It causes bladder outlet obstruction, pelvic pain, hematuria, and renal failure. It is surgically managed by radical prostatectomy, which only involves the removal of the prostate and seminal vesicles and preserving the bladder. Unlike the given gross specimen one or more lobes are predominantly involved in prostatic carcinoma.

Option D- Schistosomiasis of the bladder is a parasitic infection by Schistosoma haematobium. Cystoscopy would show nodules, pseudotubercles, ulceration, or sandy patches. Chronic infection can lead to squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder.

questions.text: Which of the following rectal prolapse procedures is performed through the abdominal approach?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, Repstein operation is the abdominal approach for rectal prolapse.

It is managed by using the Perineal approach or the abdominal approach. The perineal approach is easy to perform and has fewer complications but a high recurrence rate. The surgeries done using this approach for rectal prolapse are the following:

  • Thiersch's wiring
  • Delorme's mucosectomy
  • Altemeier's procedure or perineal recto sigmoidectomy

The abdominal approach is difficult to perform and has more complications but a lower recurrence rate. The surgeries done using this approach are the following: 

  • Moschcowitz repair
  • Ripstein and Wells rectopexy; ventral rectopexy or suture rectopexy
  • Resection rectopexy

If the patient is fit enough for an abdominal procedure, it is preferred over the perineal procedure, since the risk of recurrence is lower. The perineal approach is preferred in elderly patients with comorbidities and in young men since the abdominal approach may injure the pelvic autonomic nerves which may result in sexual dysfunction.

questions.text: A child with acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL) undergoes prophylactic irradiation prior to autologous hemopoietic stem cell transplantation. Which of the following will be the least affected by acute radiation syndrome?
questions.solution:
Neurons are the least affected cells due to acute radiation syndrome.

The correct order of acute radiation syndromes from lowest to highest radiation exposure is hematopoietic < gastrointestinal < cardiovascular/CNS.

Syndrome    Radiation dose
Hematopoietic
(Bone marrow) 		 >0.7 Gy (>70 rads)

(mild symptoms may occur as low as 0.3 Gy or 30 rads) 
Gastrointestinal
(GI)		 >10 Gy (>1000 rads)

(some symptoms may occur as low as 6 Gy or 600 rads)
Cardiovascular (CV)
/Central Nervous System (CNS)		 >50 Gy (5000 rads)

(some symptoms may occur as low as 20 Gy or 2000 rads)

 

Stages of Acute Radiation Syndrome (ARS):

The prodromal phase manifests with non-specific symptoms like nausea, vomiting, and anorexia. Early and persistent symptoms predict severity.

Latent phase: The patient looks and feels generally healthy for a few hours or even up to a few weeks. In severe cases, this phase may be absent.

Manifest illness phase: Symptoms are seen as per the radiation dose. Tissues with greater rates of cellular division are most radiosensitive, and hence the hematopoietic and gastrointestinal systems are the most affected.

Recovery phase or Death: The recovery phase will be seen after the manifest stage when the patient recovers from the acute exposure. The time taken for recovery will depend on the severity of the injury and the organ system affected.

questions.text: The bodies shown in the below image are seen in ______.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Lewy body. Lewy bodies may be found in the remaining neurons present in the substantia nigra in cases of Parkinson’s disease.

These are single or multiple, cytoplasmic, eosinophilic, round to elongated inclusions. They have a dense core, surrounded by a pale halo. On ultrastructural examination, Lewy bodies consist of fine filaments, composed of α-synuclein and other proteins, including neurofilaments and ubiquitin. The other major histologic finding is the presence of Lewy neurites that also contain aggregated α-synuclein.

The microscopic feature of Parkinson's disease is pallor of the substantia nigra and locus ceruleus. This occurs due to the loss of pigmented, catecholaminergic neurons in these regions associated with gliosis.

Other options

Option A- Pick's disease is a type of front temporal lobar degeneration. The surviving neurons show a characteristic swelling (Pick cells), and others contain Pick bodies, cytoplasmic, round to oval, filamentous inclusions that stain strongly with silver methods. 

The below image shows Pick bodies (marked with asterisks).

Option C- Microscopy of Huntington's disease shows loss of striatal neurons in the caudate nucleus, especially in the tail and in portions nearer the ventricle.

Option D- Important microscopic features of Alzheimer's disease are neuritic plaques and neurofibrillary tangles. Neuritic plaques are focal collections of dilated, tortuous axons and dendritic processes. They are present around an amyloid core. Neurofibrillary tangles are tau-containing bundles of filaments in the cytoplasm of the neurons. They can be elongated, flame-shaped, or may be rounded. (globose tangles)

The below image on the right top shows neuritic plaques and on the left bottom shows the presence of neurofibrillary tangles.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old medical student diagnosed with dengue developed epistaxis that resolved spontaneously. He has been afebrile for the last 24 hours, and his platelet count is 14,000/μL. His BP is 110/70 mmHg and there is a 28% rise in hematocrit. What should be the management?
  1. Give 4 units of platelets
  2. Give plenty of oral fluids
  3. Give IV fluids
  4. Keep under observation
  5. Discharge the patient
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture of a student diagnosed with dengue with history of an afebrile period, epistaxis, reduced platelet count and elevated hematocrit strongly suggests dengue hemorrhagic fever.

He should be kept under observation and given adequate oral and intravenous fluids (Statements 2,3 and 4).  

Clinical criterion for dengue hemorrhagic fever is:

  • Acute onset fever lasting 2-7 days.
  • Hemorrhagic manifestations: positive tourniquet test, petechiae, ecchymoses, purpura, or bleeding from the mucosa, gastrointestinal tract, injection sites, or other locations.
  • Platelet count ≤ 100,000 cells/mm.
  • Objective evidence of plasma leakage: rising hematocrit/ haemoconcentration of ≥20% from baseline or signs of plasma leakage (e.g., pleural effusion, ascites, hypoproteinemia/ albuminemia).

Severe dengue symptoms often come after the fever has subsided, when the capillary permeability may increase along with rising hematocrit levels. Progressive leukopenia, followed by a rapid decrease in platelet count, often precedes plasma leakage.

The main pathology in dengue is plasma leakage, resulting in intravascular volume depletion and thereby shock. So, supportive management with oral or intravenous rehydration is the mainstay of treatment. If the patient is febrile, paracetamol is administered to maintain body temperature. NSAIDs should be avoided since they can cause gastritis, platelet dysfunction, and severe bleeding.

Patients should be kept under observation and vital parameters like blood pressure, urine output, platelet count, and rise or fall in hematocrit should be monitored.

Indications for platelet transfusion in dengue:

 

  • Platelet count < 10,000/cu.mm.
  • Prolonged shock with coagulopathy and abnormal coagulogram
  • Systemic massive bleeding

questions.text: A newborn with the given deformity is referred to you. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: The infant must always be examined for associated disorders such as congenital hip dislocation and spina bifida.
Relapse is uncommon in children managed with casts until the age of 1 year.
The order of correction according to Ponseti method is cavus-adduction-varus-equinus.
Foot abduction brace can be used to prevent relapse in these children.

questions.solution:
The given image shows congenital talipes equinovarus (CTEV) or clubfoot and option B is the false statement. As relapse is common, continued bracing is required for the first 4 years of life to minimize this risk.

CTEV is a congenital malformation of the foot. It is predominately seen in male children. The components of deformity are as follows:

  • Cavus: This deformity occurs due to exaggerated arching of the foot at the mid-tarsal joint.
  • Adduction: This deformity occurs at the talonavicular joint.
  • Inversion: This deformity occurs at the subtalar joint. The calcaneum is inverted and along with it, the whole foot is inverted. This leads to a medially facing sole. 
  • Equinus: This deformity occurs at the ankle joint and tarsal joints.

Ponseti method is a successful method of manipulation in CTEV. It should begin as early as the first 2 weeks after birth. Weekly manipulation of the foot is done with the help of plaster casts. 

To begin with, the first metatarsal is elevated to correct the cavus. This creates a flat longitudinal medial border of the foot. Then, the forefoot is abducted in the plane of the metatarsals. This everts the hindfoot and corrects the forefoot out of supination. Finally, equinus is corrected by dorsiflexing the foot at the ankle joint. In most cases, a percutaneous Achilles tenotomy is required later for complete correction of the equinus.

Following the complete correction of the club foot by serial casting, the deformity must be held using a foot abduction brace (FAB) to prevent relapse. For the first 3 months, it is used full-time (23 hours per day) and then at sleep time for 4 years.

The infant must always be examined for associated disorders such as congenital hip dislocation and spina bifida, as there is an association between these conditions.

Related Pearl: Age wise management of CTEV

Initial treatment starts with Ponseti's POP cast as early as possible, but within 1 year of age.

If deformity gets corrected:

  • Dennis Brown splint is used till 1 year of age
  • After 1 year upto 5 years CTEV shoes are used in day, and Dennis Brown splint is used at night

If deformity is not corrected or untreated previously:

  • 1-3 years: Posteromedial soft tissue release (PMSTR) 
  • 3-5 years: Dillwyn Evans procedure
  • 5-8 years: Dwyer osteotomy
  • 8-10 years: Wedge tarsectomy
  • >10 years: Triple arthrodesis, external fixators

questions.text:
A 52-year-old woman presented with progressive dyspnea at rest. Chest x-ray showed significant left-sided pleural effusion. The results of the thoracocentesis and blood tests are shown in the table given below. Which of the following is not a cause of pleural effusion in this case?
Parameter Serum Pleural fluid
Protein 6 g/dL 2.4 g/dL
LDH 150 U/L 120 U/L
pH - 7.1
questions.solution:
Pulmonary embolism cannot be the cause of the above clinical picture.

Pleural fluid analysis and the ratio of pleural fluid lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) to serum LDH (120:150 = 0.8) shows that the fluid is an exudate.

For fluid to be considered an exudate, the fluid needs to meet only 1 of the Light criteria:

  • Ratio of pleural fluid protein to serum protein >0.5 or
  • Ratio of pleural fluid LDH to serum LDH >0.6; or
  • Pleural fluid LDH greater than two-thirds of the upper limit of the reference range for serum LDH).

From the results given in the above table, the protein ratio is less than 0.5, but the LDH ratio is greater than 0.6. Hence, the pleural fluid is an exudate.

The low pH suggests a certain diagnosis. When thoracentesis fluid pH is less than 7.3 (pleural fluid acidosis), diagnostic possibilities include empyema, esophageal rupture, rheumatoid arthritis, trauma, tuberculosis, and malignancy.

Also, if the diagnosis was of pulmonary embolism, a history of sudden onset dyspnea would have been mentioned.

questions.text: An elderly female patient presents to the hospital with complaints of increased tiredness and breathlessness. She is unable to do her day-to-day work. On examination, her conjunctiva appears pale. Laboratory investigations reveal a hemoglobin value of 7 g/dL. Which of the following curves represents the oxygen dissociation curve in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, the patient has hemoglobin of 7g/dL. The curve that represents the oxygen dissociation curve in this patient is curve D.

In anemic hypoxia, the blood oxygen content is decreased. This is denoted by curve D. The patients might not experience any difficulty during rest because 2,3-DPG increases in the red blood cells. However, they may have difficulty during exercise because of a limited ability to increase O2 delivery to the active tissues. 

Conditions that cause a right shift in the oxygen hemoglobin curve are: (Conditions with the increased requirement of O2 - metabolically active tissues)

  • Hypoxia
  • Hypercarbia
  • Decreased pH
  • Increased temperature
  • Increased 2,3-biphosphoglycerate

Conditions that cause a left shift in the oxygen hemoglobin curve 

  • Increased oxygen
  • Decreased carbon dioxide
  • Increased pH
  • Decreased temperature
  • Decreased 2,3-biphosphoglycerate
  • Fetal hemoglobin

Curve B represents the normal oxygen hemoglobin curve

Curve C represents oxygen with hemoglobin with 50% carboxyhemoglobin. CO is toxic because it reacts with hemoglobin to form carbonmonoxyhemoglobin (carboxyhemoglobin, COHb), and COHb does not take up O2. The affinity of hemoglobin for CO is 210 times its affinity for O2. Therefore, the hemoglobin bound to oxygen is decreased, and the oxygen dissociation curve of the remaining HbO2 shifts to the left.

questions.text: A clinical trial is conducted on 750 patients at multiple centers to confirm the efficacy of the new drug. Half the patients were given the new drug, and the remaining were given a placebo. Both the patients and researchers were blinded. What is the phase of the clinical trial?
questions.solution:
The given scenario indicates phase 3 of the clinical trial.

Clinical trials of drugs are designed to acquire information about the pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic properties of a candidate drug in humans. The FDA-regulated clinical trials typically are conducted in four phases.

Phase 1 (first in humans) is carried out with 10-100 participants. It aims to test the safety and tolerability of the drug. Usually, healthy volunteers are chosen. Sometimes patients with advanced or rare diseases are also considered. It generally lasts for 1-2 years. (Option D)

Phase 2 (first in patients) checks the efficacy and dose-ranging of the drug. 50-500 patient subjects receive the experimental drug. It lasts for 2-3 years. (Option C)

Phase 3 (multisite trial) is carried out for confirmation of the efficacy tested in phase 2. The indications are finalized and guidelines for therapeutic use are formulated. A few hundred to a few thousand patient subjects receive the drug. It lasts for around 3-5 years.

Phase 4 (postmarketing surveillance) tests for adverse effects, or those that occur only after long-term use and drug interactions. It is done in patients already on treatment with the approved drug. There is no fixed duration for this stage. (Option B)

questions.text: A patient who is undergoing treatment for a malignancy, develops generalized edema of the body. Urinary examination reveals grade 3 proteinuria and the presence of hyaline and fatty casts. She has no history of hematuria. The renal biopsy shows no immune deposits. What neoplasm is the patient likely to have?
questions.solution:
The clinical findings, proteinuria, and the absence of immune deposits on biopsy in this patient are strongly suggestive of nephrotic syndrome due to minimal change disease (MCD). There is an increased incidence of MCD in patients suffering from Hodgkin lymphoma.

Minimal change disease is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children (peaks between 2–6 years). They account for only 10–15% of nephrotic syndrome in adults.

Minimal change disease in adults is usually associated with Hodgkin's lymphoma and less frequently other lymphomas and leukemias. 

Causes:

  • It is mostly idiopathic.
  • Associated with Hodgkin lymphoma (due to the increased production of cytokines)
  • Associated with atopic disorders such as eczema and rhinitis.
  • It is clinically associated with respiratory infections and prophylactic immunizations

They present mostly with proteinuria. 

Biopsy findings include the following: 

  • Light microscopy: Glomeruli appear normal as shown in the image below (hence called "minimal change")
  • Immunofluorescence studies: No Ig or complement deposits
  • Electron microscopy: Diffuse effacement of foot processes of visceral epithelial cells (podocytopathy)

 

The illustration given below shows the effacement of foot processes of podocytes as seen in MCD.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true about Na+ imbalance?

Statement A: Rapid correction of hyponatremia leads to central pontine myelinolysis.

Statement B: Rapid correction of hypernatremia can be done safely.

Statement C: Sodium deficit is calculated as (target sodium concentration-sodium before correction) x 0.6 x Body weight in kg.

Statement D: Hypernatremia is seen in SIADH.
questions.solution:
Statements A and C are true about Na+ imbalance.

Statement A: Rapid correction of hyponatremia at a rate of more than 8–10 mM in 24 hours or 18 mM in 48 hours causes hypertonic stress, leading to apoptosis and cell death. It causes central pontine myelinolysis (CPM) which presents as quadriplegia, mutism, and rigidity after treatment and can present a few days after the initial correction.

Prevention of CPM depends on therapeutic guidelines employed for the restoration of severe hyponatremia; the guidelines should aim for gradual correction, i.e. at a rate of ≤10 mmol/L (10 mEq/L) within 24 hours and ≤20 mmol/L (20 mEq/L) within 48 hours.

Statement C: The formula for calculating sodium deficit is as follows.

(target sodium concentration-sodium before correction) x 0.6 x Body weight in kg.

Statement B: Rapid correction of hypernatremia can be done safely is a false statement. Hypernatremia must be corrected slowly by replacing the calculated free water deficit over 48 h, in order to avoid cerebral edema. The plasma Na+ concentration should be corrected by no more than 10 mM per day.

Statement D: Hypernatremia is seen in SIADH is a false statement. SIADH is characterized by impaired water excretion leading to hyponatremia with euvolemia or hypervolemia. 

The image shows the MRI finding of central pontine myelinolysis with axial fat saturated T2-weighted MRI showing hyperintense signal in the central pons.

It is an objective test that records electrical activity occurring in the auditory pathway.

  • Wave II –proximal part of the cochlear nerve

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presented with increased fatiguability and shortness of breath.  He would feel tired after exercise or activity and would feel better after rest or on waking up in the morning.  Investigations reveal the presence of anti-acetylcholine receptor antibodies. Which of the following pulmonary flow-volume loops would most likely correspond to the disease he is suffering from?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient with antibodies against acetylcholine receptors is myasthenia gravis. His pulmonary function test is likely to show a restrictive pattern corresponding to curve D.   

Myasthenia gravis presents with ventilatory restriction due to reduced respiratory muscle strength and shows a restrictive pattern on the flow-volume curve. It is characterized by decreased total lung capacity and vital capacity. Hence, the loop shrinks or narrows and shifts toward the right, as seen in Curve D in comparison to Curve A, which represents the normal flow-volume curve.

Curve B represents an obstructive pattern of the flow-volume curve in which the expiratory limb is concave upward. This is also called a scooped-out or coved pattern and is observed in conditions responsible for airflow obstruction, like asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. 

Tracheal stenosis shows a fixed upper airway obstruction pattern on the flow-volume curve, as seen in curve C. In this condition, there is obstruction and limitation of airflow during both inspiration and expiration. This leads to the flattening of both inspiratory and expiratory limbs of the flow-volume loop.

questions.text: At a health camp, you notice a child with a fever and rash. On history taking, you find that her friend had similar symptoms 1 week back. How will you epidemiologically categorize the friend of the child you examined?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the friend of the child is categorized as the primary case. It is the first case of a communicable disease introduced into a population unit. 

An index case is the first case that comes to the notice of an investigator or physician.

A secondary case is one that develops after contact with the primary case. 

A suspect case refers to a patient with all the disease's features but has not been diagnosed with it yet.

Note: There is no such term as tertiary case.

questions.text:
Arrange the following in order for the replication of hepatitis B virus.
  1. Uncoating
  2. DNA synthesis
  3. Transcription
  4. Enveloping
  5. Closed circular DNA
  6. Encapsidation
questions.solution:
The correct sequence in the hepatitis B viral replication is 1,5,3,6,2,4: uncoating > closed circular DNA > transcription > encapsidation > DNA synthesis > enveloping.

The hepatitis B virus is a DNA virus with an outer envelope and an inner nucleocapsid. The viral genome consists of two linear strands of DNA in a circular configuration. One of the strands (the plus strand) is incomplete resulting in partially double-stranded and partially single-stranded DNA. The steps in replication of HBV can be summarised as follows:

  • The virus first attaches to the host and gets uncoated.
  • The partially double-stranded DNA is converted to covalently closed circular (ccc) DNA in the nucleus.
  • The cccDNA serves as the template for the production of HBV mRNAs and pre-genomic RNA.
  • The pre-genomic RNA is encapsidated by newly synthesized HBcAg core particles.
  • Within the encapsidated core, RNA serves as a template for the HBV reverse transcriptase which is a part of the polymerase gene to synthesise negative-strand DNA. Positive-strand DNA synthesis starts but does not proceed to completion within the core, resulting in a variable-length positive-strand DNA.
  • Core particles containing these DNA replicative intermediates acquire HBsAg-containing envelopes to complete the process.

The images below show the structure and life cycle of the hepatitis B virus.

questions.text: Serum galactomannan is helpful in the diagnosis of ______.
questions.solution:
The galactomannan assay is used for the diagnosis of invasive (deep-seated) mycoses caused by Aspergillus species.

Galactomannan is a component of the cell wall of Aspergillus. It can be detected in serum or bronchoalveolar lavage by ELISA for the diagnosis of invasive aspergillosis in adults and children. This test is especially useful in hematopoietic stem cell transplant recipients or patients with hematologic malignancies. 

Other diagnostic features of invasive aspergillosis are:

  • A positive culture from the affected organ
  • Aspergillus antigen detection of galactomannan
  • Narrow, septate hyphae with branching at 45o and conidiophores
  • Halo sign on CT scan

β-glucan is helpful in diagnosing invasive aspergillosis as well as candidiasis.

The levels of galactomannan can also be elevated in cases of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA) but have a limited role in the diagnostic workup of patients with ABPA.

Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) - 112 fL

questions.solution:
The probable cause of anemia in this patient of vitamin B12 deficiency.

The given clinical scenario of macrocytic anemia in a vegetarian with elevated homocysteine and methyl malonic acid levels is due to megaloblastic anemia caused by vitamin B12. Folic acid deficiency is associated with elevated homocystine and normal methyl malonic acid levels.

The laboratory findings include:

  • Elevated homocysteine and methylmalonic acid

Neurological abnormalities which are seen in B12 deficiency and not in folate deficiency are peripheral neuropathy, subacute combined degeneration of the cord that affects dorsal column(sensory), lateral tract (motor), and spinocerebellar tract (cerebellum)-a positive Romberg's sign.

questions.text:
Match the following antiretroviral drugs with their important adverse effects.
Antiretroviral drug Adverse effect
1. Didanosine  a. Hypersensitivity syndrome
2. Abacavir b. Vivid dreams
3. Efavirenz c. Peripheral neuropathy
4. Enfuvirtide d. Injection-site reactions
questions.solution:
The correctly matched options are as follows:

Antiretroviral drug Adverse effect
1. Didanosine c. Peripheral neuropathy
2. Abacavir a. Hypersensitivity syndrome
3. Efavirenz b. Vivid dreams
4. Enfuvirtide d. Injection-site reactions

Didanosine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI). Peripheral neuropathy characterized by pain, numbness, and tingling in glove and stock pattern, and pancreatitis are the most adverse effects of this drug.

Abacavir is also an NRTI. The most serious adverse effect is a hypersensitivity syndrome characterized by fever, maculopapular rash, abdominal pain, gastrointestinal upset, malaise, and fatigue.

Efavirenz is a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI). Adverse effects are dizziness, impaired concentration, dysphoria, disturbing or vivid dreams, and insomnia.

Enfuvirtide is an entry (fusion) inhibitor. It is the only approved parenteral antiretroviral drug and therefore, injection-site reactions like pain, erythema, and induration are most frequently seen.

questions.text: Which of the following is observed in an infant of a diabetic mother?
questions.solution:
Infants of diabetic mothers are at increased risk of hypomagnesemia.

Elevated HbA1c levels correlate with an increased risk of neonatal complications. These include hypoglycemia, respiratory distress syndrome, hypocalcemia, polycythemia, hyperbilirubinemia, hyperviscosity syndrome, and cardiomyopathy, macrosomia , congenital anomalies and unexplained fetal demise. Long-term complications are childhood obesity, neurophysiological effects, and diabetes.

Hyperplasia of fetal β-islet cells occurs due to maternal hyperglycemia. Excess insulin secretion in the fetus leads to blockage of the action of cortisol which activates type II pneumocytes resulting in respiratory distress syndrome. It also makes the fetal interventricular septum and right ventricular wall thicker causing cardiomyopathy. Excess insulin secretion continues even after delivery causing neonatal hypoglycemia.

Fetal hypoxia leads to increased production and subsequent destruction of red cells causing polycythemia and hyperbilirubinemia. Fetal macrosomia (birth weight of more than 4 kg) causes birth injuries due to prolonged labour and shoulder dystocia.

questions.text:
In the course of resuscitation of a term neonate, positive pressure ventilation is started and there are no signs of effective ventilation after 30 seconds. Arrange the following ventilation corrective steps in the correct order.

A. Open the mouth

B. Pressure increase

C. Reposition the head

D. Mask readjustment

E. Alternative airway

F. Suction mouth and nose
questions.solution:
The correct order of ventilation correction steps is D-C-F-A-B-E. The steps are as follows and can be remembered with the mnemonic MRSOPA.

  • Mask has to be reapplied 
  • The infant's head is repositioned 
  • Suction the secretions
  • The mouth is kept open slightly and ventilated
  • The pressure is increased slightly
  • Change the airway 

The most effective indicator of successful ventilatory effort is a rise in heart rate. In a vast majority of infants, the underlying cause for having a low heart rate is ineffective ventilation rather than a primary cardiac cause.

When there is no sign of effective ventilation after 30 seconds of positive pressure ventilation (PPV), ventilation corrective steps should be taken. If the heart rate remains <60 beats per minute even after 60 seconds of PPV with the corrective steps, the infant should then be intubated.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman presented with a breast lump categorized as BI-RADS 4. What is the next best step in management?

BI-RADS - Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System
questions.solution:
The best option for further management would be tissue diagnosis by biopsy.

A BI-RADS category 4 is indicative of a suspicious abnormality with the likelihood of malignancy being 2% to 95%. Therefore, the next best step would be a tissue diagnosis by biopsy for ruling out/confirmation of the malignancy.

The Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BI-RADS) is used to categorize the degree of suspicion of malignancy for a mammographic abnormality. This is helpful when mammographic abnormalities that cannot be detected by the patient's physical examination include clustered microcalcifications and areas of abnormal density that have not yielded a palpable finding.

Other options:

Option A: Annual screening is usually done for BI-RADS categories 1 and 2. BI-RADS 1 means that there are no masses, suspicious calcifications, or areas of architectural distortion on mammography. BI-RADS 2 is consistent with benign findings including secretory calcifications, simple cysts, fat-containing lesions, calcified fibroadenomas, implants, and intramammary lymph nodes.

Option B: Bi-annual screening is done for BI-RADS category 3. BI-RADS 3 includes a non-palpable, circumscribed mass or a solitary group of punctate calcifications on a mammogram.

Option D: Surgical excision/lumpectomy is done for BI-RADS category 6 which indicates a known, biopsy-proven malignancy.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old woman is diagnosed to have cavernous sinus thrombosis. Which of the following features are present in this condition?
  1. Edema in the mastoid region
  2. Lateral rectus palsy
  3. Pus points below the conjunctiva
  4. Severe supraorbital pain
questions.solution:
The features of cavernous sinus thrombosis are edema in the mastoid region, lateral rectus palsy, and severe supraorbital pain.

 

 Features of cavernous sinus thrombosis are:

  • Fever
  • Severe Headache
  • Eye signs-
    • Early abducent nerve (6th cranial nerve) involvement causing lateral rectus palsy.
    • Later involvement of oculomotor (3rd cranial nerve) and trochlear nerve (4th cranial nerve) causing palsy.
    • Proptosis, restricted eye motility
    • Severe supraorbital pain
    • Chemosis
    • Absence of corneal sensation due to the involvement of the ophthalmic division of the 5th cranial nerve
    • Ipsilateral ptosis dilated pupil, and absence of direct and consensual pupillary right reflex are signs of 3rd cranial nerve palsy.
  • Edema in the mastoid region due to thrombosis of the emissary vein is a pathognomic sign.
  • Focal neurological deficits
  • Focal or generalized seizures
  • Altered mental status. 

Investigation using brain magnetic resonance imaging or magnetic resonance venography should be done urgently. Following early diagnosis, management of cavernous sinus thrombosis typically includes intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics, analgesics, anti-inflammatory drugs, and anticoagulants.

questions.text: Which pharyngeal arch is the muscle marked below derived from?
questions.solution:
The muscle marked in the image is the temporalis, and it is derived from the first pharyngeal arch. All muscles of mastication are derived from the first pharyngeal arch.

The first pharyngeal arch is known as the mandibular arch. The artery associated with the first arch is the maxillary artery and the nerve supply is provided by the maxillary and mandibular branches of the trigeminal nerve.

Derivatives of the first pharyngeal arch:

i. Skeletal derivatives: It has 2 prominences:

  • Mandibular prominence (ventral)- The mandibular prominence has two components:
    • Meckel's cartilage- It forms the malleus, incus, spine of the sphenoid, and the sphenomandibular and anterior malleolar ligaments.
    • Mesenchyme surrounding the Meckel's cartilage undergoes membranous ossification to form the mandible.
  • Maxillary prominence (dorsal). The mesenchyme of this process forms the maxilla, zygomatic bone, and part of the temporal bone.

ii. Muscular derivatives include

  • tensor tympani
  • tensor veli palatini
  • muscles of mastication (masseter, temporalis, medial pterygoid, lateral pterygoid)
  • anterior belly of digastric
  • mylohyoid

Pharyngeal pouch derivatives include the auditory tube and middle ear cavity.

questions.text: A female patient comes to the casualty ward after noticing the passage of blood instead of urine at night. Laboratory investigations show pancytopenia and elevated LDH levels. The findings of flow cytometry of blood are shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given history and flow cytogram showing a population of red blood cells deficient in both CD55 and CD59 suggest a likely diagnosis of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH).

PNH is a chronic acquired hemolytic anemia that occurs due to mutations in the phosphatidylinositol glycan complementation group A (PIGA) gene. PIGA is an enzyme that is essential for the synthesis of certain membrane-associated complement regulatory proteins.

Thus, PNH blood cells are deficient in three glycosylphosphatidylinositols (GPI) linked proteins that regulate complement activity:

  • Decay accelerating factors or CD55
  • Membrane inhibitor of reactive lysis or CD59
  • C8 binding protein

The most important of these is CD59, which is the potent inhibitor of C3 convertase. It prevents the spontaneous activation of the alternative complement pathway. Red cells deficient in these GPI-linked factors are susceptible to lysis or injury by the C5b - C9 membrane attack complex.

Clinically, the patient would have hemolysis, pancytopenia, and a tendency for venous thrombosis. Intravascular hemolysis may be nocturnal and paroxysmal or chronic hemolysis without the dramatic hemoglobinuria. Some patients may complain of recurrent attacks of abdominal pain that may be related to thrombosis in abdominal veins. 

Investigations show iron deficiency anemia (due to chronic hemoglobinuria), and elevated LDH levels. The gold standard for diagnosis is flow cytometry which would be CD59 and CD55 negative. 

Flow cytometry: It shows a population of red cells that is deficient in both CD55 and CD59 (left-lower quadrant in the image below). Also, a second population of red cells, which are derived from residual normal hematopoietic stem cells may be seen, which are positive for CD55 and CD59 (right-upper quadrant in the image below).

 

Eculizumab is used in treatment. It is a monoclonal antibody that prevents the conversion of the complement C5 to C5a.  

Other options: 

Option A: Hereditary spherocytosis is an autosomal dominant disorder that causes the loss of red cell membrane leading to its conversion to a spherocyte. The spherocytes are phagocytosed by the spleen causing red cell destruction. Clinically, patients present with anemia and splenomegaly. 

Option C: Warm antibody immune hemolytic anemia is caused by antibodies that bind to red blood cells at 37 degrees Celsius. It may be idiopathic, or secondarily caused by drugs such as alpha-methyldopa, other autoimmune diseases such as SLE, or lymphoid neoplasms. Autoimmune hemolytic anemias can also be caused by other antibodies such as cold agglutinin type (binds to RBCs at 0 to 4 degrees Celsius) or cold hemolysin type (causing paroxysmal cold hemoglobin type). 

Option D: Disseminated intravascular coagulation is a thrombohemorragic disorder caused by excessive coagulation. This causes the consumption of platelets and coagulation factors leading to bleeding, vascular occlusion, and tissue hypoxemia. Here, red blood cells undergo traumatic damage while passing through lumens filled with thrombi. This causes intravascular hemolysis known as microangiopathic hemolytic anemia. The most common triggers are major trauma, sepsis, and obstetric complications.

questions.text: Permanent alteration of the fingerprint pattern occurs in all of the following conditions, except ________.
questions.solution:
Permanent alteration of the fingerprint pattern does not occur in acromegaly.

Fingerprints are impressions of patterns formed by the papillary or epidermal ridges of the fingertips. The arrangement and distribution of the ridges not only remain unchanged throughout life but is unique for each individual. The study of this ridge pattern in the skin is called dermatoglyphics or dactylography and helps in the identification of the individual.

However, permanent impairment of the fingerprint pattern occurs in leprosy, electrical injury, and subsequent radiation exposure.

In acromegaly, there is a change in the distance between the ridges but no permanent impairment in the fingerprint pattern. A similar change is observed in infantile paralysis and rickets. Ridge alteration can also occur in eczema, acanthosis nigricans, scleroderma, and dry or atrophic skin. Additionally, there is moderate epidermal ridge atrophy and loss of pattern in celiac disease.

A patient presents with a vaginal discharge with a fishy odor and no itching. While evaluating the Pap smear of a patient, you come across the following finding. Which of the following organisms can cause this infection?
  1. Mobiluncus curtisii
  2. Gardnerella vaginalis
  3. Candida albicans
  4. Mycoplasma hominis
  5. Haemophilus vaginalis
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and the pap smear finding are suggestive of bacterial vaginosis. Bacterial vaginosis is a polymicrobial infection caused by Mobiluncus curtisii, Gardnerella vaginalis, Mycoplasma hominis, and Haemophilus vaginalis. Hence, option B is correct.

Clue cells are epithelial cells with a fuzzy border or granular cytoplasm caused by small gram-negative bacilli adhering on their surface is characteristic of bacterial vaginosis. It has a malodorous (fishy smell) vaginal discharge with minimal vulval irritation.

Amsel's Criteria is helpful in diagnosing bacterial vaginosis when 3 of the following 4 are present

  • Thin, white homogenous vaginal discharge
  • A pH of vaginal fluid >4.5
  • Fishy odor of discharge accentuated by adding 10% KOH-Whiff test
  • Presence of Clue cells on microscopy. 

 Treatment of sexual partners is not required and symptomatic women are treated with metronidazole or clindamycin.

questions.text:
A woman brought her 14-month-old child to the PHC for routine immunization. The child was born in February 2020 at home and has not received any vaccine till now due to the lockdown. The mother is apprehensive about her child's health and wants to immunize him. Which of the following vaccines can be given to the child now?
  1. OPV
  2. Measles
  3. BCG
  4. Vitamin A
  5. Pentavalent
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1, 2, 4.

In the case of an unimmunized 14-month-old child, OPV, measles, and vitamin A vaccines can be given.

Catch-up vaccination involves the administration of vaccines in children who have not been immunized at all (left-outs) or for children who took vaccines but could not complete the course (dropouts).

According to the National Immunization Schedule, BCG can only be given up to 1 year of age. 

OPV can be given till 5 years of age.

Measles can be given till 5 years of age.

DPT can be given until 7 years of age (with booster doses).

Only the above-mentioned vaccines have upper age limits. 

For pentavalent, IPV, PCV, and rotavirus vaccines, if at least one dose is given before one year of age, then remaining doses can be administered and the schedule must be completed irrespective of the age of the child. If the first dose is not administered before one year of age, then these vaccines cannot be administered to the child under UIP.

questions.text:
FAST investigation is helpful in assessing

(FAST: Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma)

  1. Splenic injury
  2. Morison’s pouch
  3. Pouch of Douglas
  4. Pericardial injury
questions.solution:
A FAST investigation is helpful in assessing all the given options including 1. Splenic injury, 2. Morisson’s pouch, 3. Pouch of Douglas and 4. Pericardial injury

FAST is a rapid diagnostic examination that uses USG to assess patients with potential thoracoabdominal injuries- Hemoperitoneum and Hemopericardium. It is performed within 2­-4 minutes. 

Technique:

  • Patient in supine position
  • 3.5-5.0 MHz curvilinear/large convex transducer
  • Traditionally, in cases of blunt trauma, examination starts with RUQ, while in penetrating trauma examination starts with a cardiac view.
  • Five regions may be scanned :
    • Subxiphoid transverse view: Assess for pericardial effusion and left lobe liver injuries.
    • Longitudinal view of the right upper quadrant: Assess for right liver injuries, right kidney injury, and Morison's pouch.
    • Longitudinal view of the left upper quadrant: Assess for splenic injury and left kidney injury.
    • Transverse and longitudinal views of the suprapubic region: Assess the bladder and pouch of Douglas.

An "extended FAST or eFAST" scan: Assess left and right thoracic views, in addition to the FAST assessed regions, to look for pneumothorax and hemothorax.

questions.text: Excitatory postsynaptic potential (EPSP) is due to the influx of ______.
questions.solution:
Excitatory postsynaptic potential (EPSP) is due to the influx of sodium ions (Na+).

At the post-synaptic membrane, neurotransmitters binding to receptors generate responses that can be excitatory or inhibitory. If it generates an excitatory response (makes the membrane more electrically positive/ depolarized), it is an excitatory postsynaptic potential (EPSP) because it makes the cell more likely to reach an action potential.

EPSP may be due to

  • The opening of sodium channels or calcium channels to allow large numbers of positive electrical charges to flow to the interior of the postsynaptic cell.
  • Depressed conduction through chloride or potassium channels or both.
  • Various changes in the internal metabolism of the postsynaptic neuron to increase the number of excitatory membrane receptors or decrease the number of inhibitory membrane receptors.

As seen in the figure, following the discharge of the sensory neuron, there is positivity in the motor neuron signifying a EPSP.

questions.text:
All the following are methods of indirect transmission of diseases, except _____.
  1. Contact with soil
  2. Droplet nuclei
  3. Fomite borne
  4. Unclean hands and fingers
  5. Transplacental
questions.solution:
Contact with soil & transplacental route is the direct mode of disease transmission among the given options.

Communicable diseases are classified based on the mode of transmission:

  • Direct:
    • Direct contact (e.g.: sexual intercourse)
    • Contact with soil
    • Droplet infection
    • Skin or mucosal inoculation
    • Transplacental 
  • Indirect: 
    • Vehicle-borne
    • Vector-borne
    • Air-borne
      • Droplet nuclei
      • Dust
    • Fomite-borne
    • Unclean hands and fingers

The traditional 5 F's - flies, fingers, fomites, food, and fluids can be used to remember the modes of indirect transmission. Some infectious agents are able to survive in the external environment while maintaining their basic properties of virulence. This is a requirement for this indirect transmission.

An important distinction has to be drawn between droplet nuclei infection and droplet infection. The main difference between airborne droplet nuclei and droplet transmission is in the size of infected/ contagious particles and whether proximity is required for transmission.

Droplet nuclei/ residue from evaporated droplets containing infective microorganisms can result in airborne transmission. The size of these droplet nuclei is <5 μm in diameter, and they can remain suspended in the air for significant periods of time, allowing them to be transmitted over distances >1 m. There's no need for close proximity or contact. Diseases like chickenpox, measles, tuberculosis, and influenza can spread through airborne transmission.

Droplet transmission occurs when one cough or sneezes, and contagious droplets from the infected person travel shortly in the air and directly comes in contact with another person's conjunctiva, mouth, or nasal mucosa. The particle size here is >5 μm in diameter. Transmission here requires close proximity and direct contact. Examples of diseases spread via this route include the common cold, diphtheria, and whooping cough.

questions.text: An RNA isolated is found to have 90 nucleotides and is rich in dihydrouracil and pseudouridylic acid. Which of the following is present in the 3' end of this RNA?
questions.solution:
The sequence CCA attaches at the 3' end of the cloverleaf structure in transfer RNA (tRNA) that is rich in modified bases such as dihydrouracil and pseudouridylic acid.

Transfer RNA is a type of RNA that helps to transport amino acids from the cell cytoplasm to the ribosome where protein synthesis is taking place. Since they are soluble in nature, they are also known as soluble RNA (sRNA). They undergo internal base-pairing (represented by the black dotted lines in the image below) to form the secondary cloverleaf structure.

Each part of the cloverleaf structure serves a different purpose. The parts of the cloverleaf include the following:

  • Anticodon loop
  • Acceptor arm
  • D loop
  • TΨC loop
  • Variable loop

The anticodon loop shown is where the anticodon triplet codons are present that make a tRNA specific. This anticodon will base pair with the complementary codon on the mRNA (messenger RNA) strand undergoing translation.

The acceptor arm is at the 3' end. This 3' end of the tRNA has the CCA sequence. The hydroxyl group on the A of the CCA sequence gets charged by accepting the amino acid specific to the codon (on the mRNA) that pairs with the anticodon loop. This then gets added to the elongating polypeptide chain. 

The D loop, TΨC loop, and variable loop are involved in defining the specific tRNA and ensuring accurate codon-anticodon base pairing.

Thus, at least one specific tRNA exists for each of the 20 amino acids that are commonly present in proteins. This tRNA acts as a mediator between the cytosolic amino acids and the mRNA strand undergoing translation.

Other options:

Options A and D: AUG and UAG are mRNA start and stop codons that initiate and terminate translation respectively.

Options B: After transcription, eukaryotic pre-mRNA undergoes posttranscriptional modification, which includes the addition of a poly-A tail at the 3' end and methylguanosine cap at the 5' end, and the removal of introns. It is not seen in tRNA.

questions.text: Double bleb sign seen in early pregnancy is due to _______.
questions.solution:
The double bleb sign is due to the yolk sac and amniotic sac.

On ultrasonographic examination, a gestational sac may contain the yolk sac and amniotic sac, appearing like two small bubbles. This is known as the double bleb sign. The embryonic disc is located between the yolk sac and the amniotic sac. It is an important feature of an intrauterine pregnancy.

Other options:

In a twin pregnancy, the chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed with the help of an ultrasound examination.

  • In dichorionic gestation, the twins are separated by amniotic membranes and an intervening chorion. So, a thicker twin peak sign or lambda (λ) sign is formed at the point at which the amnions meet the placenta.
  • In monochorionic diamniotic gestation, the twins are separated only by the two amniotic membranes with no intervening chorion. So, a thin T sign is formed at the point at which the amnions meet the placenta.

Heterotopic pregnancy is a condition in which a normal uterine pregnancy co-exists with an extrauterine (ectopic) pregnancy. Although heterotopic pregnancy can occur spontaneously, it is more likely after artificial reproductive technology (ART) and ovulation induction.

The below image shows heterotopic pregnancy with 2 sacs, one inside the uterus (white arrow) and the other in the cervix (black arrows).

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient presents with painful blisters over the oral mucosa and genital areas. She gives a history of similar lesions in the past. A biopsy from the lesion shows a suprabasal split on histopathology. Immunofluorescence microscopy reveals intercellular IgG deposits. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario point towards the diagnosis of pemphigus vulgaris.

Pemphigus vulgaris is characterized by flaccid blisters, denuded skin, and oro-mucosal lesions. Histopathology showing suprabasal split is the hallmark feature of pemphigus vulgaris. Immunofluorescence shows the fishnet appearance of IgG antibodies against Dsg3 > Dsg1.

Other options:

Dermatitis herpetiformis is associated with gluten‐sensitive enteropathy presenting as chronic, intensely pruritic, skin lesions. It results in the deposition of IgA autoantibodies in the dermal papillae which leads to neutrophil infiltration and blister formation over extensor surfaces.

Bullous pemphigoid usually affects elders (60-80 years). It is characterized by large, tense, subepidermal blisters with no mucosal involvement. Immunofluorescence shows linear IgG deposits in dermal-epidermal junction.

In pemphigus foliaceus, subcorneal blisters are seen with no mucosal involvement.
