questions.text: In which of the following images do the green areas correctly represent the areas of the spinal cord affected in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis?
questions.solution:
Image B correctly represents the areas of the spinal cord affected by amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). The pathologic hallmark of ALS is the death of the affected lower motor neurons (LMN) consisting of the anterior horn cells of the spinal cord and their homologues in the brainstem, upper motor neurons (UMN) consisting of the corticospinal tract and corticobulbar tract originating in the motor cortex. Image B has the anterior horn of the spinal cord and the corticospinal tracts highlighted in green.

Image A: The anterior horn of the spinal cord is highlighted in green in this image. Spinal muscular atrophy is a genetic disease characterized by progressive degeneration of anterior horn cells, which results in weakness. 

Image C: The dorsal column and dorsal root of the spinal cord are highlighted in green in this image. Tabes dorsalis (or syphilitic myelopathy) is a slow degeneration and demyelination of the neural tracts seen in tertiary syphilis, primarily involving the dorsal columns of the spinal cord, dorsal roots, and dorsal root ganglia.

Image D: The dorsal columns and the lateral column tracts of the spinal cord are highlighted in green in this image. Vitamin B12 deficiency causes subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord (SACD) and affects the dorsal column and the lateral tracts.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy presents with pain and claudication in the legs after exercise. There is a disparity of blood pressure in the arms and legs. His x-ray shows the given finding. Which of the following is true regarding the suspected condition?

A. Most common site of etiology is juxtaductal.

B. It is associated with Turner's syndrome.

C. More than 70% of these patients have a bicuspid aortic valve.

D. Upper limbs have weak pulse due to hypotension.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of pain and claudication in the legs after exercise, disparity of blood pressure in the arms and legs, and x-ray finding of notching of the ribs point to a diagnosis of coarctation of the aorta. The true statements regarding it are A, B, and C.

Coarctation of aorta occurs most commonly due to a constriction of the aorta below the origin of the left subclavian artery at the origin of the ductus arteriosus known as a juxtaductal coarctation (Option A). It classically presents as a disparity in blood pressure in the arms and legs. The femoral, popliteal, posterior tibial, and dorsalis pedis pulses are weak, in contrast to the bounding pulses of the arms and carotid vessels. (Option D)

It can be a feature of Turner syndrome and more than 70% of these patients will have a bicuspid aortic valve. The x-ray shown in the question shows rib notching that occurs due to rib erosion by dilated collateral vessels. The below x-ray demonstrates a "3" sign seen due to indentation of the aorta at the site of coarctation.

questions.text: A 33-year-old lady, who is also a chronic smoker, presents with the symptoms of bloody diarrhea with mucus, and tenesmus for 4 months. She has been on oral contraceptives for the past  6 months. A colonoscopy was done and showed continuous mucosal ulcerations primarily involving the recto-sigmoid colon. Which of the following factors is protective against this condition?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette with colonoscopy showing continuous mucosal ulcerations primarily involving the recto-sigmoid colon is suggestive of ulcerative colitis. Smoking has found to be protective against this condition.

Inflammatory bowel diseases are chronic idiopathic conditions that include

  1. Ulcerative colitis
  2. Crohn's disease

Though smoking is protective against ulcerative colitis, it acts as a risk factor for the development of Crohn's disease.

Ulcerative colitis is a type of inflammatory bowel disease characterized by diarrhea, rectal bleeding, tenesmus, the passage of mucus, and crampy abdominal pain. Diffuse involvement of the mucosa is seen.

Colonoscopic findings include erythema, regenerative mucosal nodules, psuedopolyps, and ulcerations.

Extra-intestinal manifestations of ulcerative colitis include ankylosing spondylitis, sacroiliitis, episcleritis, uveitis, pyoderma gangrenosum, and primary sclerosing cholangitis.

Complications include toxic megacolon, hemorrhage, strictures, and perforations. These patients are also at increased risk of colon cancer.

Other options:

Option A: Males are comparatively more commonly affected. This is common to both ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease.

Option B: Oral contraceptives have shown no increased risk for the development of ulcerative colitis. But oral contraceptives have a hazard ratio of almost 3 for Crohn's disease.

Option C: People in the age groups of 20-40 years and 70-90 years are commonly affected. This is common to both ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease.

questions.text:
A patient was started on latanoprost for the treatment of wide-angle glaucoma. Which among the following statements is/are true regarding the drug?
  1. Twice daily application of the drug is preferred.
  2. It decreases the uveoscleral outflow.
  3. Macular edema can develop as an adverse effect.
questions.solution:
The correct statement about latanoprost is macular edema can develop as an adverse effect.

Topical PGF2 alpha (prostaglandin) analogs are used as a first choice in the treatment of open-angle glaucoma. Latanoprost is the most commonly used. Travoprost and bimatoprost are the other drugs available.

Mechanism of action: It reduces intraocular pressure by increasing the uveoscleral outflow. It has good efficacy and once-daily application is preferred.

Adverse effects:

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl came to the hospital with a history of severe sore throat, enlarged and tender cervical lymph nodes, and fever (38.2 degrees Celsius). There is no cough or shortness of breath. Findings of oral cavity examination are shown in the image below. Which of the following statement is true for the organism causing this condition?

choices.text: It belongs to Lancefield's group B
The infection is treated with oral penicillin V for 10 days

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the given image are suggestive of group A β- hemolytic streptococcal (GABHS) pharyngitis. The correct statement is that this condition is treated with penicillin V.

The above image shows tonsillar exudates. Based on the clinical features the patient has a centor score of 4, suggesting a high probability of group A β- hemolytic streptococcal (GABHS) pharyngitis. Streptococcus pyogenes belongs to Lancefield group A based on carbohydrate antigen. It characteristically shows complete hemolysis on blood agar which is called beta-hemolysis. This Streptococcus pyogenes is further typed based on the M protein on the cell surface by Griffith typing. It is characteristically sensitive to bacitracin which can also be used for identification.

The management of suspected bacterial pharyngitis includes obtaining a streptococcal rapid antigen detection test(RADT) or a throat culture. For a patient with Centor score of 4, empirical antibiotic therapy with Penicillin V for 10 days or Erythromycin (in case of allergy to penicillin) is given. 

Centor criteria:

  • Absence of cough
  • Pharyngotonsillar exudate
  • Tender anterior cervical lymphadenopathy
  • Fever over 38°C

One point is allotted for each criterion, and the maximum score is 4. For the above patient, the score is: 1+1+1+1 = 4

 Based on the Centor score, the management is as follows:

Centor criteria score Management
0 or 1 No testing or treatment
2 or 3 A single Throat swab culture and Rapid streptococcal antigen testing, and if they are positive provide antibiotic treatment
4 Empirical antibiotic therapy with penicillin V potassium for 10 days or Erythromycin (in case of allergy to penicillin) or Cefuroxime axetil for 5-10 days

questions.text: Which among the following is the earliest internal organ change seen in putrefaction?

choices.text: Heart becomes soft with dilation of the cavity
Mucous membrane of larynx becomes brownish-red and soft
Lungs reduced to a small black mass

questions.solution:
The earliest internal organ change in putrefaction is the larynx's mucous membrane, which becomes brownish-red.

Internally decomposition proceeds more slowly than the surface. Color change in viscera varies from dark red to black. The viscera becomes softer and greasy to the touch and finally breakdown into a soft disintegrating mass.

The order of putrefaction of organs from first to last:

Larynx and trachea—> Stomach, intestine, spleen—>Liver and lungs —> Brain—>Heart—>Kidney and the bladder—>Prostate and uterus—>Bones

At first, the mucous membrane of the larynx and trachea becomes brownish-red and later greenish and softened.

The stomach and intestine become softened, dark brown, and change into a dark, soft, pulpy mass. The mucosa appears macerated which can be easily peeled off. The spleen becomes soft, and pulpy, and liquefies in two to three days.

The liver becomes soft and flabby. Cl. Welchii forms small clumps in a tissue space and produces gas, that soon increases in size. The pancreas becomes soft and hemorrhagic. Gaseous bullae are formed under the pleura in the lungs which are small, pale-red, and scattered. The lung becomes soft and it collapses and is reduced to a small black mass.

The leptomeninges of the brain may appear red. the liquefying brain may be grey-green.

The heart becomes soft and flabby and there is dilation of the cavity. There are formations of nodules of 1mm or less in size and are called "miliary plaques". They consist of calcium and soapy material.

The renal tissue becomes flabby and the surfaces turn dull and appear parboiled. The cortex darkens and later becomes green. The bladder resists putrefaction for a long time if it is empty and contracted.

Related Pearl: Order of Putrefaction

  • Larynx and trachea – first organ to putrify   
  • Stomach, intestine, and spleen
  • Liver and lungs
  • Brain
  • Heart
  • Kidney and bladder
  • Prostate and uterus – virgin uterus resists putrefaction whereas uterus soon after delivery putrefies rapidly.
  • Skin, muscle, tendon
  • Bones


NOTE: This is only a generalised order of putrefaction, as each case must be assessed as per the attending factors, both endogenous and exogenous.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding ligature strangulation?

choices.text: Bruising of the neck muscles commonly seen
Subcutaneous tissue underneath the ligature mark is usually hard, white, and glistening
Thyroid cartilage fracture is commonly seen
Dribbling of saliva is not seen in the victim

questions.solution:
Subcutaneous tissue underneath the ligature mark is usually hard, white, and glistening in cases of hanging, not ligature strangulation. In cases of ligature strangulation, the subcutaneous tissue appears ecchymosed.

Strangulation is a type of asphyxia where there is neck constriction without suspension of the body. The pressure on the neck is applied either by bare hands, a ligature, or by any other instrument. There is sudden and violent compression of the windpipe which causes immediate insensibility and death. 

When strangulation is done by using a ligature, like a constricting band or rope, it is called ligature strangulation. The constricting band is tightened by a force other than the victim's body weight. It is characterized by the ligature mark which is transverse and completely encircling the neck below the thyroid cartilage. There is no dribbling of saliva. Bleeding may be present in the ears, nose, and mouth. Thyroid cartilage fracture is commonly seen in strangulation. But the hyoid bond fracture is uncommon. Ligature and manual strangulations are mostly homicidal. Marks of violence are usually seen on other parts of the body.

questions.text: An 82-year-old male patient dies of severe congestive heart failure. An autopsy was done, which revealed the following appearance of the aortic valve. Blood investigations done before death revealed normal levels of serum sodium, potassium, calcium, and chloride. Which of the following pathological processes is likely to have resulted in the appearance of the aortic valve as shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The image shows extensive calcification of the aortic valve resulting in stenosis. Calcification of the valve, in an elderly patient, with normal serum calcium levels, occurs due to dystrophic calcification.

When the deposition of calcium occurs in dead or dying tissues, it is called dystrophic calcification. This occurs in the absence of derangements in calcium metabolism, i.e. the calcium levels are normal. Dystrophic calcification is seen in areas of necrosis of any type including coagulative, caseous, or liquefactive, and in foci of enzymatic fat necrosis.

Some examples include atheromas of advanced atherosclerosis and areas of caseous necrosis in tuberculosis. It also commonly develops in aging or damaged heart valves.

Other options:

Option A - Cardiac amyloidosis may occur secondary to systemic amyloidosis or as a result of aging (senile amyloidosis). It is associated with the deposition of hyaline, eosinophilic amyloid, in the conduction tissue, interstitium, and coronary vessels. These deposits may be seen on Congo red staining.

Option B - Monckeberg medial sclerosis is a vascular pathology of aging characterized by calcifications accumulating in the medial layers of muscular arteries. Since there is no vascular compromise (no luminal narrowing), it is usually an accidental finding.

Option D - Metastatic calcification occurs in normal tissues, in the presence of hypercalcemia. It is usually a consequence of excessive parathyroid hormone.

questions.text:
Which of the following statement/s is/are correct regarding antemortem burns?
  1. Zone of hyperemia is present at the edge of the burnt area.
  2. Skin adjacent to the burn area does not show an increase in enzyme reaction.
  3. The base of the blister is red and inflamed.
  4. Reactive changes present in the tissue cells
questions.solution:
Statement 1,3,4(option B) is correct regarding antemortem burn.

A zone of hyperemia (line of redness), which varies in width is present at the edge of the burnt area in antemortem burns.  It is due to edema of tissues and capillary dilatation which merges with the edge of the burn. It involves the whole thickness of true skin. It is permanent and persists even after death. I f the whole body is burnt, line of redness will be absent.

The antemortem blister appears as a raised dome. It contains serous fluid with proteins and chlorides. The base shows reddening with swollen papillae.

In antemortem burns, the skin adjacent to the burnt area shows an increase in enzyme reaction. The reaction is increased for sulfhydryl groups in all layers. There is also an increase in ATP, esterases, aminopeptidases, and acid and alkaline phosphatase.

Marked cellular exudation and reactive tissue changes are called a vital reactions. This is characteristic of antemortem burns.

questions.text:
Which of the following is the best test for quantifying viral load for herpes simplex virus?

PCR: Polymerase chain reaction

RTPCR: Reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction

choices.text: RTPCR followed by Real time PCR

questions.solution:
Real-time PCR is the best test to quantify the viral load of herpes, which is a DNA virus.

Quantification of DNA involves the assessment of the amount/concentration of DNA that is present in a sample when carrying out a technique like PCR. Real-time PCR or quantitative PCR/qPCR involves the quantification of DNA after each cycle of amplification, or, in "real-time" at the end of the procedure; therefore real-time PCR helps in the quantitative analysis of DNA viral load.

Option A: RT-PCR (reverse transcriptase PCR) involves the generation of complementary DNA (cDNA) copies of the mRNA using the reverse transcriptase enzyme followed by amplifying the cDNA copies by PCR technique. When reverse transcriptase PCR and qPCR are combined, they can be used to quantify RNA viruses like coronavirus.

Option B: RTPCR can convert the RNA into cDNA by reverse transcriptase enzyme and then amplify the cDNA copies by means of PCR but cannot quantify the RNA.

Option C: PCR-Restriction fragment length polymorphism (PCR-RFLP) is also called cleaved amplified polymorphic sequence (CAPS) assay. Polymorphisms are inherited differences found among individuals in more than 1% of the normal population. PCR-RFLP is a technique in which organisms may be differentiated by variations in their DNA sequence by restriction endonucleases. Typically, gel electrophoresis is used to visualize RFLPs. Thus, RFLP can detect differences in homologous DNA sequences and is not a tool for quantifying viral load.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old morbidly obese diabetic woman presents with a history of failed metformin therapy. She is started on canagliflozin. Which of the following side effects are associated with canagliflozin?
  1. Urinary tract infections
  2. Weight gain
  3. Increased risk of fractures
  4. Increased risk of lower extremity amputation
questions.solution:
The side effects associated with canagliflozin are urinary tract infections, increased risk of fractures, and lower extremity amputations.

Canagliflozin is a sodium-glucose transporter 2 (SGLT-2) inhibitor. Other SGLT-2 inhibitors include dapagliflozin and empagliflozin. They act by inhibiting the SGLT-2 transporter which is present on the proximal segment of the renal tubule. It is responsible for the reabsorption of 80-90% of filtered glucose. It inhibits glucose reabsorption resulting in glycosuria and a change in the renal threshold.

SGLT2 inhibitors can cause mild weight loss and reduction in blood pressure. Drugs like empagliflozin and canagliflozin are found to reduce major cardiovascular events.

The common side effects include urinary tract infections and genital mycotic infections due to the high glucose content of the urine. There is a risk of the development of diabetic ketoacidosis. It increases the risk of fractures and lower limb amputations due to the creation of an imbalance with the minerals and circulating parathormone and vitamin D. Since SGLT2 inhibitors depend on the rate of glucose filtration to be effective, potency decreases if given in stage 3 kidney disease (GFR 60–30 mL/min).

questions.text: Which of the following actions is examined and what is the defect observed in a patient with abducens nerve palsy?
questions.solution:
Abducens nerve innervates the lateral rectus muscle. The action produced by this muscle is abduction. The sixth cranial nerve palsy results in an esotropia/convergent squint.

The outward movement (abduction) of the affected eye is impaired, and the face will be turned towards the same side. When the patient looks at the paralyzed side, they will experience homonymous diplopia. 

Esotropia can be revealed using the cover-uncover test. 

First, the patient has to fix their gaze by looking at a distant object. One of the eyes is covered while simultaneously observing the other eye. If the other eye moves away from the nose, then esotropia is present. This procedure should be repeated on the other eye. 

 

The occulomotor nerve supplies all extraocular muscles except:

  • Lateral rectus, which is supplied by the 6th nerve
  • Superior oblique, which is supplied by the 4th nerve

questions.text: A child born to a mother has hypoplasia of the brain, intracranial calcifications, and microcephaly, as shown below. Which of the following could have prevented this congenital infection?

choices.text: Treatment of pregnant mother with penicillin

questions.solution:
The features seen in this newborn with microcephaly and intracranial calcifications are suggestive of Zika virus infection, and it could have been prevented by using barrier contraceptives during pregnancy.

Zika virus belongs to Flavivirus genus. It spreads by

  • Transplacental route from an infected mother to her child (primary route)
  • Mosquito-borne through Aedes aegypti 
  • Sexual contact 
  • Blood transfusion.

In adults, it can be asymptomatic or cause mild symptoms like fever, headache, joint pain, rash, conjunctivitis, and myalgia. But infection during pregnancy causes microcephaly and other severe brain defects.

Other options:

Option A: Vaccination before pregnancy will prevent congenital rubella syndrome characterized by cataracts, chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and hearing defects. 

Option C: Treatment with penicillin during pregnancy prevents congenital syphilis characterized by jaundice, hepatomegaly, maculopapular rash, and bone lesions.

Option D: Avoiding cats during pregnancy will prevent congenital toxoplasmosis mainly causes hydrocephalus, chorioretinitis, and intracranial calcification.

questions.text:
A patient with chronic tophaceous gout was prescribed probenecid. Which of the following statements is/are true regarding the drug?
  1. It inhibits the reabsorption of uric acid in the renal tubules.
  2. It can precipitate uric acid calculi.
  3. It promotes the urinary excretion of penicillin and methotrexate.
  4. Aspirin blocks the uricosuric action of probenecid.
questions.solution:
The true statements about probenecid are 1,2, and 4.

Probenecid is a uricosuric agent that promotes the excretion of uric acid. It is used to decrease the body pool of urate in patients with chronic gout. The drug acts by inhibiting the organic anion transporter, particularly URAT-1 in the renal tubules that are involved in uric acid reabsorption. It is used as an adjuvant to allopurinol in chronic gout and hyperuricemia.

Probenecid increases urinary urate levels. Plenty of fluids are given to avoid urate calculi formation. Probenecid should not be used in gouty patients with nephrolithiasis or with overproduction of uric acid.

Probenecid inhibits the urinary excretion of penicillin hence prolonging penicillin action by enhancing and sustaining their blood levels. It inhibits the urinary excretion of other drugs such as cephalosporins, sulfonamides, methotrexate, and indomethacin. Aspirin blocks the uricosuric action of the drug.

questions.text: In a reaction, the substrate is available in a concentration that is 1000 times the Km value of the enzyme.  After 10 minutes of reaction, 1% of the substrate is converted to product (10 μg/mL). If the concentration of the enzyme is changed to 1/3 and the concentration of substrate is doubled, what is the time taken to convert the substrate into 20 μg/mL of the product?
questions.solution:
The time taken for the formation of 20 μg/mL of the product is 60 minutes.

When the substrate concentration is much greater than the Km value, the rate of the reaction is independent of the substrate concentration i.e. it follows zero-order kinetics. In this reaction, the substrate concentration is 1000 times the Km value therefore it follows zero-order kinetics. So, doubling the substrate concentration does not change the velocity of the reaction.

The rate of the reaction is directly proportional to the concentration of the enzyme. As the enzyme concentration becomes 1/3rd, the velocity of the reaction also becomes 1/3.

Hence the time taken for the formation of the same amount of product will become tripled. That is 10 × 3 = 30 minutes. Therefore time taken to form twice the product which is 20 micrograms/ml is doubled i.e 60 minutes.

Alternatively, for zero-order kinetics, 10 μg/mL in 10 minutes gives a reaction rate of 1 μg/m/min. To make a product of 20 μg/mL it would take 20 minutes. since the enzymes are cut to 1/3 rd of their initial concentration, it will take 3 times the original time for the same product i.e 20*3= 60 minutes.

questions.text: What is the most common complication of the procedure shown in the picture?
questions.solution:
The image depicts the procedure of endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP). Pancreatitis is the most common complication of ERCP. 

Here in this question image, a side-viewing endoscope is passed through the pylorus of the stomach into the second part of the duodenum to visualize the papilla. It is then cannulated, and dye is injected into the pancreatic or bile duct to visualize the pancreatic or biliary tree.

The pancreatitis is usually mild and resolves in a few days. CT scan is indicated in a patient complaining of pain, tachycardia, or hypotension post-ERCP. The risk factors for the development of post-ERCP pancreatitis include sphincter of Oddi dysfunction, young age, normal bilirubin, past history of pancreatitis, contrast injecting into pancreatic ducts, pancreatic sphincterotomy and balloon dilatation of biliary sphincter.

It is now recommended to administer per-rectal indomethacin or diclofenac before or after the procedure to reduce the risk of post-ERCP pancreatitis.

The other complications of ERCP include duodenal perforation, hemorrhage, and sepsis.

 

Related Pearl: Diagnostic Evaluation of the Bile Ducts

Diagnostic Evaluation of the Bile Ducts

  • Hepatobiliary ultrasound: Initial procedure of choice in investigating possible biliary tract obstruction
  • CT scan: Procedure of choice in investigating possible biliary obstruction if diagnostic limitations prevent HBUS
  • MRCP: Useful modality for visualizing pancreatic and biliary ducts
  • ERCP: Best visualisation of distal biliary tract
    • Endoscopic sphincterotomy and stone removal can also be done
  • PTC(Percutaneous Transhepatic Cholangiography): Best visualisation of proximal biliary tract
    • Indicated when ERCP is contraindicated or failed
  • EUS: Most sensitive method to detect ampullary stones

questions.text:
Which of the following is a feature of compartment syndrome?

1. Differential pressure is more than 30 mmHg.

2. Fasciotomy involves incising up to the superficial fascia.

3. It can be a complication of open fractures.

4. Pain on the passive stretch is a late feature.
questions.solution:
Compartment syndrome can occur as a complication of open fractures.

Acute compartment syndrome refers to the rise in the intra-compartmental pressure to an extent and duration that without decompression would lead to tissue ischemia and necrosis. 

The classic features of ischemia in acute compartment syndrome include the 5 Ps. 

  1. Pain is the first symptom (Statement 4) of acute compartment syndrome. On passive stretching of the muscles, severe pain can be elicited. 
  2. Paresthesia and hypoesthesia are the first signs of nerve ischemia.
  3. Paralysis of muscle groups affected in that compartment is a late sign. 
  4. Pulselessness is an indication to do arteriography. Usually, the peripheral pulses and capillary return are intact in the early stages, unless there is a major arterial injury.
  5. Pallor of the skin may not always be seen as ischemia occurs at the capillary level.

The diagnosis can be confirmed by measuring the intra-compartmental pressure. The difference between diastolic pressure and compartment pressure is known as differential pressure (ΔP). If the differential pressure (ΔP) is less than 30 mm Hg (Statement 1), immediate compartment decompression by fasciotomy is indicated.

Treatment includes prompt decompression of the affected compartment is done. Fasciotomy is done if the differential pressure is less than 30 mm Hg. The incision for a fasciotomy involves the skin, subcutaneous tissue, superficial fascia, and deep fascia (Statement 2). Fasciotomy wounds are left open and after 2 days if there is necrosis debridement is done. If the wounds are healthy they can be sutured without tension or skin grafting can be done.

Related Pearl: Acute Compartment and Crush Syndromes

1. Acute Compartment Syndrome

Acute compartment syndrome is an elevation of the intracompartmental pressure (ICP) which increases the risk for tissue ischemia and necrosis.

Causes: Fractures (70%) and severe soft tissue injuries (30%). Common fractures causing compartment syndrome include tibial diaphyseal (most common), distal radius, and forearm fractures. 

Pathology: Increased pressure in one of the osseofascial compartments due to bleeding, oedema or inflammation. A vicious cycle of ischemia → edema→ ischemia leading to necrosis of the muscles and nerves within the compartment in 6 hours or less. 

Clinical features: Five Ps: Pain, Paraesthesia, Pallor, Paralysis and Pulselessness. 

Management: Fasciotomy to decompress the threatened compartment if the differential pressure (ΔP) goes less than or equal to 30 mmHg. 

 

2. Crush Syndrome 

Crush syndrome is the systemic manifestation of muscle necrosis. It is commonly caused due to prolonged external compression of an extremity. 

Causes: Crush injuries sustained during motor vehicle accidents, earthquakes, mining and other occupational accidents.

Pathology: Underperfusion of muscle causes myonecrosis. When the limb is freed, there is a release of toxic metabolites causing reperfusion injury. Reactive oxygen metabolites create further tissue injury. Free myoglobin can get precipitated in the renal glomeruli. 

Clinical features: The affected limb is pulseless, red, swollen and blistered. Sensation and muscle power may be lost. There can be signs of impaired renal function, metabolic acidosis, hyperkalemia and hypocalcaemia.

Management: Encouraging high urine output, alkalization of the urine, hemofiltration, radical excision of dead muscles, fasciotomy if there is compartment syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following is an absolute contraindication of fibrinolytic therapy for the management of myocardial ischemia?
questions.solution:
The absolute contraindication of fibrinolytic therapy is suspicion of aortic dissection.

Clear contraindications to the use of fibrinolytic agents:

  • History of cerebrovascular hemorrhage at any time
  • Non-hemorrhagic stroke or any other cerebrovascular event within the past year
  • Marked hypertension (systolic arterial pressure >180 mmHg and/or a diastolic pressure >110 mmHg)
  • Suspicion of aortic dissection, and active internal bleeding (excluding menses).  

Relative contraindications to fibrinolytic therapy, which require the assessment of the risk-to-benefit ratio:

  • Current use of anti-coagulants (international normalized ratio ≥2)
  • Recent (<2 weeks) invasive or surgical procedure or prolonged (>10 min) cardiopulmonary resuscitation
  • Known bleeding diathesis
  • Pregnancy
  • Hemorrhagic ophthalmic condition (e.g., hemorrhagic diabetic retinopathy),
  • Active peptic ulcer disease
  • History of severe hypertension that is currently adequately controlled.

Related Pearl: Plasminogen activators (classification of fibrinolytics)

Fibrin non-specific plasminogen activators

  • Streptokinase - least fibrin specific and has the lowest incidence of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Anistreplase
  • Urokinase

Fibrin specific plasminogen activators

  • Alteplase - has the shortest half-life
  • Tenecteplase - most fibrin specific and given as a single bolus dose
  • Reteplase

questions.text: A 20-year-old college student complains of an irresistible urge to move his legs, especially during his sleep. He is feeling comfortable only after doing so. He is also experiencing burning, itching, and cramp-like sensation in his legs. What is the next best step in his management?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is indicative of a diagnosis of restless leg syndrome. The first step following the diagnosis of restless leg syndrome is to check serum ferritin levels.

Restless legs syndrome (RLS) is an irresistible urge to move the legs when at rest or while trying to fall asleep or an uncomfortable sensation of creeping-crawling feeling. It is worse at night and moving legs or walking reduces discomfort. Uremia, neuropathies, as well as iron-deficiency and folic acid–deficiency anemias can produce secondary RLS.

In patients with restless legs syndrome, iron stores are initially repleted, and the aggravating factors are eliminated. If RLS still persists, initial therapy with a gabapentinoid (pregabalin, gabapentin, gabapentin enacarbil) is preferred, rather than a dopamine agonist (pramipexole, ropinirole, rotigotine). This is due to the high frequency of intermediate and long-term augmentation with dopamine agonists, as well as their risk of impulse control disorders.

FDA-approved drugs for the treatment of restless leg syndrome: 

  • Gabapentin
  • Ropinirole
  • Pramipexole
  • Rotigotine 

A dopamine agonist is used as an alternative in patients with increased risk for side effects from gabapentinoids, such as those with obesity and its complications, a past or present history of moderate to severe depression, a disorder causing gait instability or respiratory failure, and a history of substance use disorder.

Propranolol is the treatment of choice for essential tremors, and an EEG is not needed to make a diagnosis of RLS.

questions.text:
Identify the true statements about the device shown in the image when compared to endotracheal intubation.

A. Increased risk of gastric aspiration

B. More secure airway

C. Requires muscle relaxants

D. Does not require neck mobility

E. Less invasive
questions.solution:
The given image shows a laryngeal mask airway (LMA), which is indicated in cases with difficult airways. LMA is a less secure airway when compared to endotracheal intubation and it does not require muscle relaxants.

LMA is used for airway management as a temporary, life-saving measure in patients with difficult ventilation. Difficult ventilation can be either due to difficult airways, unavailability, or difficulty in mask ventilation and intubation.

Advantages of LMA:

  • Less invasive as compared to tracheal tubes.
  • Lesser bronchospasm as compared to tracheal tubes 
  • It partially protects the larynx from pharyngeal secretions.
  • Useful in difficult intubations
  • Less trauma to teeth and pharynx
  • Muscle relaxation is not required
  • Neck mobility is not required 

Disadvantages:

  • Increased risk of gastrointestinal aspiration
  • Less safe in prone or jack-knife positions
  • Less secure airway
  • Greater risk of a gas leak and pollution

Related Pearl: Indications and contraindications of Laryngeal mask airway (LMA)

Indication:

  • Difficult airway management during cardiopulmonary resuscitation.
  • In emergency where intubation & mask ventilation is not possible. 
  • For minor surgeries, where Anesthetist wants to avoid intubation. 
  • As a conduit for bronchoscopes, small size tubes, gum elastic bougies.

Contraindications:

  • Oropharyngeal abscess or mass
  • Poor mouth opening 
  • Conditions with high risk of aspiration:
    • Hiatus hernia
    • Pregnancy
    • Full stomach patients who are vulnerable to go in bronchospasm
    • Low pulmonary compliance (eg. Obesity)
    • Peak inspiratory pressure > 30 cm of H2O.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency room following blunt abdominal trauma. On examination, he was hemodynamically stable. Contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) showed splenic trauma with a subcapsular hematoma over 30% of the surface area with ongoing hemorrhage. Angiography and embolization were done but failed to achieve hemostasis. Which of the following is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The next step in management is splenorrhaphy. 

The non-expanding subcapsular hematoma over 30% of the surface area is suggestive of grade II splenic injury. These patients are managed by angiography and embolization, and if it fails, the next step in management is a spleen-saving technique or splenorrhaphy.

Splenorrhaphy is a procedure done to preserve the spleen parenchyma. These involve all the surgical procedures done to save the spleen parenchyma while splenectomy is the entire surgical removal of the viscera. Splenorrhaphy should not be performed if the patient is unstable if there are multiple injuries or extensive splenic injury. 

Grades of splenic injury:

Grade Injury
I Non-expanding subcapsular hematoma (<10% of surface area) or laceration, <1 cm of parenchymal depth
II Non-expanding subcapsular hematoma (10-50% of surface area) or laceration, 1-3 cm of parenchymal depth which does not involve the trabecular vessels
III

Hematoma > 50% of surface area or expanding

  • Ruptured subcapsular or parenchymal hematoma,
  • Intraparenchymal hematoma >5 cm or expanding Or
    Laceration, >3 cm parenchymal depth or involving
    trabecular vessels
IV Laceration involving segmental or hilar vessels leading to major devascularization (>25% of the spleen)
V Shattered spleen
or
A hilar vascular injury that devascularizes the spleen.

Management of splenic trauma:

Grade I and II injuries:

They are usually hemodynamically stable and are managed non-operatively. Initially, these patients are managed conservatively with regular monitoring of vitals, hematocrit, and serial CECT.

If the grade of injury is found to increase, then angiography and embolization of the bleeding vessel are done to achieve hemostasis. If angiography and embolization fail to achieve hemostasis, or if the patient becomes hemodynamically unstable, then a splenorrhaphy is done.

Grade III injuries that are hemodynamically stable are managed like that of grades I and II, while those that are hemodynamically unstable are managed like that of grades IV and V.

Grade IV and V injuries patients are usually hemodynamically unstable and splenectomy is done.

Other options: 

Option A: Repeat angiography and embolization are unlikely to help as it has already failed once in this patient. 

Option B: Conservative management will not stop the ongoing hemorrhage that is present in this patient. It is useful in patients who are no longer bleeding. 

Option C: Splenectomy is not required in this patient as they have a grade II injury and are still hemodynamically stable.

Related Pearl: American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) Spleen Injury Scale

Related Pearl: Indications for Selective Non-Operative Management (SNOM) in splenic trauma

Indications :

  • Patient younger than 55 years
  • Grade I, II, or III (in selective cases) splenic injury
  • Physiologic stability, as indicated by normal blood pressure, lack of tachycardia, absence of physical examination findings indicating shock, and absence of metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: A 67-year-old male patient with a history of smoking presented with a painless palpable mass in the parotid region. The biopsy of the mass is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical presentation and histopathological slide showing epithelial elements with lymphoid infiltration are suggestive of a Warthin tumor (papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum) of the parotid gland.

Warthin tumor is the second most common salivary gland neoplasm. It is seen in elderly male smokers. It is a benign, well-encapsulated cystic tumor.

The gross appearance of these tumors shows round to oval encapsulated masses, easily palpable in the superficial parotid. Transection reveals a pale grey surface punctuated by cleft-like spaces filled with mucinous or serous secretions.

Histologically, the tumor shows epithelial and lymphoid elements. The epithelium typically consists of a double layer of oncocytic epithelial cells, with an inner columnar layer and an outer cuboidal layer.

Other options:

Option A: Adenoid cystic carcinoma is poorly encapsulated infiltrative carcinoma involving minor salivary glands, commonly the palatine glands. Histology shows tumor cells, organized in a cribriform growth pattern, resembling swiss cheese. The image is shown below.

Option C: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is the most common primary malignant tumor of the salivary gland, commonly affecting the parotid gland. Many are associated with a balanced (11;19) (q21;p13) chromosomal translocation. Histology shows mucinous, intermediate, and squamous elements, with small to large mucus-filled vacuoles. Image is shown below.

Option D: Pleomorphic adenomas are the most common salivary gland neoplasms. The parotid gland is most commonly involved. They are benign tumors that consist of a mixture of ductal (epithelial), myoepithelial, and mesenchymal cells. Image is shown below.

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: An intern, while calculating Bishop score, gives a score of 2 for the position of the cervix. Which of the following inferences can you draw regarding the position of the cervix from this?
questions.solution:
The position of the cervix in the given scenario is anterior.

The modified Bishop score is a pre-induction cervical scoring system used to predict the success of induction of labor where a score >8 conveys a high likelihood for successful induction, and a score ≤6 is considered unfavorable. It is based on the station of the head, dilation, length, position, and consistency of the cervix noted by doing a vaginal examination.

The cervical position reflects the relationship of the cervical os to the center point of the presenting part. It is categorized as posterior, mid-position, or anterior. Fetal descent will gradually move the cervix anteriorly. The initial posterior position is given a score of 0. As the labor progresses and the cervix comes to midline it is scored as 1. Finally, when the cervix is in the anterior position, it is scored as 2.

 

Related Pearl: Bishop’s Score (Modified)

Cervical length (cm) >4 2-4 1-2 <1
Consistency Firm Medium Soft -

Total score = 13

Favourable= 6-13

Unfavourable= 0-5

Note: 

  • According to NICE guidelines, a score of 6-13 is favorable for induction of labour.
  • According to Williams Obstetrics (26th edition), a score of 9 or more indicates a high likelihood of successful induction.

questions.text: A screening test was carried out in a population of 120 persons, of which 20 had the disease. The screening test result was positive for 20 people, of which 15 had the disease. What is the specificity of the test?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the specificity of the test is 95%

  Disease + Disease - Total
Test + 15 (True Positives) 5 (False Positives) 20
Test - 5 (False negatives) 95 (True Negatives) 100
Total 20 100 120

Positive results:

  • Out of the 20 positive results, 15 had the disease
  • So, the number of true positives = 15
  • The remaining 5 people are false positives because they had positive results but did not have the disease

Negative results:

  • The population who got negative results = 120-20 = 100
  • Out of the 100 people with negative results, 5 are false negatives. This is because out of the 20 people who had the disease, 15 had positive results, and the remaining 5 had negative results despite having the disease (i.e. false negatives).
  • So, the remaining 95 (100-5) are true negatives.

The specificity of a test is given as follows:

True negatives (TN) / False positives (FP) + True Negatives (TN) × 100

= 95/5+95 × 100

= 95/100 × 100

= 0.95 × 100

Specificity = 95%

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: A post-menopausal woman presents with a history of pain over the wrist after falling down the stairs. Diagnosis of Colles' fracture is confirmed. Which of the following statements is not true regarding the management of such fractures?

choices.text: Colles' cast is applied in palmar flexion and ulnar deviation.
For displaced fractures, management comprises closed manipulative reduction and immobilization in Colles' cast.
For undisplaced fractures, management comprises immobilization in an above-elbow plaster cast for 6 weeks.
Sonographically guided closed reduction is the newer modality of treatment.

questions.solution:
In undisplaced Colles' fracture, a below-elbow cast is applied.

Management of Colles' fracture:

  • Undisplaced fractures: Immobilization in a below-elbow plaster cast for 6 weeks
  • Displaced fractures: Closed manipulative reduction and immobilization in Colles' cast. The technique of reduction of Colles' fracture is as follows:
    • Disimpaction of the fracture fragments by longitudinal traction against counter traction provided by the assistant. 
    • The distal fragment is then pressed into palmar flexion followed by ulnar deviation.
    • The patient's hand is drawn into pronation, palmar flexion, and ulnar deviation.
    • A Colles' cast is then applied, extending from below the elbow to the metacarpal heads, with the wrist in palmar flexion and ulnar deviation. 
    • Surgical correction is advisable for comminuted fractures, especially in young adults where the dominant hand is involved. It can be with percutaneous K-wire fixation, external fixators, or locking compression plates.

Colles' cast is applied on a hand that is pronated, in palmar flexion, and ulnar deviation as shown:

questions.text: Which of the following diseases occurs as a consequence of genomic imprinting?
questions.solution:
The phenomenon of a differential effect of the same gene from different parents is called genomic imprinting. Prader-Willi syndrome occurs as a result of genomic imprinting.

Genomic imprinting refers to gene silencing/ inactivation. Here either the maternal or the paternal allele is inactivated resulting in only one functional allele. It occurs via the process of epigenetics, where gene expression is lowered by:

  • DNA methylation
  • Histone deacetylation

Genomic imprinting is best illustrated by two uncommon genetic disorders: Prader-Willi syndrome and Angelman syndrome.

questions.text: A 3-years-old child presented with chronic itchy plaques over the neck and bilaterally over the popliteal and cubital fossae, as shown in the image; the itching is aggravated by sweating. On examination, white dermatographism can be elicited. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of chronic itchy plaques over the neck and bilaterally over the popliteal and cubital fossae suggests the diagnosis of atopic dermatitis.

Atopic dermatitis is the cutaneous expression of the atopic state, characterized by a family history of asthma, allergic rhinitis, or eczema. The epidermal barrier is impaired due to a mutation in the gene encoding filaggrin (a structural protein in the stratum corneum).

In infants, it presents as erythema and edematous papule in the face and extensor aspect of the knees and elbows. The papules are intensely itchy and may become exudative and crusted as a result of rubbing.

The site of lesions shifts to elbow and knee flexures when the child is 18 months to 2 years. There is also a mixture of erythema, crusting, excoriation, hyper- and hypopigmentation, and warty lichenification seen on the sides of the neck, wrists, and ankles. Blanching of the skin occurring at the site of stroking or scratching, which is called white dermatographism, is also seen.

Other features of atopic dermatitis include xerosis (dry skin), ichthyosis (fish-like scaly skin), and headlight sign (facial eczema sparing periorbital, perinasal, and perioral area).

Other options:

B) Dermatitis herpetiformis is a chronic, intensely pruritic, skin condition associated with gluten‐sensitive enteropathy. Multiple erythematous papules and vesicles can be seen over the extensor aspects like elbows, knees, buttocks, and scalp. They appear symmetrical and heal without scarring. The oral cavity may show mucosal abnormalities and enamel pits.

The image below shows dermatitis herpetiformis on the knee.

C) Pemphigus vegetans is a rare form of bullous disorder that presents as bullae that become erosions and form fungating vegetation on the scalp or flexural fold.

D) Psoriasis present with itching and a papulosquamous rash commonly on the scalp, trunk, and extensor surfaces of the limbs. The lesions are red, scaly, and have well demarcation from the normal skin. They can also be encircled by a clear peripheral zone called the Woronoff ring.

Related Pearl: UK refinement of Hanifin & Rajka’s diagnostic criteria of atopic dermatitis (eczema)

In order to qualify as a case of atopic dermatitis (eczema) with the UK  diagnostic criteria, the child must have an itchy skin condition (or parental report of scratching or rubbing in a child).

Plus three or more of the following:

  • Onset below age of 2 years (not used if child is under 4 years)
  • History of skin crease involvement (including cheeks in children under 10 years)
  • History of a generally dry skin
  • Personal history of other atopic disease (or history of any atopic disease in a first-degree relative in children under 4 years)
  • Visible flexural dermatitis (or dermatitis of cheeks/forehead and outer limbs in children under 4 years)

questions.text:
Sequentially arrange the following steps to be followed in breaking bad news according to the accepted standard protocol.

A. Giving knowledge and information to the patient 

B. Setting up the interview

C. Addressing the patient’s emotions with empathic responses

D. Assessing the patient’s perception
questions.solution:
According to the SPIKES protocol for breaking bad news, the correct sequence of steps to follow is given by Option 4.

  1. S - Setting up the interview
  2. P - Assessing the patient’s perception
  3. I - Obtaining the patient’s invitation
  4. K - Giving knowledge and information to the patient
  5. E - Addressing the patient’s emotions with empathic responses
  6. S - Strategy, and summary

Key components of the SPIKES strategy:

  • Demonstrating empathy
  • Acknowledging and validating the patient's feelings
  • Exploring the patient's understanding and acceptance of the bad news
  • Providing information about possible interventions

questions.text: All of the following can be used in second-trimester medical termination of pregnancy (MTP), except
questions.solution:
Electric vacuum aspiration cannot be used in the second trimester of medical termination of pregnancy(MTP).

Suction and evacuation is a procedure best suited for first-trimester MTP. Here the products of conception are sucked out from the uterus by a cannula fitted to the suction apparatus. It is not used after 10 weeks because of increased risks of retained products and hemorrhage.

Medical methods of second-trimester abortion include mifepristone, mifepristone and misoprostol, dinoprostone, and concentrated oxytocin.

Surgical methods of second-trimester abortion are:

  • Dilatation and evacuation- Pregnancies at 13–14 menstrual weeks are evacuated through this procedure.
  • Intrauterine instillation of hyperosmotic solutions- Pregnancies at 16-20 menstrual weeks are evacuated through this procedure. Hyperosmotic solutions can be:
    • Extra-amniotic—ethacridine lactate, prostaglandins (PGE2, PGF2a), extra-amniotic saline infusion (isotonic) with a transcervical catheter balloon
    • Intra-amniotic hypertonic urea (30%), saline (20%)

Related Pearl: Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act - MTP Act 1971

MTP Act with 2021 amendments 

Indications:

  • Therapeutic - to save the life of the mother
  • Eugenic - to prevent the risk of the child being born with serious mental or physical abnormality i.e. first-trimester viral infections, teratogenic drug intake, radiation exposure
  • Humanitarian - pregnancy resulted from rape or incest
  • Social - pregnancy resulted from failure of contraceptives 

Rules:

  • Only a registered medical practitioner who is qualified (one who has assisted in the performance of 25 cases of MTP in a recognized hospital) can terminate a pregnancy.
  • MTP should be carried out in a government or government-recognized hospital. Private hospitals may take up MTP if they obtain a license from the chief medical officer of the district.
  • The termination of pregnancy by a person, who is not a registered medical practitioner (the person concerned), or in an unrecognised hospital (administrative head) shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term not less than 2 years, but which may extend to 7 years. 

Consent:

The consent of the woman is required for conducting an abortion. The written consent of the guardian is required if the woman is minor or mentally ill. Consent of the husband or partner is not necessary. 

If the woman is not willing, abortion cannot be performed at the request of the husband alone. The woman need not produce proof of her age. It is enough for the woman to say that she was raped, and it is not necessary that a complaint was lodged with the police.

Opinion of doctors:

  • Till 20 weeks - 1 doctor's opinion
  • 20 to 24 weeks - 2 doctors' opinion
  • For substantial fetal anomalies - approval from the medical board consisting of obstetrician, paediatrician, radiologist and a person appointed by the state

Upper limit of MTP:

  • Up to 24 weeks of gestation in victims of rape and incest, fetal anomalies, or congenital malformations
  • Up to 20 weeks in case of contraception failure (any female with her partner)
  • At any gestational age for substantial fetal anomalies decided by the medical board

Confidentiality:

A register for recording the details of MTP must be kept for at least 5 years. The patient's name must not be entered, only the reference number is used. Unlawful disclosure of patient's details is punishable with 1-year imprisonment ± fine.

questions.text: Which of the following lobes of the lung is affected when aspiration occurs in the prone position?

choices.text: Upper part of right inferior lobe

questions.solution:
The right upper lobe is prone to aspiration in the prone position. It is commonly seen in those with alcohol use disorder.

The location of aspiration depends on the position of the patient since it is gravity-dependent. Commonly the lower lobes are involved when aspiration occurs in an upright position, and superior lobes can be involved in the recumbent position. Aspiration while standing may lead to infiltration of bilateral inferior lobes because of larger and more vertical corresponding bronchi, the middle lobes, and the lingula. 

Aspiration of contents into foreign substances into the bronchial tree, usually oral or gastric contents, produces aspiration pneumonia. Chemical (gastric acid) injury or bacterial infection complicates the condition.

questions.text: A 36-year-old nulliparous woman presents with menorrhagia for 3 months. The first day of her last menstrual period (LMP) was 3 weeks ago. She undergoes a Pap smear which shows atypical glandular cells of unknown significance. How would you proceed with further management?

choices.text: Schedule an endometrial and cervical sampling

questions.solution:
The pap smear shows atypical glandular cells in a woman aged ≥35 years should proceed with an endometrial and cervical sampling.

Atypical glandular cells on a Pap smear usually signify underlying cervical or endometrial neoplasia. The glandular abnormality is evaluated by doing a colposcopy and endocervical curettage. Endometrial biopsy is also needed in the following cases to be certain that the endometrial cells originated in the endometrium:

  • Female patients ≥ 35 years.
  • Female patients < 35 years, and a risk factor for endometrial diseases like abnormal uterine bleeding(AUB) or anovulation.

Other options:

Options A & D: Since the atypical glandular cells are seen on a pap smear, we need to sample the endometrium and cervix to see from where the cells have originated. Colposcopy will help in locating abnormal areas and accurately obtaining a directed biopsy from the suspicious areas on the cervix. Hence, only an endometrial biopsy or only colposcopy(Option D) is not sufficient.

Option B: Loop electrosurgical excision procedure is an acceptable option for patients who have moderately severe to severe dysplasias. As the pap smear shows atypical glandular cells, colposcopy with endocervical curettage and endometrial sampling is required before an excisional procedure is considered.

questions.text: What is the pathological mechanism responsible for the RBC shape shown in this peripheral smear?

choices.text: Mutations in genes encoding for ankyrin, spectrin, and band proteins
Acquired mutation in the PIGA gene
Point mutation in the beta-globin gene

questions.solution:
The peripheral smear shows bite cells or degmacytes, characteristically associated with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency (G6PD deficiency), an X-linked recessive condition.

Reduced glutathione is required to protect the cells against oxidant injury. This glutathione is kept in a reduced state by NADPH. Glucose 6 phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) is required to generate NADPH while oxidizing glucose-6-phosphate. G6PD deficiency results in reduced levels of NADPH which subsequently reduces the level of reduced glutathione. Therefore, in conditions like infections, which increase the production of oxygen free radicals, the red blood cells are damaged. 

Other triggers that lead to oxidative stress are drugs like sulphonamides, antimalarials, and fava beans.

Increased oxidative damage to RBCs leads to the formation of denatured precipitates known as Heinz bodies. These bodies can damage the RBC membrane leading to intravascular hemolysis. Additionally, when such RBCs pass through the splenic cords, macrophages pluck out these precipitates, giving them the characteristic appearance of bite cells. 

Other features of the peripheral smear include anisocytes, polychromatic cells, and poikilocytes with unevenly distributed hemoglobin (hemighosts). 

Other options:

Option A: Mutations in the genes coding for ankyrin, spectrin, and band proteins are responsible for hereditary spherocytosis (HS). It is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by poor interaction between the mutated RBC membrane proteins. This leads to the loss of membrane fragments relative to the cytoplasm, thereby causing the RBC to assume the least possible diameter for a given volume. Peripheral smear shows characteristic spherocytes that appear dark, with no central pallor. Howell- Jolly bodies can also be seen.

A slide showing spherocytes in peripheral smear:

 

Option B: Acquired mutation of PIGA gene is responsible for paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH). This condition causes complement-mediated destruction of RBCs due to the absence/ impaired production of membrane-associated complement regulatory proteins CD59 and CD55. PNH is characterized by a triad of hemolysis, pancytopenia, and venous thrombosis. The peripheral smear reveals RBCs that are usually normo-macrocytic but may become microcytic due to chronic iron loss through hemoglobinuria. 

Option C: Point mutation in the beta-globin gene is responsible for sickle cell anemia. This autosomal recessive disorder is characterized by the polymerization of the abnormal HbS hemoglobin during conditions of low oxygen tension (acidosis, hypoxia) which leads to sickling of the red blood cell, hemolysis, and microvascular obstruction (may lead to vaso-occlusive crises and autosplenectomy). Peripheral smear findings reveal sickled RBCs, reticulocytosis, and Howell-Jolly bodies (small nuclear remnants in RBCs that are usually removed by a functional spleen). 

A slide showing sickled RBCs in a peripheral smear:

questions.text:
A 25-year-old female patient with a history of epilepsy presented with a seizure episode lasting 30 minutes. The seizure activity was resolved after appropriate therapy was given. The patient complained of muscle pain, and investigations showed the following. What is the next best step in management?
Creatine kinase Markedly increased
Phosphate Increased
Calcium Decreased
Uric acid Elevated
questions.solution:
The given scenario suggests prolonged seizure leading to rhabdomyolysis and acute kidney injury. The next best step in management is volume replacement. He may require up to 10 L of fluid per day.

Rhabdomyolysis occurred in this patient as a result of prolonged seizure activity causing muscle injury and lysis. As a result, the myoglobin released precipitates in the renal tubules resulting in endogenous kidney injury. Aggressive hydration will prevent further tubular injury.

Once the fluid replacement is adequate, diuretics may be administered if the patient has a urinary flow rate of less than 200-300 ml/hour.

Alkaline fluids like sodium bicarbonate in half-normal saline can help prevent injury to renal tubules. However, it may worsen hypocalcemia. Thus, sodium bicarbonate should only be given in patients who do not have hypocalcemia, whose arterial pH is less than 7.5, and serum bicarbonate is less than 30 mEq/L. 

The focus of acute kidney injury management in the setting of rhabdomyolysis is to maintain fluid and electrolyte status in order to maintain tissue perfusion. 

Other options: 

Option A - Diuretic therapy can be used after adequate volume resuscitation has been administered if the urine output is not satisfactory. However, they should not be used as initial treatment as it can worsen acute kidney injury. 

Option C - Hemodialysis can be used in severe cases of rhabdomyolysis to correct electrolyte imbalances but is not the first-line treatment. 

Option D - Rhabdomyolysis is associated with marked hyperphosphatemia and hypocalcemia. The electrolyte levels should be monitored closely during treatment but they are not the primary focus.

questions.text:
Match the following drugs with the targets of their actions.
1. Rituximab A. HER2
2. Ipilimumab

B. CTLA-4
3. Trastuzumab C. PD-1
4. Pembrolizumab D. CD20
questions.solution:
The correct pairs are 1-D, 2-B, 3-A, 4-C.

1. Rituximab D. CD20
2. Ipilimumab B. CTLA-4
3. Trastuzumab A. HER2
4. Pembrolizumab C. PD-1

Rituximab is a chimeric murine/human monoclonal IgG1 antibody that acts against CD20 B­-cell surface antigen. It is approved as a single agent for relapsed indolent lymphomas and significantly enhances response and survival when used in combination with chemotherapy for the initial treatment of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma.

Ipilimumab is a fully humanised IgG1 monoclonal antibody that inhibits cytotoxic T lymphocyte-Associated Protein-4 (CTLA-4). It is approved for the treatment of late-stage melanoma.

Trastuzumab is a humanised IgG1 monoclonal antibody that blocks the extracellular domain IV of HER2 (human epidermal growth factor receptor 2). It is approved for HER2-overexpressing breast and gastric cancer. 

Pembrolizumab acts by inhibiting PD-1 (programmed cell death protein 1) and was used for the treatment of advanced melanoma. Now, the FDA has approved the use of pembrolizumab for any cancer with mismatch repair (MMR) deficiency or high microsatellite instability (MSI-H).

questions.text: What is the type of scoliosis shown in the X-ray given below?
questions.solution:
In the given radiograph, the presence of a single hemivertebra at T9 and concavity to the right in the lower thoracic region is suggestive of congenital scoliosis.

Congenital scoliosis is a lateral curvature of the spine which is always associated with a radiologically demonstrable anomaly of the vertebral bodies, which includes:

  • Hemivertebrae (where only one-half of the vertebra grows) 
  • Block vertebrae (where two vertebral bodies fuse)
  • An unsegmented bar (a bone bar joining two adjacent vertebrae on one side, which hinders growth on that side)

The image below shows a unilateral and unsegmented bar with contralateral hemivertebra: 

In infantile scoliosis (option C), most curves are thoracic with convexity to the left and the anomalies described above are absent. 

Note: The most progressive type of congenital scoliosis is a concave, unilateral unsegmented bar with a convex hemivertebra.

questions.text: A kid slips and falls while walking and hurts his head in the process. His mother starts rubbing the area of his skin where he suffered the injury. Activation of which of the following types of nerve fibers near the site of injury is achieved by the mother's actions?
questions.solution:
The mother rubbing the area of his skin where he suffered the injury is based on the gate control theory of pain. The tactile stimulus of touch or pressure activate Aα and Aβ fibers near the injury to relieve pain.

Gate control theory is based on the inhibition of the pain pathways in the spinal cord. Various sensory inputs from a particular dermatome reach the dorsal horn of the spinal cord. The pain is transmitted via A-delta and C fibers, whereas, A-beta fibers carry tactile sensations (touch, pressure) and A-alpha fibers carry proprioception.

When these large-diameter A-beta/A-alpha fibers are stimulated, they inhibit the pain pathway in the spinal cord. This inhibition is thought to result from the local lateral inhibition of interneurons in the spinal cord.

Gate control theory operates at the substantia gelatinosa of the dorsal horn of the spinal cord.

The gate control theory is used in transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) for pain relief and is the basis for liniments. This mechanism along with psychogenic excitation of the central analgesia system explains pain relief by acupuncture.

The sphenopalatine foramen serves as a gateway between the pterygopalatine fossa and the nasal cavity. It transmits the following structures from the pterygopalatine fossa to the nasal cavity

  • Sphenopalatine artery
  • Nasopalatine nerve
  • Posterior superior nasal nerves (lateral and medial)

As it transmits the sphenopalatine artery, it is the common site of the origin of the nasal angiofibroma.

questions.text: A 1-year-old child has circumferential burns involving both buttocks and both thighs, as well as the face, including the scalp, with singeing of hair. Calculate the approximate percentage of the area involved according to Lund and Browder's chart.
questions.solution:
The approximate percentage of the area involved is 37%.

The age of the child is 1 year and the percentage of burns can be calculated using Lund and Browder’s Chart (which is given below).

  • Head (Face and scalp) → (a-anterior half)8.5 + (a-posterior half)8.5= 17
  • Both thighs circumferentially → (b-left front thigh)3.25 + (b-left back thigh)3.25 + (b-right front thigh)3.25 + (b-right back thigh)3.25 = 13
  • Both buttocks → 2.5 + 2.5 = 5

Total percentage = 17+13+5 = 35%. The closest answer is 37%.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy was brought with complaints of repeatedly twitching his mouth, raising his eyebrows, and grunting since he was 6 years old. There is a new-onset habit of throat clearing multiple times a day. Which of the following is associated with the child's condition?
questions.solution:
The child has symptoms of Tourette's syndrome, which is associated with obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD).

Tourette's syndrome is a neurobehavioral disorder characterized by sudden, rapid, recurrent, non-rhythmic motor movements and vocalizations, called tics.  Vocal tics can be socially offensive, such as loud grunting, barking noises, or shouted words. Coprolalia may be seen, which refers to shouting or speaking socially unacceptable or obscene words.

Over half of the children diagnosed with Tourette's syndrome also meet the criteria for OCD and attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).

The DSM-V criteria for the diagnosis of Tourette syndrome include:

  • Presence of both multiple motor and one or more vocal tics, at some time during the illness. Although both need not occur simultaneously.
  • The tics may wax and wane in frequency but have persisted for more than 1 year since the onset of the first tic.
  • Onset is before the age of 18 years.
  • The disorder is not attributable to the physiological effects of substance abuse (e.g. cocaine) or underlying medical condition (e.g., Huntington’s disease, postviral encephalitis). 

Behavioral interventions like habit reversal, comprehensive behavioral intervention, and exposure and response prevention are the first line of treatment where the academic performance or social life is not affected.

Pharmacotherapy must be included in severe cases when they cause social and emotional problems, depression, or isolation. 
First-line agents are antipsychotics like aripiprazole or noradrenergic agents like atomoxetine, clonidine, and guanfacine can be used as adjunctive for comorbid ADHD. Alternative treatments are tetrabenazine, topiramate, and tetrahydrocannabinol

questions.text: The following statement is correct regarding Mullerian agenesis, except:

choices.text: The condition should be evaluated for congenital renal or skeletal anomalies.
Pregnancy can be achieved using oocyte retrieval.
Associated with skeletal malformations such as spina bifida, sacralization

questions.solution:
All are correct statements regarding Mullerian agenesis except option D. Typically normal ovaries are present in this condition hence this statement is wrong.

Congenital absence of both the uterus and vagina is termed Mullerian agenesis or Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome.
In classic Mullerian agenesis, patients have a shallow vaginal pouch(1 to 2 inches deep). The uterus, cervix, and upper part of the vagina are absent. Typically, normal ovaries persist, as they originate from the genital ridge. Individual presents with primary amenorrhea, have a normal female appearance, secondary sexual characteristics, and 46 XX karyotype. Most patients with Mullerian agenesis have only small rudimentary mullerian bulbs without endometrial activity. 

With mullerian agenesis, traditional conception is not possible, but pregnancy may be achieved using oocyte retrieval, fertilization, and gestational surrogacy.

Individuals with Mullerian agenesis or hypoplasia have associated congenital renal or skeletal anomalies. Common renal anomalies include ectopic- horseshoe or pelvic kidney and collecting system anomalies. Skeletal malformations include spina bifida, sacralization (partial fusion of L5 to the sacrum), sacral bone lumbarization (nonfusion of the first and second sacral segments), and cervical vertebral anomalies.

questions.text: The image shown below represents a side effect of drug X in a fetus if used by the mother during pregnancy. Which of the following options is false regarding it?

choices.text: Agranulocytosis is a rare but serious side effect.
Blocks thyroid peroxidase but not peripheral conversion of T4 to T3.
It is only contraindicated in first trimester of pregnancy.

questions.solution:
The given image shows aplasia cutis congenita of the newborn depicting the absence of scalp hair and skin along with calvarial defects. This is commonly associated with methimazole when used in pregnancy. It is used to treat Graves' ophthalmopathy is a false statement.

Ophthalmopathy requires no active treatment when it is mild or moderate because there is usually spontaneous improvement. General measures include meticulous control of thyroid hormone levels and cessation of smoking. Severe ophthalmopathy, with optic nerve involvement or corneal damage, is an emergency and may be treated with IV methylprednisolone. 

Methimazole is an anti-thyroid drug that belongs to the group of thioamides. It acts to prevent hormone synthesis by inhibiting the thyroid peroxidase-catalyzed reactions - iodine organification and coupling of iodotyrosine residues. It does not inhibit the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 (Option C). It is the drug of choice for Grave's disease.

Methimazole crosses the placenta to a greater degree than propylthiouracil. It is usually avoided in the first trimester due to methimazole-associated embryopathy including fetal aplasia cutis. Thus, when available, propylthiouracil should be used in the first trimester. Methimazole is used for the remainder of the pregnancy due to the concern for propylthiouracil-associated liver failure in pregnancy. (Option D)

Agranulocytosis is the most serious side effect of propylthiouracil and methimazole though the incidence is low. Development of sore throat or fever should be reported, the antithyroid drug should be discontinued, and an urgent complete blood count is obtained to confirm the presence of agranulocytosis. (Option A)

questions.text:
Choose the correct option regarding the given two statements about congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection.

Statement A: The rate of transmission of CMV following primary maternal infection is greater than that following non-primary infection.

Statement B: Infants with congenital CMV infection due to non-primary maternal infection outnumber those with congenital CMV infection due to primary maternal infection.

choices.text: Statement A is true, Statement B is false.
Statement B is true, Statement A is false.

questions.solution:
Both statements A and B regarding CMV are true.

The rate of transmission of infection to the fetus in a mother who has a primary infection is about 30%, while in a mother with a nonprimary infection, it is 1-2%. Thus, Statement A is true.

However, in most populations, the total number of infants who have acquired an infection from a mother with nonprimary infection is 3-4 times more than infants who have acquired an infection from mothers with primary infection. Thus, Statement B is true.

Congenital infection with CMV is mostly asymptomatic, and symptomatic infections can occur in about 10% of newborns. Neonates who are asymptomatic at birth have a lesser risk of late sequelae.

The clinical manifestations are hepatosplenomegaly, petechial rashes, jaundice, chorioretinitis, and microcephaly. They can also develop hemorrhagic purpuric eruptions due to dermal erythropoiesis giving the appearance of a blueberry muffin baby. One of the long-term sequelae is sensorineural hearing loss. 

There is no definitive treatment for congenital CMV infection. Treatment with oral ganciclovir for 6 months could reduce the extent of hearing loss. Oral valganciclovir can also be used. Regular follow-ups should be done, particularly hearing screening tests.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old female patient presented with a 2-cm thyroid nodule. The results of thyroid function tests are within normal limits. FNAC of the nodule was done, and the findings are shown in the given image. Identify the incorrect statement regarding this condition.

FNAC - Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology

choices.text: Exposure to ionizing radiation is causative.

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and histopathological slide showing epithelial cells with clear ground-glass or Orphan Annie–eye nuclei are suggestive of the diagnosis of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. Papillary thyroid cancers usually have an excellent prognosis.

Papillary carcinoma thyroid has an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate of around 95%. The prognosis of papillary thyroid cancer is poor when age is more than 40 years, in the presence of extrathyroidal extension, and in the presence of distant metastases.

Papillary carcinoma thyroid (PTC) is the most common thyroid cancer. It is frequently associated with exposure to ionizing radiation. A gain-of-function mutation in BRAF is commonly seen in papillary thyroid cancer. Translocations that result in gene fusions of RET or NTRK are also seen in the PTC. 

Metastasis usually occurs via the lymphatic route, but hematogenous metastasis is less common. PTCs appear as cold masses on thyroid scintigraphy.

Microscopic features of papillary thyroid carcinoma:

  • The carcinoma shows branching papillae with fibrovascular stalk covered with simple or stratified cuboidal epithelium.
  • At high power, the nuclei appear optically clear or empty as the chromatin is dispersed. These empty-appearing nuclei are called Orphan Annie–eye nuclei.
  • Concentric calcified structures called psammoma bodies are usually seen.
  • Foci of lymphatic invasion by the tumor are usually present.

The presence of Orphan Annie-eye nuclei is diagnostic of papillary thyroid cancer, regardless of the presence of papillary architecture.

Variants of papillary carcinoma thyroid:

  1. Tall cell variant - Occurs in older people. Tall columnar cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm. The presence of BRAF mutations is diagnostic of this variant. They present with a higher rate of vascular invasion, extrathyroidal extension, and cervical and distant metastases than conventional PTC.
  2. Diffuse sclerosing variant - Occurs in younger individuals. This variant lack BRAF mutations, but RET/PTC translocations are present. There is a prominent papillary growth pattern with nests of squamous metaplasia. There is extensive, diffuse fibrosis throughout the thyroid gland, associated with lymphocytic infiltrate, simulating Hashimoto thyroiditis.
  3. Follicular variant - It has the characteristic nuclear features of papillary carcinoma and an almost totally follicular architecture. Contrasting to conventional PTC, this variant has a gain-of-function mutation of RAS.

The image below shows psammoma bodies in the papillary carcinoma thyroid. Inset shows a single concentrically calcified psammoma body.

Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid carcinoma. It is most common in iodine sufficient areas, children and in those exposed to ionizing radiation. 

The mean age of presentation is 3rd-4th decade and is more common in women than men (2:1). Dysphagia, dysphonia and dyspnea are associated with local invasion.

It usually presents as a cold nodule on the scan. Histological findings include:

    • Pseudo-inclusions
