Lymph node metastasis is common. Lateral aberrant thyroid denotes a cervical lymph node invaded by papillary carcinoma. The most common sites of metastasis : lung > liver > bone > brain.

It has an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%.

questions.text: Identify the surgical step shown in the image given below.
questions.solution:
Capsulorrhexis is the step shown in the given image.

Capsulorrhexis is a method of anterior capsulotomy, where an opening is made in the anterior capsule of the lens. It is one of the steps involved in conventional extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE).

Anterior capsulotomy can be done by one of three methods - can opener's technique, linear capsulotomy or envelope technique, or continuous curvilinear capsulorhexis.

Continuous curvilinear capsulorrhexis (CCC), is considered to be superior to all the preexisting methods because when done correctly, it does not leave any edges or tears. Trypan blue dye can be used to stain the lens capsule for better visibility.

In ECCE, a portion of the anterior capsule of the lens is removed, allowing extraction of the lens nucleus and cortex. This leaves the remainder of the anterior capsule, the posterior capsule, and the zonular support intact. The intact lens nucleus is then removed from the eye through a limbal incision. 

An anterior capsulotomy is followed by hydro dissection using a balanced salt solution. This helps to separate the corticonuclear mass from the capsule. Removal of lens nucleus and aspiration of the cortex is done using a two-way irrigation and aspiration cannula. An intraocular lens (IOL) is then implanted and the incision is then closed.

Some of the IOLs used are shown in the image below.

questions.text: A 33-year-old lady comes with a history of  7 weeks of amenorrhea, severe left-sided pelvic pain, and spotting PV. She gives a history of an IUCD inserted 3 years back, after her first pregnancy. A urine pregnancy test is weakly positive.  The findings of ultrasound and Doppler studies are shown below. What is true about the patient's condition?

choices.text: Salphingitis isthmica nodosa is associated with a higher incidence of the condition
Passage of a decidual cast rules out the given condition
The only treatment for it is surgical management
Doubling of beta-HCG values in 48 hours is highly suggestive of the condition

questions.solution:
Salpingitis isthmica nodosa is associated with a higher incidence of ectopic pregnancy.

This is a case of ectopic pregnancy, with the ultrasound color Doppler showing the ring-of-fire appearance in tubal ectopic pregnancy.   

Salpingitis isthmica nodosa is an inflammatory condition of the fallopian tube, characterized by nodular thickening of its isthmic portion. Histologically, the proliferation of smooth muscle and diverticula of tubal epithelium contribute to this thickening. This condition typically develops bilaterally. Since the tubal anatomy is altered, there is an increase in the risk of ectopic pregnancy.

The passage of a decidual cast is suggestive of ectopic pregnancy (Option B). The decidual cast has a smooth glistening inner surface and a shaggy maternal surface. The chorionic villi are absent.

Beta-HCG doubles every 2 days in a normal pregnancy (Option D). If the level does not rise or rises by less than 66% from the previous reading, it is suggestive of ectopic pregnancy. Beta-HCG in the urine and serum, empty uterus, adnexal mass, and free fluid in the peritoneal cavity is pathognomonic of an ectopic pregnancy. The ring of fire can be seen with color doppler imaging placental blood flow within the periphery of an ectopic pregnancy. 

Ectopic pregnancy can be managed with the following interventions: (Option C)

  • Expectant management: Ectopic pregnancies measuring <3 cm and with declining beta-hCG levels initially <1500 mIU/mL may resolve without inter­vention and can be managed expectantly. 
  • Medical management with single or multiple-dose methotrexate. Methotrexate(MTX) can be given as a single IM or as a multiple-dose regimen on days 1, 3, 5, and 7.
  • Surgical management for indicated cases is done with salpingectomy or salpingostomy.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is being evaluated for frequent falls and recurrent sino-pulmonary infections. The image below shows the ocular findings. What is the likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes a case of ataxia-telangiectasia, which is due to a defective homologous repair of DNA.

This child who has frequent falls (gait disturbances), characteristic ocular telangiectasia (seen in the image), and immunodeficiency(recurrent sinopulmonary infections) has ataxia-telangiectasia. It is an autosomal recessive disorder due to defect is in the ATM gene localized to chromosome 11.

Ionising radiations and free radicals cause breaks in DNA chain and cause abbarent cross linking between the same or different strand of DNA. Homologous recombination uses an undamaged DNA as a template and repairs the break, leading to the reconstitution of the original sequence . A mutation of the ATM gene is responsible for improper repairing of the breaks of double-strand DNA. Because of this defect, cell response to different pathogenic triggers, such as ionizing radiation and alkylating agents is impaired. Other diseases caused due to similar defect include

  • Nijmegen breakage syndrome (NBS)
  • Bloom syndrome (BS)
  • Werner syndrome (WS)
  • Rothmund-Thomson syndrome (RTS)
  • Breast cancer susceptibility 1 and 2 (BRCA1, BRCA2).

Other human diseases of DNA damage repair:

  • Defective non-homologous end joining repair 
    • Severe combined immunodeficiency disease (SCID)
  • Defective DNA base excision repair 
    • MUTYH-associated polyposis  
  • Defective DNA mismatch repair (MMR)
    • Hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC)

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman with a history of abortion 3 years back presents with secondary amenorrhea and a desire for pregnancy. Her hysterosalpingography revealed multiple filling defects. Her hysteroscopy is shown below. Which of the following statements regarding her condition is false?

D&C- Dilatation and curettage

choices.text: It occurs due to endometrial damage
Risk of this condition is least when D&C is done for postpartum hemorrhage
It can cause recurrent abortions due to inadequate placentation

questions.solution:
The given clinical features and hysteroscopy is suggestive of Asherman syndrome and the risk of developing Asherman syndrome is high if dilatation and curettage (D&C) are done in the postpartum period.

Asherman syndrome is a spectrum of scarring that includes filmy adhesions, dense bands, or complete obliteration of the uterine cavity. It occurs as a result of damage to the endometrium and the risk of this condition increases in pregnancy-related curettages such as incomplete abortion, postpartum hemorrhage, and elective abortion complicated by infection. Damage may also result from other uterine surgery and infection associated with an intrauterine device.

Depending on the degree of scarring, patients can develop amenorrhea (in less severe cases), hypomenorrhea, or recurrent pregnancy loss due to inadequate placentation.

Definitive diagnosis requires hysteroscopy. Treatment of Asherman syndrome is by hysteroscopic adhesiolysis. It improves fertility rates and relieves symptomatic hematometra.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient whose wife died in a car accident a month ago complains of insomnia and decreased appetite for 2 weeks. He has stopped going out to meet his friends as he does not have the energy to get out of the house.  On further conversing, he says he feels guilty and responsible for his wife's death and confirms not having any thoughts of suicide.  What is the diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient suffers from major depressive disorder.

DSM-V criteria for diagnosis of depression:

  1. Depressed mood most of the day
  2. Anhedonia- diminished interest in day-to-day activities
  3. Significant weight loss or weight gain and/or change in appetite.
  4. Insomnia or hypersomnia
  5. Psychomotor agitation or retardation
  6. Fatigue or loss of energy
  7. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive, inappropriate guilt
  8. Diminished ability to think or concentrate, indecisiveness
  9. Recurrent thoughts of death and suicide

At least five out of nine symptoms must be present over two weeks, and one symptom must be depressed mood or anhedonia.

Other options:

Option A: Acute stress disorder is characterised by intrusive symptoms like distressing memories, dreams and flashbacks of the event occurring after death, serious injury, or sexual violation lasting less than one month.

Option B: Adjustment disorder has emotional or behavioural symptoms in response to an identifiable stressor occurring within 3 months of the onset of the stressor and causing significant functional impairment. It is not diagnosed if the criteria for other disorders are met.

Option D: Post-traumatic stress disorder occurs after exposure to intense trauma such as death or injury. It has recurrent distressing memories of the traumatic event(flashbacks), sleep disturbance and dreams related to the traumatic event, and avoidance of stimuli associated with the traumatic event and symptoms lasting more than one month.

questions.text: A gardener living with his cats presents with fever, linear pustular lesions of 2 cm in the distal forearm, and axillary lymphadenopathy for 2 weeks. Identify the causative organism.
questions.solution:
The causative organism of cat scratch disease is Bartonella henselae.

This patient with a linear pustular lesion at the site of a cat's scratch and regional lymphadenopathy has cat scratch disease. The reservoir for B. henselae is cat, which infects humans through contact with skin lesions. It is usually self-limited and treated symptomatically with analgesics and drainage of excessively large lymph nodes. Azithromycin helps shorten the recovery period and lymph node swelling. 

It is also associated with bacillary angiomatosis, which are vascular tumors that appear as red papules on the skin, mucosa, and other locations, which resemble Kaposi sarcoma and bacillary peliosis involving the liver and spleen.

A biopsy of the affected lymph node will show the presence of rounded or stellate granuloma as shown in the image below.

Other options:

Option A: Streptobacillus moniliformis causes rat-bite fever characterized by septic fever, blotchy and petechial rashes, and very painful polyarthritis.

Option C: Francisella Tularensis is spread through infected rodents such as rabbits or through ticks. It causes ulceration at the site of inoculation and regional lymphadenopathy.

Option D: Sporothrix schenckii causes ulceration and necrotic nodules following inoculation by trauma or thorn prick. It also has a lymphocutaneous form with the spread of lesions along the lymphatics till the lymph node where all lesions are ulcerated.

questions.text:
Which of the following are true regarding wound healing by primary intention?
  1. These wounds usually involve injury of only the epithelial layer.
  2. Neutrophils usually arrive at the site at 48 hours.
  3. By the third day, neutrophils have been replaced by macrophages.
  4. There is a peak in neovascularization by day 7.
questions.solution:
Regarding healing by primary intention, only statements 1 and 3 are true. 

The sequence of events in wound healing is as follows:

Time after injury Events
Within 24 hours

Neutrophils:

  • Migrate from the incision margin towards the fibrin clot
  • Release proteolytic enzymes that begin to clear the debris

Basal cells: 

  • Located at the cut edge of the epidermis
  • Show increased mitotic activity
24 to 48 hours

Epithelial cells:

  • Migrate and proliferate from the wound edges towards the center 
  • Deposit basement membrane components 
  • Form a continuous epithelial layer that closes the wound
Day 3
  • Macrophages become predominant, with very few neutrophils 
  • Granulation tissue progressively invades the incision space
  • Collagen fibers at the incision margins
  • Increased thickness of the epithelial layer through continued epithelial proliferation 
Day 5
  • Neovascularization reaches its peak as granulation tissue fills the incisional space
  • As new vessels are leaky, new granulation tissue is often edematous
2nd week
  • Continued collagen accumulation
  • Fibroblast proliferation.
End of the 1st month
  • Scar contains cellular connective tissue
  • Largely devoid of inflammatory cells
  • Covered by an essentially normal epidermis

 

Incorrect option:

Statement (2): Neutrophils arrive at the incision/ injury site within 24 hours.

Statement (4): There is a peak in neovascularization on day 5, not day 7.

Healing of a wound can occur in three ways:

Healing by primary intention: Also called healing by first intention. This occurs when there is an apposition of the wound edges and minimal surrounding tissue trauma that causes the least inflammation and leaves the best scar. Eg: clean surgical incision.

Healing by secondary intention: Wounds are left open and allowed to heal by granulation, contraction, and epithelialization.

Healing by tertiary intention (also called delayed primary intention): Wound initially left open and edges later opposed when healing conditions are favorable.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with complaints of severe itching every time he takes a hot shower for the past few months. He also reports a burning sensation in his fingers and frequent headaches. His hemoglobin is 18 g/dL, and his erythropoietin levels are low. Which of the following is not a part of his management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of polycythemia vera (PCV), and heparin is not required as a part of management now.

Polycythemia vera is a chronic myeloproliferative disorder associated with a mutation of Janus kinase-2 (JAK2) which results in the neoplastic proliferation of hematopoietic progenitor cells. It shows a slight predominance in males. Most of the cases are incidental findings with high hemoglobin, hematocrit, or red cell count which are seen in other causes of erythrocytosis.

Aquagenic pruritis is one of the most common symptoms associated with polycythemia vera and is managed with antihistamines and SSRIs like doxepin. Ruxolitinib, hydroxyurea, and pegylated interferon alpha are used for pruritis intractable to the antihistamine. Digital ischemia, easy bruising, or gastrointestinal bleeding can occur due to thrombocytosis or vascular stasis. 

One of the complications of PCV includes thrombosis involving vital organs such as the liver, heart, brain, or lungs. Phlebotomy serves to reduce hyperviscosity and reduce the red cell mass. Aspirin is given to lower thrombotic risk if there are no contraindications. Anticoagulants like heparin are given only if thrombosis develops and not given prophylactically like aspirin. This patient has symptoms of hyperviscosity but no thrombosis and does not require heparin. 

Related Pearl: WHO Polycythemia Vera Criteria

Major criteria:

1. Hemoglobin >16.5 g/dL in men

     Hemoglobin >16.0 g/dL in women 

Or

     Hematocrit >49% in men

     Hematocrit >48% in women 

2. Bone marrow biopsy showing hypercellularity with trilineage hyperplasia (panmyelosis) and prominent erythroid, granulocytic, and megakaryocytic proliferation with pleomorphic mature megakaryocytes in the bone marrow, and 

3. Presence of JAK2 exon 12 mutation

Minor criterion:

Subnormal serum erythropoietin level

Diagnosis of polycythemia vera requires meeting either all 3 major criteria or the first 2 major criteria along with the minor criterion

questions.text: Identify the true statement regarding kidney transplantation from a live donor.

choices.text: Donor's renal artery is end-to-end anastomosed  with internal iliac artery
Donor's renal vein is end-to-end anastomosed  with internal iliac vein
It is a type of orthotopic organ transplantation
The maximum safe cold storage time is 18 hours

questions.solution:
In a live donor kidney transplantation, the donor's renal artery is end-to-end anastomosed with the internal iliac artery.

In the kidney transplant,

  • The renal vein is anastomosed end-to-side to the external iliac vein.
  • In the case of a cadaveric donor, the renal artery is anastomosed end-to-side to the external iliac artery.
  • In the case of a living donor, as the renal artery lacks an aortic patch, it may be preferable to anastomose the donor artery end-to-end to the recipient's internal iliac artery.

The below image shows the different types of anastomosis in kidney transplantation from live and deceased donors.

The iliac fossa, in the retroperitoneal position, is the usual site for kidney transplantation making it a heterotopic type of transplantation. The diseased kidney is left in situ.

The optimal cold storage time for the kidney is 18 hours and the maximum safe cold storage time for the kidney is 36 hours.

Optimal and maximum safe cold storage time for various organs are as follows:

Organs Optimal time(hours) Maximum time(hours)
1) Kidney <18 <36
2) Liver <12 <18
3) Pancreas <10 <18
4) Small intestine <4 <6
5) Heart <3 <6
6) Lungs <3 <8

 

In orthotopic graft/transplantation, the graft is placed in its normal anatomical site. However, in heterotopic graft/transplantation, the graft is placed at a site different from its normal anatomical site.

questions.text:
Match the following fundal findings with their associated diseases.
1. Headlight in the fog appearance a. Toxoplasmosis uveitis
2. Splashed tomato appearance b. Central retinal vein occlusion
3. Pizza pie appearance c. Cytomegalovirus retinitis
4. Candle wax dropping appearance d. Sarcoidosis
questions.solution:
The correctly matched set is 1 - a, 2 - b, 3 - c, and 4 - d.

1. Headlight in the fog appearance a. Toxoplasmosis uveitis
2. Splashed tomato appearance b. Central retinal vein occlusion
3. Pizza pie appearance c. Cytomegalovirus retinitis
4. Candle wax dropping appearance d. Sarcoidosis

 

Toxoplasmosis can cause severe vitritis. This leads to an impaired fundus examination that will give a "headlight in fog" appearance (a white retinal inflammatory nidus when viewed through vitritis). This finding is seen in the image below:

Fundal examination may show a satellite lesion (a single focus of fluffy white retinitis that is associated with a pigmented scar) or vitiritis as mentioned above. Optic disc edema is also common.

Splashed tomato appearance of fundus is seen in central retinal vein occlusion and occurs due to massive retinal hemorrhages. It is seen in the image below:

Pizza pie appearance of fundus is seen in retinitis associated with cytomegalovirus (otherwise known as hemorrhagic retinitis). It is seen in the image below:

questions.text:
While assessing an antenatal mother, the biophysical profile score is found to be 2. How would you manage this case?

AFI- Amniotic fluid index
questions.solution:
Almost certain fetal asphyxia is suspected when the biophysical profile score(BPP) is 2/10. If the BPP score comes out to be 2, delivery is done regardless of gestational age.

BPP is a multi-parametric, screening test to assess uteroplacental insufficiency. It consists of five components/ variables and the observations are made in 30 minutes.

Components of BPP:

  • Breathing movements of the fetus
  • Amniotic fluid volume(AFV)
  • Tone of the fetus
  • Movements of the fetus
  • Non-stress test (NST)

Each parameter has a maximum score of 2 and a minimum score of 0. So the total maximum score will be 10. A score of 4 or less indicates fetal acidemia.

Interpretation and management of BPP scores:

BPP score Interpretation Management
10 Normal, nonasphyxiated fetus Repeat test weekly 
8 with normal AFV Normal, nonasphyxiated fetus Repeat test weekly
8 with decreased AFV Suspicion of chronic fetal asphyxia

If ≥36 weeks, delivery is done
6 Possible fetal asphyxia

If AFV is abnormal-Deliver>36 weeks.

If AFV is normal- deliver≥ 37 weeks. 
4 Probable fetal asphyxia

If ≥32 weeks, deliver
0-2 Almost certain fetal asphyxia Delivery 

BPP is directly related to fetal pH and fetal outcome. A lower BPP score is associated with a poor outcome (stillbirth, perinatal mortality) and lower APGAR scores at birth.

The modified biophysical score has only 2 components i.e NST and amniotic fluid index only. It is considered abnormal (nonreassuring) when the NST is non-reactive and/or the AFI is <5.

questions.text:
Match the given diagnoses with their respective X-ray findings.

1. Transposition of great arteries (TGA)
2. Total anomalous pulmonary venous connection (TAPVC)
3. Ebstein's anomaly
4. Tetralogy of Fallot
questions.solution:
The correct match is A-4, B-1, C-3, and D-2. 

Image A represents "coeur en sabot" or a boot-shaped heart. It is due to cardiac apex elevation as a result of right ventricular hypertrophy. The cardiac silhouette has been likened to that of a boot. It is seen in the Tetralogy of Fallot (4). The hilar areas and lung fields are relatively clear because of diminished pulmonary blood flow or the small size of the pulmonary arteries. The aorta is usually large.

 

 

Image B shows a globular (like an egg) heart due to an abnormal convexity of the right atrial border and left atrial enlargement. The superior mediastinum appears narrow which gives the appearance of an egg-on-a-string. This is classically present in the transposition of great arteries (1).

 

 

Image C shows a box-shaped heart as is classically seen in Ebstein's anomaly (3). 

 

Image D shows a snowman or a figure of 8 appearance. This is seen in TAPVC (2) where pulmonary veins drain into the right atrium instead of draining into the left atrium directly or indirectly.

questions.text: Which of the following is evaluated as a part of the first-trimester aneuploidy screening test for Down syndrome?
questions.solution:
Pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A) is evaluated as a part of the combined first-trimester aneuploidy screening test.

First-trimester Aneuploidy Screening at 11-14 weeks of gestation includes:

  • β-HCG
  • Pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A)
  • Nuchal translucency scan  

Fetal trisomy 21 causing Down syndrome has higher levels of hCG and lower PAPP-A. With trisomy 18 and trisomy 13, levels of both hCG and PAPP-A are lower.

Second-trimester aneuploidy screening at 15-21 weeks includes

  • β-HCG        
  • Maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP)         
  • Unconjugated estriol        
  • Inhibin A

questions.text: Which of the following statement is correct about osteosarcoma?

choices.text: It is located in the metaphysis .
It has onion skin appearance on X-rays.
It is associated with low levels of serum LDH
It is associated with Ollier's disease.

questions.solution:
Osteosarcoma affects the metaphysis of the long bones such as the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus, and is the most common primary malignant bone tumor.

Patients present with pain and swelling especially at night, non-mechanical pain, fever, or joint restriction. The swelling may be erythematous with venous engorgement. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated lactate dehydrogenase (Option C).

Radiographs reveal an ill-defined bone-forming lesion with cortical destruction, periosteal reaction, Codman’s triangle, and sunburst appearance. Osteosarcoma is associated with Li-Fraumeni syndrome and hereditary retinoblastoma syndromes and Rothmund-Thompson syndrome (Option D).

Secondary osteosarcomas are associated with irradiation, Paget’s disease, fibrous dysplasia, bone infarcts, and chronic osteomyelitis. The lungs are a common site of metastasis and hence, a CT chest is mandatory.

Treatment involves limb salvage surgery and chemotherapeutic drugs such as doxorubicin, cisplatin, ifosfamide, and methotrexate. 

Factors associated with poor prognosis include large tumors, male gender, age<14 years, high ALP, p-glycoprotein expression, local recurrence, and Erb2 expression.

The x-ray below shows the sunburst appearance seen in osteosarcoma:

Other options:

Option B: Onion skin appearance is seen in radiographs of Ewing's sarcoma as shown below. It arises from mesenchymal cells in the bone marrow and is related to neuroectodermal tumors. It more commonly occurs in males between 10-20 years in the diaphyseal region. 

Option D: Multiple enchondromatosis is also known as Ollier disease. It is an epiphyseal tumor that occurs due to the lack of normal endochondral ossification. It will result in restricted epiphyseal growth, broadened metaphysis, and bowed long bones.

questions.text: What is the first diagnostic test to be done when tuberculous meningitis is suspected?

choices.text: Nucleic acid amplification test on CSF
Measurement of adenosine deaminase levels in CSF

questions.solution:
The Xpert MTB/ RIF test involving real-time nucleic acid amplification is done initially and has a sensitivity of 80% in the diagnosis of tuberculous meningitis. The test can simultaneously detect tuberculosis infection and rifampicin sensitivity in less than two hours. The WHO also recommends its use as a first-line diagnostic test in all patients with active TB, including those with co-existing HIV infection.

Other options: ·      

Option B: CSF culture is considered the gold standard in the diagnosis of TB meningitis, but it is not the first test to be done.

Option C: Adenosine deaminase levels are useful as a screening test in pleural effusion and very low levels in the pleural fluid help to exclude the diagnosis of tuberculosis.

Option D: CT and MRI Brain reveal hydrocephalus and involvement of basal cisterns/ ependyma.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man who is a known diabetic and hypertensive comes to the casualty ward with chest pain radiating to the left arm. ECG shows ST elevation. On thrombolytic therapy, the patient's condition becomes worse, and he develops arrhythmia. Which of the following is true about the mechanism of cell death due to the reperfusion of ischemic tissue?
  1. There is a calcium efflux.
  2. Both intrinsic and extrinsic pathways are seen.
  3. There is a failure to activate caspase 8.
  4. There is a loss of ATP.
  5. There is no generation of reactive nitrogen species.
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of reperfusion injury seen in a patient treated for MI, where cell death occurs following the pathway of necroptosis. Statements 3 and 4 are true about the mechanism of necroptosis.

Necroptosis starts as apoptosis, fails to activate caspase, and ends like necrosis, hence the name. It is referred to as "caspase-independent” programmed cell death.

Necroptosis is programmed cell death without caspase activation. As there is no caspase activation, only one pathway is seen in necroptosis. The process of necroptosis starts in a manner similar to that of the extrinsic form of apoptosis by ligation of a receptor by its ligand. It can be both physiological and pathological. 

Examples

  • Pathological: Cell death in steatohepatitis, acute pancreatitis, ischemia-reperfusion injury, neurodegenerative diseases like Parkinson's disease, and viral infections
  • Physiological: Formation of the mammalian bone growth plate

Mechanism:

  • TNF-α activates TNFR1 and, in turn, induces the recruitment of RIP1 and RIP3 kinase and other proteins to form a complex.
  • This complex includes caspase 8. But, caspase 8 is not activated in this pathway.
  • This leads to the formation of a necrosome which causes metabolic alterations leading to a loss of ATP and generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and nitrogen species.
  • Acute ischemia causes intracellular and mitochondrial calcium overload that worsens during reperfusion. Reperfusion results in cell membrane damage that allows a further influx of calcium into the cell. The calcium overload increases the permeability of mitochondria with resultant ATP depletion.
  • There is the disintegration of the cell membrane, which causes the cell contents to leak out of the cell leading to an acute inflammatory response.
  • There is a loss of cell and organelle integrity leading to cell death by necroptosis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a history of bipolar disorder presents with nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and abnormal movements of her hand since the previous night after dinner at a local restaurant. What is the next best step in the management of her current condition?
questions.solution:
This bipolar patient with nausea, vomiting, confusion, agitation, and tremors pointing towards lithium toxicity should first get serum drug levels tested to rule out lithium toxicity. 

Lithium is a mood stabilizer with a very narrow therapeutic index and is the first line of management in bipolar disorder. It decreases the rate of suicide and is also used in depression with inadequate response to monotherapy and cases of recurrent depression.

Lithium has a very narrow therapeutic index of 0.8-1.2 mEq/L. The severity of lithium toxicity is often divided into the following three grades: 

Grade

Sr. lithium concentration (in mEq/L)

 Symptoms
Mild symptoms 1.5-2.5  nausea, vomiting, tremor, and fatigue
Moderate intoxication 2.5-3.5  confusion, agitation, delirium, tachycardia, and hypertonia
Severe intoxication >3.5  coma, seizures, hyperthermia, and hypotension

Treatment options include gastric lavage and whole bowel irrigation for patients presenting early to the emergency department. Hemodialysis is done for patients demonstrating any signs and symptoms of severe lithium poisoning.

Related Pearl: Lithium in bipolar disorder

Guidelines for Lithium therapy
Indications:
Mania, hypomania, bipolar disorder, etc.

Blood levels of lithium:

For therapeutic purpose (treatment of acute mania) : 0.8-1.2 mEq/L

For prophylaxis (to prevent relapse of bipolar disorder): 0.5-0.8 mEq/L

Toxic levels of lithium: >/= 1.5 mEq/L
Contraindications:
  • CKD
  • Heart disease
  • Hyponatremia or diuretic use
Baseline studies:
  • BUN (Blood Urea Nitrogen), Creatinine, Calcium, Urine analysis
  • Thyroid function test
  • ECG in patients with coronary risk factors
Acute adverse effects:
  • Tremor, ataxia, weakness
  • Polyuria, polydipsia
  • Vomiting, diarrhea
  • Cognitive impairment
Chronic adverse effects:
  • Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus
  • Thyroid dysfunction
  • Hyperparathyroidism

questions.text: A patient with neuromyelitis optica will test positive for which of the following antibodies?
questions.solution:
Patients with neuromyelitis optica (NMO) test positive for AQP4 IgG antibodies.

Neuromyelitis optica, also known as Devic’s disease, is an aggressive inflammatory demyelinating disorder characterized by recurrent attacks of optic neuritis and myelitis. 

Diagnostic Criteria for Neuromyelitis Optica Spectrum Disorder (NMOSD):

Diagnostic Criteria for NMOSD associated with AQP4-IgG

  1. At least 1 core clinical characteristic
  2. A positive test for AQP4-IgG using the best available detection method (cell-based assay)
  3. Exclusion of alternative diagnoses

 Core Clinical Characteristics:

  1. Optic neuritis- usually bilateral and cause severe visual loss.
  2.  Acute myelitis- may be severe, transverse and typically longitudinally extensive involving three or more contiguous vertebral segments.
  3. Area postrema syndrome: episodes of otherwise unexplained hiccups or nausea or vomiting
  4. Acute brainstem syndrome
  5. Symptomatic narcolepsy  associated with NMOSD-typical diencephalic MRI lesions

For acute cases of NMO, high-dose glucocorticoids or plasma exchange is used. Mycophenolate mofetil, rituximab, and glucocorticoids with azathioprine are used for prophylaxis against relapses.

The FDA has approved satralizumab, a humanized IgG2 monoclonal antibody, for the treatment NMO spectrum disorder with AQP4 antibody positivity.

Eculizumab, a complement inhibitor, and inebilizumab, a B-cell depletion agent, are two more new drugs that have recently been approved for use in NMO attack prevention.

questions.text: You are a forensic medical officer; you have been asked to evaluate the gender of a skull found on a crime scene. Which of the following trait in the skull would suggest to you that it is a male skull?

choices.text: Mastoid process is narrow and pointed
Frontal and parietal eminences are smaller
Orbits are round with sharp margin

questions.solution:
Frontal and parietal eminences are smaller in a male skull; hence, option C is correct.

Differentiating features between male and female skulls:

questions.text: An opioid overdose victim with severe respiratory depression was brought to the casualty. You start the patient on the most potent drug known to reverse respiratory depression in this condition. Which of the following graphs represents the action of this drug?
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for the reversal of respiratory depression in opium overdose is naloxone which acts as a competitive opioid antagonist represented by graph 3.

Competitive antagonist is an agent which blocks or reduces the action of an agonist on a receptor but does not have any effect of its own. Naloxone acts on the µ receptors in the brainstem respiratory centres.

Naltrexone is also an opioid antagonist that blocks opioid effects, particularly euphoria, and discourages per­sons with opioid dependence from substance-seeking behaviour. It is not the first choice in acute opioid overdose.

Graph 1 represents the agonist: An agonist is an agent which initiates the normal physiological response when combined with a receptor. Example: Salbutamol is a beta-2 receptor agonist. 

Graph 2 represents a partial agonist: An agent which produces a submaximal or partial effect when combined with a receptor. Example: Buprenorphine and butorphanol are partial agonists at opioid receptors.
 
Graph 4 represents an inverse agonist: An agent which activates a receptor to produce an effect in the opposite direction to that of the agonist. Example: β-Carboline is an inverse agonist at the benzodiazepine site of the GABA-A receptor.
 
According to the receptor occupation theory, the ability of a drug to bind to a receptor is its affinity, and the ability to induce functional change in the receptor is designated as the intrinsic activity (IA) of the drug. These 2 properties are independent of each other.

The intrinsic activities of the above groups of drugs are given below:

Type of drugs

Intrinsic activity

Agonists

1

>0 to <1

Competitive antagonists

0

<0 to -1

The image given below shows the action of various types of selective receptor modulators:

Related Pearl: Pure opioid antagonists

Naloxone: short-acting opioid antagonist with duration of action of 1-2 hours. Used in opioid overdose and respiratory depression in newborns due to perinatal opioid use.

Naltrexone: long-acting opioid antagonist with effects lasting till 48 hours. Used for prevention of relapse in opioid addiction treatment. It is associated with hepatotoxicity. It does not suppress craving in opioid addiction but suppresses craving in chronic alcoholics.

Nalmefene: long-acting opioid antagonist with a half-life of 8-10 hours administered intravenously. Used in opioid overdose like naloxone.

questions.text: Which of the following patients is the best candidate for rabies immunoglobulin?

choices.text: An HIV patient with a category II dog bite on his leg
A patient vaccinated last year with a category III bite on the buttock
A 10-year-old boy with a dog bite on his neck
A 20-year-old woman with a lick on the intact skin over thigh by a dog confirmed to have rabies

questions.solution:
Patient 3 is the best candidate for rabies immunoglobulin (RIG).

Any transdermal bite is considered as category III, especially on the head, neck, face, hands, and genitals, because of the rich innervation of these areas. These wounds require prophylaxis with vaccine immediately and RIG as soon as possible, preferably within 7 days.

RIG provides passive immunization and is administered only once, as soon as possible after the initiation of post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine with as much of the dose as possible infiltrated around the wound site. It is indicated for category 3 wounds. It is not indicated for a previously vaccinated person. 

Patient 1 with a category II wound can be treated with a vaccine alone

Patient 2 has previously taken the rabies vaccine before and requires a booster dose without RIG this time.

Patient 3 is an adult who can give a reliable history of licking on intact skin and does not require any post-exposure prophylaxis.

Related Pearl: Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins schedules

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India:

WHO category II or III exposures should receive post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) immediately.

One intradermal (ID) dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one intramuscular (IM) dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted).

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

  • Passive immunization
  • Single-dose; after initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine
  • Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight
  • Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.
  • Alternatives for RIG- WHO recommends monoclonal antibodies (mAb) as a 'cocktail' containing at least two antibodies against the rabies virus.

Administration of RIG:

  • RIG should be administered into or around the wound site or sites.
  • The remaining RIG, if any, should be injected IM at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration.
  • RIG may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.

Prioritization of RIG allocation (numbered according to priority order):

  1. Multiple bites
  2. Deep wounds
  3. Bites to head, neck, and hands
  4. Patients with severe immunodeficiency
  5. Confirmed/probable rabies in biting animal
  6. Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat

Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)

PrEP is considered in the following conditions:

  • High-risk groups- laboratory staff, wildlife wardens, veterinarians, animal handlers, and travelers to endemic regions.
  • Remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult
  • Areas where dog bite incidence is >5% per year
  • Areas where vampire bat rabies is known to be present.

Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of 3 intramuscular (IM) or 3 intradermal (ID) doses. These are given on days 0, 7 and 21 or 28.

  • Adults - the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm
  • Young children (under 1 year of age)- Administration into the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended.
  • Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.

For exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous completion of PEP or PrEP the following guidelines would be applicable:

  • Proper wound management should be done.
  • There is no need for the administration of RIG.
  • One site ID or IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3.

Only adequate wound washing would be required in case of re-exposure where the animal bite victim has documented proof of complete PEP within the last three months.

The following cases are treated as fresh cases and given full PEP:

  • Those who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccines of unproven potency
  • Those who cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment

questions.text: Which of the following is a non-parametric test?
questions.solution:
The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric (non-numeric) test, and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data. Non-parametrical tests are commonly used when the overall data of the outcome variable is not normally distributed.

Other options: Student t-test, analysis of variation (ANOVA) test, and paired t-test are all based on quantitative data and hence grouped under parametric tests. Parametric tests are used when the overall data of the outcome variable is normally distributed.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with features of acute pancreatitis. His qSOFA score is calculated to be 1. Which of the following statements is true about this scoring system?

choices.text: Score of 1 is suggestive of life-threatening sepsis
Can be performed as a bedside test

questions.solution:
qSOFA scoring is a simplified derivative of SOFA for bedside assessment that is particularly useful outside the ICU setting as it does not require laboratory values.

The qSOFA suggests potentially life-threatening sepsis when at least two of the following parameters are met. It assigns one point for each.

  • Altered mental status (GCS <15)
  • Systolic blood pressure of 100 mmHg or less
  • Respiratory rate greater than 22 breaths/min.

A qSOFA score of ≥2 is associated with a significant risk of death or prolonged intensive care unit stay.

The qSOFA is a simplified derivative of SOFA to identify patients at risk of poor outcomes from sepsis without reliance upon laboratory or imaging data. 

SOFA is a more comprehensive and accurate scoring system which is particularly superior to qSOFA in the ICU setting. The qSOFA is a simplified derivative of SOFA for bedside assessment of individuals at risk for sepsis particularly useful outside the ICU setting (i.e. ward/emergency department).

Related Pearl: SOFA and qSOFA Scores

Sepsis is defined as a state of life-threatening organ dysfunction that occurs due to an unregulated host immune response to an infection. To objectively define the beginning of organ dysfunction, sequential organ failure assessment (SOFA) scoring is used. The variables in the SOFA score include:

  • Circulation - Systolic BP & need for vasopressors and platelet count
  • Respiration - PaO2/FiO2 & need for mechanical ventilation
  • Mentation - Glasgow coma score (GCS)
  • Hepatic function - Bilirubin
  • Renal function - Creatinine

A simplified version, recommended by the 'Sepsis 3' taskforce, is known as the quick sepsis-related organ dysfunction assessment "qSOFA" score. It includes:

  • Systolic BP ≤100 mmHg
  • Respiratory rate ≥ 22/min
  • Altered mentation/sensorium

Each criterion carries 1 point. A qSOFA score of ≥ 2 is associated with increased mortality due to sepsis.

SOFA vs qSOFA:

  • SOFA is a more comprehensive and accurate scoring system that is particularly superior to qSOFA in the ICU setting.
  • qSOFA is a simplified derivative of SOFA for bedside assessment that is particularly useful outside the ICU setting (i.e. ward/emergency department).

Thereby, the best description of sepsis would be :

  • Suspected or documented infection with SOFA score ≥ 2
    OR
  • Suspected or documented infection with qSOFA score ≥ 2

However, note that these scores were originally designed as a predictive tool that calculates the risk of death from sepsis rather than a diagnostic tool.

questions.text: An elderly male patient was rushed to the emergency room with symptoms of dry mouth, blurred vision, urinary retention, and confusion. His attenders reported a history of him consuming an unknown plant. On examination, his pulse rate was 170 beats/min, and he had warm and dry skin. Pupils were dilated. Which of the following can be used in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Physostigmine can be used in the management of this patient.

The above clinical scenario of dryness of mouth, blurred vision, urinary retention, confusion, tachycardia, warm and dry skin, and dilated pupils are suggestive of poisoning with an atropine-containing plant.

The adverse effects of atropine are due to the antimuscarinic effects. Below is an image of a mnemonic to remember the symptoms of atropine overdose.

Treatment of atropine intoxication includes a short-acting barbiturate or diazepam to control convulsions. Physostigmine is used as an antidote in atropine poisoning to treat delirium and coma. Other symptomatic management measures like respiratory support and control of hyperthermia are done.

Option B: Atropine is the causative toxic agent in the above scenario. It is used in the management of organophosphate poisoning.

Option C: Hyoscine is also a muscarinic receptor antagonist. It is used in the prevention of motion sickness.

Option D: Pralidoxime is the cholinesterase regenerator compound due to the presence of the oxime group present in this. It is used in the treatment of organophosphate poisoning.

questions.text:
Match the following tests with the ligament injuries they are used to examine.

                 

1)Apley test  a)Medial collateral ligament
2)Lachman test b)Posterior cruciate ligament
3)McMurray test  c)Anterior cruciate ligament
4)Valgus stress test  d)Menisci
questions.solution:
The correctly matched options are as follows:

1)Apley test  d)Menisci
2)Lachman test c)Anterior cruciate ligament
3)McMurray test  d)Menisci
4)Valgus stress test  a)Medial collateral ligament

It is to be noted here that both Apley grinding test and McMurray test are done to test meniscal injuries.

Apley test: This test is performed with a prone patient, the knee is flexed to 90  degrees and rotated while a compression force is applied, which is called the grinding test. Reproduction of symptoms indicates a torn meniscus. The distraction test involves repeated rotation while the leg is pulled upwards by the examiner, holding the thigh down. This produces increased pain only if there is ligament damage.

The Lachman test is also done to detect injuries to the anterior cruciate ligament. Here the leg is in slight external rotation and the knee is flexed 20 degrees. One hand is placed to stabilize the femur and another hand applies the anterior force to the proximal tibia to look for any abnormal movement.

McMurray test: Done to detect menisci injuries. The patient's knee is completely flexed while he lies supine. One hand is used to stabilize and palpate the knee joint and the leg is internally and externally rotated with the other hand. The leg is then slowly extended. Meniscal injury presents as a palpable or audible click.

The valgus stress test is performed with the knee extended by placing one hand along the lateral thigh and pressing inward while the other hand is placed on the medial aspect of the ankle and pushed outward as shown in the image below. It is positive in medial collateral ligament injury.

questions.text: Which of the following proteins is responsible for the intercellular chemical signaling mechanism depicted in the given image?
questions.solution:
The image shows gap junctions between the signaling and target cells, and the protein responsible for the signaling is connexon.

Gap junctions are intercellular junctions that allow the passage of ions and smaller molecules between the cells. It permits rapid cell-to-cell spread of action potentials that provide for coordinated and smooth contraction. They are present in the intercalated discs, urinary bladder, ureter, uterus, and choroid plexus between the cells, etc.  

The functions of gap junctions are

  • Passage of ions, sugars, amino acids, and other solutes with molecular weight up to about 1000 Da. It permits these substances to pass between the cells without entering the extracellular fluid. 
  • Provide both chemical and electrical coupling between cells. 

The structural unit present in the gap junctions is connexons, made of subunits called connexins. These connexons determine the permeability and selectivity of these junctions. 

Mutations of the connexin have predisposed to conditions like arteriosclerosis, myoclonic epilepsy, idiopathic atrial fibrillation, Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (X-linked), etc.

questions.text: A type 1 diabetic mother is on magnesium sulfate infusion post cesarean section for preeclampsia. She develops delirium and is drowsy.  She has a respiratory rate of 8/min, a random blood glucose level of 240 mg/dL, oliguria, and a bilaterally absent knee reflex. Which of the following is the most appropriate way to manage this case?

choices.text: Stop magnesium therapy and give IV calcium gluconate
Stop magnesium therapy and give oral calcium gluconate
Continue magnesium therapy and give IV calcium gluconate
Continue magnesium therapy and give diuretics

questions.solution:
Magnesium sulphate (MgSO4) infusion should be stopped, and IV calcium gluconate should be given to this woman with MgSO4 toxicity.

MgSO4 is used as an anticonvulsant in the management of eclampsia and as prophylaxis in severe preeclampsia. The therapeutic level of magnesium in eclampsia is 4–7 mEq/L. Measurement of serum magnesium levels is indicated to monitor magnesium toxicity if serum creatinine >1.0 mg/dL.

Signs suggestive of magnesium toxicity include:

  • Loss of deep tendon reflexes
  • Decreased respiratory rate <12/min
  • Urine output <30 mL/h
  • Chest pain and heart block 
  • Visual changes, flushing, muscle paralysis, and drowsiness

It is treated by stopping magnesium therapy and giving slow IV calcium gluconate 10 mL (10% solution) infusion. Fluid loading and forced diuresis are done and estimation of serum magnesium and creatinine levels

Repeated/maintenance dose IM injections of magnesium sulfate are continued only under the following conditions:

  • The patellar reflex is present
  • Respiration is not depressed
  • Urine output >30 mL/h

questions.text:
Which of the following options is the probable cause of the metabolic abnormality indicated by the following parameters?

pH = 7.5

HCO3-= 30 mEq/L

pCO2 = 40 mmHg

Urine Cl- = 18 mEq/L
questions.solution:
The metabolic abnormality in the above scenario is metabolic alkalosis, and vomiting is the probable cause of this metabolic abnormality.

Interpretation of the ABG:

Step 1: The pH of 7.5 is above the normal limits (7.35–7.45) and thus implies the presence of alkalosis.

Step 2: Plasma HCO3- is 30 mEq/L and is higher than the normal limits (22–28 mEq/L) while the pCO2 is 40 mmHg and is within the normal limits (35 - 45 mmHg). This implies that the alkalosis is due to an increase in the plasma HCO3- and is thus metabolic in origin. The only cause of metabolic alkalosis from the given options is vomiting.

On the contrary, normal plasma HCO3- with a decrease in pCO2 levels would point to a respiratory cause of alkalosis.

Option A: Weakening of respiratory muscles leads to hypoventilation, which is a cause of respiratory acidosis.

Option B: Methanol intoxication causes high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

Option C: Anxiety/panic attack leads to hyperventilation and is a cause of respiratory alkalosis.

Note: Metabolic alkalosis can be further classified based on the urine Cl- levels as follows:

Metabolic alkalosis Saline-resistant  Saline-responsive 
 Urine Cl- levels  >20 mEq/L  <20 mEq/L
Causes  Hyperaldosteronism  Vomiting
 Bartter syndrome

 Recent loop/ thiazide   diuretics
 Gitelman syndrome  Antacids

Thus, vomiting causes saline-responsive metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: An elderly man presents with fatigue and weight loss. Physical examination revealed pallor and splenomegaly. Investigations revealed Hb level of 10 mg/dL, WBC count of 1,50,000/mm3; platelet count of 5,00,000/μL; and a decreased leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) score. The peripheral smear is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely chromosomal translocation seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of fatigue, significant weight loss, splenomegaly, leukocytosis and peripheral smear showing increased white blood cells with myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and band forms, and a low LAP score all point towards the diagnosis of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). The chromosome translocation most commonly seen in CML is t(9;22).

CML is a hematopoietic stem cell disorder that is common in males 55-65 years of age. It occurs due to the translocation between the long arms of chromosomes 9 and 22, forming the Philadelphia chromosome. The resulting BCR-ABL translocation results in the activation of tyrosine kinase that signals pro-growth and pro-survival pathways like RAS and JAK/STAT pathways resulting in the proliferation of hematopoietic stem cells. Common presenting features are fatigue, malaise, weight loss, and splenomegaly. 

On the peripheral smear, there is leukocytosis , with a leukocyte count often exceeding 100,000 cells/mm3 (neutrophils, band forms, metamyelocytes, myelocytes, eosinophils, and basophils). Blasts are usually less than 10% of the circulating cells, and the platelet count is usually increased. Basophils and eosinophils are often increased. There are decreased levels of leucocyte alkaline phosphatase due to a relative increase in abnormal myeloid cells.

The emergence of tyrosine kinase inhibitors as first-line therapy has dramatically improved the survival of these patients. Imatinib is the most commonly used drug.

Other options-

Option A: t(11;22) - This is seen in Ewing's sarcoma. The biopsy sample, as shown below, has the typical small round blue cells and Homer-Wright rosettes:

Option B: t(14;18)- This is seen in follicular lymphoma. They present with multiple areas of painless lymphadenopathy. Histopathology of the enlarged nodes would show nodular expansion of tumor cells, composed of small cells with cleaved nuclei (centrocytes) and larger cells with more cytoplasm (centroblasts). A follicular lymphoma biopsy slide can be seen below:

Option D: t(15;17)- This is seen in the acute promyelocytic variant of acute myeloid leukemia. Peripheral smears (as depicted below) would show the classic intracytoplasmic Auer rods (red arrows):

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with increased fatigue, low-grade fevers, and night sweats. Physical examination reveals several small, rubbery, mobile, non-tender supraclavicular lymph nodes. The lymph node biopsy findings are shown in the image below. Immunophenotyping shows CD15+, CD30+, and PAX5+. Activation of which of the following factors occurs in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and the image showing Reed-Sternberg cells are suggestive of a diagnosis of Hodgkin's lymphoma. Activation of the transcription factor NF-κB is a common event in classical Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL).

NF-κB may be activated by Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection. EBV+ tumor cells express latent membrane protein-1 (LMP-1), a protein encoded by the EBV genome that transmits signals that upregulate NF-κB. Activation of NF-κB may occur in EBV tumors as a result of the acquired loss-of-function mutations in TNF alpha-induced protein 3 (TNFAIP3). (Option D)

Activation of NF-κB by EBV or other mechanisms rescues “crippled” germinal center B cells that cannot express Igs from apoptosis, eventually leading to the formation of Reed-Sternberg cells. TNF α, IL-10, and TGF beta are involved in cross-talk between Reed-Sternberg cells and other normal cells in classical forms of Hodgkin's lymphoma. (Option A and B)

Reed-Sternberg cell: It is a giant cell. It has a classic owl-eyed appearance due to the presence of a symmetric or mirror-image bilobed nucleus with prominent nucleoli surrounded by a clear space.

Clinical features of Hodgkin's lymphoma - Typical presentation involves lymphadenopathy/ mass with B symptoms, which include fever, night sweats, and weight loss.

Diagnosis - Requires microscopic findings and immunophenotyping findings to correlate. Microscopy of lymph nodes shows the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells.

questions.text: A boy presented to the emergency with severe rice-watery diarrhea and dehydration. Upon investigating, he was diagnosed to have cholera. On which of the following enzymes in the intestinal tract does the cholera toxin act?
questions.solution:
Cholera toxin acts on the adenylyl cyclase enzyme. The diarrhea is due to the action of this toxin that acts by stimulating the enzyme adenylate cyclase, which catalyzes the production of cyclic AMP from ATP. 

Mechanism of action of cholera toxin: 

The cholera toxin is made up of an active (A) subunit, and a receptor binding (B) subunit. B subunit attaches to the GM1 ganglioside receptors on the surface of jejunal epithelial cells. Once bound, the entire toxin complex is endocytosed by the cell and the A subunit is released inside. This A subunit then binds to the stimulatory Gα-coupled receptor causing activation of cellular adenylate cyclase which catalyzes the production of cyclic AMP from ATP. 

High levels of cAMP start a cascade leading to overactivity of the cell resulting in outpouring of large quantities of water and electrolytes into the lumen. This is the reason for rice-watery diarrhea which is isotonic with plasma but contains much more potassium and bicarbonate. The toxin also inhibits the intestinal absorption of sodium and chloride.

All clinical manifestations and complications in cholera result from the massive water and electrolyte depletion thus caused.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child with a history of daydreaming in class and a decrease in academic performance. His EEG shows a symmetric 3 Hz spike and wave pattern. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and EEG showing a 3 Hz spike and wave pattern point to the diagnosis of absence seizures.

Absence seizures are characterized by sudden, brief lapses of consciousness with preserved postural control and no post-ictal confusion. Usually, the seizure lasts only a few seconds. They are predominantly seen in children between four to ten years of age, with a decline in academic performance in school and unexplained 'daydreaming'. Hyperventilation can provoke these EEG discharges and seizures.

Ethosuximide and sodium valproate are used as first-line therapy for absence seizures. Lamotrigine is used as an alternative or add-on drug for absence seizures.

Drugs like oxcarbazepine, carbamazepine, phenytoin, phenobarbital, tiagabine, and vigabatrin may worsen absence seizures and should be avoided.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male HIV patient came with a sharp, severe, constant, burning pain in the right chest. On examination, the lesion is as seen below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image showing confluent, red, pustular, painful lesions in a single dermatome is highly suggestive of herpes zoster infection. 

Herpes zoster infection or shingles is a segmental eruption due to the reactivation of latent varicella-zoster virus from the dorsal root ganglia most commonly affecting thoracic dermatomes. An earlier primary infection with varicella is essential before zoster can occur. 

The first symptom of zoster is usually pain in the affected area. It may also be accompanied by fever, headache, malaise, and tenderness localized to areas of one or more dermatome. The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved. The patients are infectious, both from the virus in the lesions and the nasopharynx.

Zoster is a self‐limiting infection, but it is painful and carries a risk of secondary infection and post‐herpetic neuralgia. Analgesia and treatment of secondary infections are sufficient for mild infections.

Other options: 

Option B: Irritant contact dermatitis is the cutaneous response to the physical/ toxic effects of a wide range of environmental exposures. The main clinical features are usually dryness or chapping. The lesions could commonly develop into patchy or diffuse erythema with scaling and fissuring.

Option C: Allergic contact dermatitis is defined as an eczematous reaction with itchy, erythematous papules and papulovesicles that occurs as an immunological response following exposure to a substance to which the immune system has previously been sensitized. 

Option D: Herpes simplex lesions are thin-walled vesicles, the roof of which breaks down, leaving tiny superficial ulcers that heal without scarring. This commonly affects face-orolabial herpes, genitals, and fingers- herpetic whitlow.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman with schizoaffective disorder was prescribed risperidone. Which of the following should be monitored in the patient taking this drug?
questions.solution:
Serum prolactin levels should be monitored in patients taking risperidone. 

Risperidone and paliperidone cause the maximum rise in prolactin levels and has the highest potential to cause hyperprolactinemia among the atypical antipsychotics. Hence, the prolactin level should be monitored through clinical inquiry. Hyperprolactinemia results from the blockade of the pituitary actions of the tuberoinfundibular dopaminergic neurons.

Risperidone is an atypical antipsychotic that shows both D2 and 5 HT2 receptor blockade. It also has an affinity for alpha 1, alpha 2, and H1 receptors. It produces a more potent D2 blockade than clozapine. At low doses, extrapyramidal side effects are less.
 
Uses of risperidone:
  • Long-term management of psychosis and schizophrenia.
  • Maintenance therapy in mania bipolar disorders.
  • Management of irritability associated with autism.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presented with vague abdominal pain. On USG, he was found to have a renal cyst of Bosniak class III. CECT was done, as shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The CT image showing renal lesions that has hypoattenuating components consistent with macroscopic fat is highly suggestive of renal angiomyolipoma.

Imaging in renal angiomyolipoma: Demonstration of macroscopic fat is the main part of making a diagnosis. USG may show hyperechoic lesions in the cortex with posterior acoustic shadowing. In patients with tuberous sclerosis, the entire kidney is affected, producing an echogenic appearance with loss of normal corticomedullary junction.

CT findings:

  • Cortical lesions that demonstrate macroscopic fat (less than -20 HU)
  • Absence of ossification or calcification
  • The presence of macroscopic fat is strongly suggestive of this condition, but not pathognomonic as RCC may rarely demonstrate macroscopic fat.
  • Approximately 5% may be fat poor.

MRI: It is an excellent tool to demonstrate intramural fat components. Two sequences are used:

  • Fat-saturated techniques 
  • Phase-in and phase-out imaging that shows India ink artifact at the junction between fat and non-fat components.

Digital subtraction angiography: They are hypervascular lesions showing 'sunburst appearance' in the arterial phase and 'onion peel appearance' in the venous phase.

Angiomyolipomas are benign tumors that occur sporadically or in association with tuberous sclerosis. The mean age of presentation is 43 years and there is a female predilection. It can present as spontaneous retroperitoneal hemorrhage, especially with larger tumors. The patient can present with flank pain, palpable mass, hematuria, urinary tract infections, hypertension, or renal failure. They usually do not require any intervention. mTOR inhibitors like everolimus can be used to decrease the size of the lesion.

Bosniak classification:

It classifies the renal cystic lesions mainly into four classes based on the CT characteristics.

Class I and II are benign and do not require follow-up imaging or surgery.

Class IIF requires follow-up for about 5 years to exclude malignancy.

Class III needs to be biopsied or surgically explored due to a higher risk of malignancy.

Class IV lesions are clearly malignant and need appropriate treatment.

Other options:

Renal cell carcinoma (RCC): It is the most common malignant tumor of the kidney. It usually occurs in the age group 50-70 years and macroscopic hematuria is seen in about 60% of the cases. It is a differential for angiomyolipoma but it is important to note that macroscopic fat is almost always associated with ossification or calcification.

Renal oncocytoma: They are relatively benign in nature and usually present in the 6th to 7th decade. An important point regarding this tumor is its similarity with RCC and hence it is very difficult to differentiate between them preoperatively. A sharp central stellate scar may be seen in one-third of the cases. But RCC may also show this stellate scar appearance in some cases.

Renal cyst: It is a broader term that includes the cystic lesions of the kidney. They can be simple cysts that are benign. Complex or complicated cystic lesions need evaluation and can be malignant. Bosniak classification of renal cysts is given above.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman is found to have a Hb of 7.2 g/dL and high ferritin levels. She has been undergoing chemotherapy for breast cancer since the last year. What change would you expect in the serum hepcidin levels of this patient?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of anemia of chronic disease. The chief mediator of this condition is hepcidin, a positive acute-phase reactant (APR) that increases in chronic inflammatory states. It binds with ferroportin, which reduces the iron intake in the gut and reduces iron transfer from macrophages to erythroid progenitor cells in the bone marrow. This is reflected by a low serum iron level, increased red cell protoporphyrin level, a hyperproliferative marrow, and normal or increased serum ferritin level. Hence, hepcidin is a negative regulator of iron balance.

Anemia of chronic disease is associated with chronic inflammatory states such as inflammatory bowel disease, rheumatoid arthritis, chronic infections, and malignancies.

questions.text: You are a resident doctor in the intensive care unit. You administer a drug 'X' to a patient. The plasma concentration of the drug reaches 500 mg/L. The drug follows zero-order kinetics. 200 mg of the drug 'X' is eliminated in 4 hours. What is the clearance of this drug?
questions.solution:
The clearance of drug X is 1.66 mL/min.

Since drug X follows zero-order kinetics, the elimination rate (amount of drug eliminated in unit time) is constant.

200 mg is eliminated in 4 hours. Therefore, 50 mg is eliminated in 1 hour as it follows zero-order kinetics.

Clearance = Rate of elimination/Plasma concentration

Rate of elimintation= 50 mg/h
Plasma concentration= 500 mg/L

Clearance = (50 mg/hr)/(500 mg/L)= 0.1 L/h

To convert L/h to mL/min, multiply by 1000 and divide by 60.

∴ Clearance = 0.1 x 1000 ml/60 min= 1.66 mL/min

Related Pearl: Zero order vs First order kinetics of drugs

Zero order

First order

Constant amount of drug is eliminated per unit time

 Constant fraction of drug is eliminated per unit time

Rate of elimination is independent of plasma concentration

 Rate of elimination is proportional to the plasma concentration

Clearance is more at low concentration and less at high concentration

 Clearance remains constant 

Half-life is less at low concentration and more at high concentration

 Half-life remains constant

Very few drugs follow zero-order kinetics, e.g.(WATT Power)

  • Warfarin
  • Alcohol, Aspirin
  • Tolbutamide
  • Theophylline 
  • Phenytoin

 

 Most of the drugs follow first order kinetics

questions.text: All the following statements are correct regarding the WHO Labour Care guide, except ______.

choices.text: Monitoring of second stage is done
Records strength, duration and frequency of uterine contractions
Records labor companionship, posture, and oral fluid intake
Active phase starts from 5 cm of cervical dilatation

questions.solution:
All are correct statements regarding the WHO Labour Care Guide except option B. It records the duration and frequency of uterine contraction. It does not record the strength of the uterine contraction, unlike the partograph which also records the intensity of contraction.

WHO Labour Care Guide is the labor monitoring tool that includes new recommendations from the WHO based on emerging evidence on normal labor progression. The following are the salient features:

  • It is a graphical representation of the progress of labor that includes cervical dilatation and descent of the fetal presenting part, against time.
  • Documentation of labor progression begins at 5 cm of cervical dilatation. This reduces unnecessary interventions in cases labeled as poor progression of active labor if it started at 4 cm.
  • Documentation of the duration and frequency of uterine contractions.
  • Time-based cut-offs for each centimeter of cervical dilatation to guide the obstetrician to take action.
  • Supportive care of the mother with assessment of labor companionship, oral hydration, maternal position and mobility, and pain management are included.

questions.text: A patient underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy and was discharged after removing  the drain tube on the first postoperative day. On day three, the patient came back to the hospital and was febrile. On ultrasound examination, there was a 5 x 5 cm collection in the subhepatic space. Next best step is ______.

choices.text: To give oral antibiotics since the given accumulation is normal
To re-explore the wound and insert a T-tube

questions.solution:
The given clinical situation suggests a bile duct injury identified on post-op day 3 following laparoscopic cholecystectomy. The next best step after imaging would be to control inflammation by drainage of fluid collection (pigtail insertion and drainage) and administration of parenteral broad-spectrum antibiotics.

Bile duct injury

  • Usually is manifested in the postoperative period
  • Clinical features include fever, increasing abdominal pain, jaundice and bile leakage from an incision.

Imaging: Ultrasonography is done to assess for fluid collection and to evaluate the biliary tree.

Treatment Strategy

  • Control of infection, limiting inflammation
    • Percutaneous drainage of periportal fluid collections
    • Parenteral antibiotics (option A)
  • Clear and thorough delineation of entire biliary anatomy
    • Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) or percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography (PTC)
    • Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP), especially if a cystic duct stump leak is suspected
  • Re-establishment of biliary-enteric continuity (surgery)
    1. Tension-free, mucosa-to-mucosa anastomosis
    2. Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy

Other options:

Option B: Re-exploration and repair in indicated for biliary leaks identified in within 48 hours post cholecystectomy.

Option D: ERCP would be indicated if drainage using a pigtail catheter fails.

questions.text: A 64-year-old diabetic and hypertensive patient with an average BP of 150/90 mmHg had a transient ischemic attack that lasted for 30 minutes. The total score adds up to 5 points which suggests a 12% risk of developing a stroke in the next 3 months.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with a history of ingestion of one uncrushed seed similar to that shown in the image below. He is asymptomatic at presentation. Which of the following can be anticipated in this case?
questions.solution:
The image shows seeds of Strychnos nux-vomica. No poisonous action is anticipated.

If swallowed uncrushed, the seeds of nux vomica have no poisonous action, as they are not dissolved in the gastrointestinal tract and are passed entirely in the feces.

Strychnine is a competitive antagonist of glycine at the postganglionic receptors in the motor neurons of the anterior horn of the spinal cord. This leads to increased activity in the motor neurons. 

The fatal dose is 15-30 mg of strychnine or one crushed seed. When crushed seeds are ingested, the symptoms are delayed for an hour or more.

Convulsions are produced as the reflex centers of the spinal cord are directly affected. The convulsions are first clonic but eventually become tonic.  Risus sardonicus results from the contraction of the jaws and facial muscles in which the corners of the mouth are drawn back. The convulsions are most marked in anti-gravity muscles so that the body typically arches in hyperextension, the posture known as opisthotonos. If the spasm involves the abdominal muscles, the body bends forward (emprosthotonos), or to the side (pleurosthotonos). If death is preceded by a severe convulsion, as in strychnine poisoning, it causes an increase in the body temperature known as postmortem caloricity.

Related Pearl: Signs and Symptoms of Strychnine Poisoning

The clinical features of strychnine poisoning are:

  • Convulsions - clonic-tonic type
  • Reflex increased
  • Awful taste
  • Mind is conscious
  • Pupils dilated
  • Opisthotonos: arching back
  • Emprosthotonos: arching forward
  • Pleurothotonus: bending sideward
  • Risus Sardonicus - fixed contraction of the facial muscles resulting in a peculiar distorted grin.

Strychnine poisoning case may resemble tetanus.

Although a poison, in relatively low doses it can be used as a medical stimulant for respiration.
