questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the pharmacological profile of sildenafil?

choices.text: It is safe for combined use with nitrates.
It acts by the accumulation of cGMP in the corpus cavernosum.
It is useful in the management of pulmonary arterial hypertension.
It is a phosphodiesterase type 5 (PDE5) inhibitor.

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement regarding sildenafil is that it is safe for combined use with nitrates.

Nitrates are not safe for use in combination with sildenafil. Both sildenafil and nitrates increase cGMP levels. Therefore, combining nitrates with sildenafil has a risk of severe hypotension. 

Sildenafil acts by inhibiting phosphodiesterase-5 (PDE-5) and is used in the treatment of erectile dysfunction. PDE-5 inhibitors cause the accumulation of cGMP in the corpus cavernosum, which leads to the relaxation of smooth muscles of penile arteries that fill the corpus cavernosum, thereby improving erectile function in patients with erectile dysfunction.

It can be used in the treatment of pulmonary arterial hypertension. The drug decreases pulmonary vascular resistance and enhanced exercise capacity.

Adverse effects include headache, flushing, nasal congestion, blue-green tinting of vision, dizziness, and back pain.

questions.text: Which of the following options represents the blood supply and site of termination of the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image is the fornix, and the blood supply and site of termination of the fornix are the anterior cerebral artery and mammillary body, respectively. 

The fornix is a part of the connecting pathways of the limbic system. It arises from the hippocampus, which wraps around the thalamus and ends in the mammillary body. It connects the hippocampus with distal brain sites. The blood supply of the fornix is by the anterior communicating artery, which arises from the anterior cerebral artery. 

The fornix has two types of fibers:

  • Association fibers connect the various cortical regions within the same hemisphere.
  • Commissural fibers connect the corresponding regions of two hemispheres. It is seen in the hippocampal commissure of the fornix. 

The limbic system is a group of structures between the cerebral cortex and the hypothalamus. It is involved in emotional and motivational activity, learning, and memory. 

Related Pearl: White matter tracts of the brain

Commissural fibers: connect corresponding regions of two hemispheres.

They include

  • Corpus callosum
  • Anterior and posterior commissure
  • Habenular commissure
  • Hippocampal commissure of fornix

Association fibers: connect various cortical regions within the same hemisphere.

They are classified as 

  • Short association fibers: lie immediately under the cortex and connect adjacent gyri. Eg- arcuate fasciculus
  • Long association fibers:
    • Uncinate fasciculus
    • Cingulum
    • Superior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Inferior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Fronto-occipital fasciculus
    • Fornix (except hippocampal commissure of fornix)

Projection fibers: fibers passing to and from the brainstem to the cerebral cortex. 

  • Internal capsule
  • Corona radiata

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with anterior epistaxis. His mother says that he frequently picks his nose. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
The next best step in the management of epistaxis is pinching the nose with the thumb and index finger for a few minutes. This action leads to compression of the vessels located in Little's area. 

Epistaxis refers to any bleeding from inside the nose. Epistaxis may be classified as anterior or posterior epistaxis. The blood may flow out from the front of the nose anteriorly when the patient sits, making it anterior epistaxis. If blood flows into the back of the throat, it is posterior epistaxis. 

The blood supply of the nasal septum and the lateral wall of the nose is by the branches of the external carotid system and the internal carotid system. Little’s area is the site of 90% of the patients with anterior epistaxis. It is located in the anteroinferior part of the nasal septum, above the nasal vestibule. This area is the site of Kiesselbach's plexus, the anastomosis of four arteries: anterior ethmoidal artery, the septal branch of the superior labial artery, the septal branch of the sphenopalatine artery, and the greater palatine artery. 

This area, due to its location, is exposed to the drying effect of inspired are, and fingernail or instrumentation-related trauma. Thus, it is the usual site of epistaxis in children and young adults. 

The following image shows the blood supply of the nasal septum. 

Bleeding may also arise from Woodruff's plexus, which is located inferior to the posterior end of the inferior turbinate. This is the site for posterior epistaxis.

It may be local, general, or idiopathic. Local causes include trauma, infections, foreign body, neoplasm, and atmospheric changes. General causes may be attributed to systemic diseases of the heart, liver, kidney, and infections. Epistaxis is mostly idiopathic in the elderly.

Management of epistaxis is as follows: 

First aid involves pinching the nose for five minutes. This compresses Little's area. Trotter's method involves asking the patient to lean over a basin to spit out blood and to simultaneously breathe from the mouth. The application of cold compresses can cause reflex vasoconstriction and reduce bleeding. 

The following image shows Trotter's method.

Cauterization (Option C) is performed when the site of bleeding has been identified, especially in anterior epistaxis. The area should be anesthetized and then cauterized by silver nitrate or electrocautery. It can also be performed endoscopically. 

Nasal packing (Option D) can be anterior or posterior depending on the site of bleeding. Here, the nose is cleared of debris and cauterized. If this does not work, then a ribbon gauze soaked in paraffin is placed in each cavity and left for up to a few days. Antibiotics should be given to prevent infection and toxic shock syndrome. 

In the submucous resection (SMR) operation, the mucoperichondrial flap is elevated and then repositioned. This causes fibrosis and constriction of blood vessels. 

If bleeding is from the external carotid, maxillary, or ethmoidal arteries, they can be ligated. The internal maxillary artery can also be embolized by an interventional radiologist with femoral artery catheterization. The ethmoidal arteries cannot be embolized.

The transnasal endoscopic sphenopalatine artery ligation (TESPAL) (Option B) is a procedure done under sedation with a rigid endoscope. Here, a mucosal flap is lifted and the sphenopalatine artery is localized as it exits the foramen. It is closed with a clip and the distal branches can be cauterized followed by repositioning of the flap. This is very successful in refractory posterior bleeds. 

Related Pearl: Nasal Septum

Septum proper is an osseocartilaginous framework made up of:

  • Septal or quadrilateral cartilage
  • Perpendicular plate of ethmoid
  • Vomer
  • Others – crest of nasal bones, nasal spine of frontal bone, rostrum of sphenoid, crest of palatine bones and the crest maxilla, and the anterior nasal spine of maxilla

questions.text:
A 37-week primigravid mother presents to you in active labor. Her serology done 2 weeks before revealed the following findings. What is the best step in the management of the newborn?
HBsAg positive
HBeAg positive
Anti-HBc IgG positive

HBIG- Hepatitis B immune globulin

choices.text: Single-dose HBIG and vaccination after 1 week

questions.solution:
The best step for an infant born to a hepatitis B carrier mother is single-dose HBIG and routine vaccination.

This pregnant woman having HBeAg and HBsAg positive with anti-HBc-IgG positive has a chronic hepatitis B viral (HBV) infection or is in a chronic carrier state. Both of the above scenarios put the infant at risk of HBV transmission. The recommended management is to give a single dose of hepatitis B immune globulin immediately and the first dose or routine vaccination within 12 hours of birth. HBIG confers passive immunity and is also given to persons exposed to HBV percutaneously or by contamination of mucosal surfaces along with the HBV vaccine. HBIG does not interfere with the antibody response to the hepatitis B vaccine. This combined procedure is ideal both for postexposure prophylaxis of persons accidentally exposed to blood known to contain hepatitis B virus and for the prevention of the carrier state in the newborn babies of carrier mothers.

Interferon alfa, entecavir, and tenofovir are first-line treatments indicated for patients with chronic active hepatitis to prevent the progression of liver fibrosis. It is not indicated as prophylaxis for babies born to seropositive mothers.

questions.text:
Which among the following is not a subcutaneous fungal infection?
  1. Chromoblastomycosis
  2. Histoplasmosis
  3. Pityriasis versicolor
  4. Sporotrichosis
questions.solution:
Histoplasmosis and pityriasis versicolor are not subcutaneous fungal infections.

The infection caused by fungi can be broadly classified as follows:

Histoplasmosis is a systemic fungal infection caused by dimorphic fungi Histoplasma capsulatum. It is acquired by inhalation and causes disease similar to tuberculosis and may present as fever, chills, headache, dry cough, dyspnea and chest pain.

Pityriasis versicolor is a superficial fungal infection localised to the stratum corneum and is caused by Malassezia furfur. Lesions are characterised by discrete or confluent, discoloured or depigmented macules occurring on the chest, abdomen, and upper limbs and back.

Chromoblastomycosis is a subcutaneous fungal infection involving subcutaneous tissue causing warty nodules that resemble cauliflower around the site of inoculation. It is characterised by the presence of sclerotic bodies which are round or irregular, dark brown, yeast-like bodies with septae.

Sporotrichosis is an infection involving cutaneous, subcutaneous and lymphatic tissue caused by the dimorphic fungi sporothrix schenckii. It presents as nodules that are first formed at the site of inoculation, followed by ulceration and necrosis of the nodules. The infection can spread via the lymphatic channels to the lymph nodes resulting in cord-like hardened lymphatics and secondary ulcers on the lymph nodes.

questions.text:
Which of the following tests would be helpful in determining whether a particular stain is due to seminal fluid?
  1. Creatine phosphokinase test
  2. Kastle Meyer test
  3. Barberio test
  4. Acid phosphatase test
  5. Takayama test
  6. Florence test
questions.solution:
The acid phosphatase test, Barberio test, Florence test, and creatine phosphokinase test are used to detect seminal stains; hence option D is correct. 

Kastle-Meyer test and Takayama test are used to detect blood stains (not seminal stains).

Forensic tests for detection of seminal stains:

  • Florence test detects choline (secreted by seminal vesicles). Florence solution consists of potassium iodide, iodine, and water. If semen is present, dark-brown crystals of choline iodide are seen.
  • Barberio’s test detects spermin (secreted by the prostate) and uses an aqueous or alcoholic solution of picric acid. Yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals of spermine picrate are seen in the presence of seminal fluid.
  • Acid phosphatase test- The prostatic secretion element of seminal fluid contains 500 to 1000 times greater acid phosphatase than any other body fluid. The test is conclusive in case of the absence of demonstrable sperms or Aspermia.
  • Creatine Phosphokinase: Creatine phosphokinase is present in high amounts in spermatozoa. Levels over 400 units of CPK/ml are almost diagnostic of seminal stains.
  • The absolute proof of semen is finding at least one unbroken spermatozoon or electrophoretic LDH isoenzyme detection of sperms.

 

 

Related Pearl: Tests to detect seminal and blood stains

Tests for seminal stains

  • Barberio's test
  • Florence test
  • Acid phosphatase test
  • Creatine phosphokinase test
  • Immunological test to detect Prostate Specific Antigen

Tests for blood stains  

  • Benzidine test
  • Phenophthalein (Kastle Meyer) test
  • Takayama hemochromogen crystal test
  • Teichmann’s hemin crystal test
  • Spectroscopic test

questions.text: A middle-aged female patient with an abdominal mass was diagnosed with gestational trophoblastic neoplasia. On further evaluation, it is found that neoplasia has metastasized to the liver and lungs. What would be the clinical staging according to FIGO classification?
questions.solution:
The patient would be classified to have stage-IV gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN).

International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics (FIGO) Staging for GTN is as follows:

  • Stage I - Confined to the uterus
  • Stage II - GTN extends outside of the uterus but is limited to the genital structures
  • Stage III - GTN extends to the lungs, with or without known genital tract involvement
  • Stage IV - All other metastatic sites.

This patient with metastasis to the liver and lungs has Stage IV disease.

GTN includes tumors that cause aggressive invasion of the endometrium and myometrium by trophoblastic cells. This includes invasive mole, choriocarcinoma, placental site trophoblastic tumor, and epithelioid trophoblastic tumor. GTN is diagnosed based on elevated β-hCG levels. Criteria for diagnosis of GTN:

  • Persistence of β-hCG level plateau in 4 measurements for 3 weeks or longer
  • Rise in β-hCG levels in 3 or more consecutive measurements done weekly, over a period of 2 weeks or longer
  • Elevated β-hCG level for 6 months or more
  • Histologic diagnosis of choriocarcinoma.

A modified prognostic scoring system by the WHO distinguishes patients at low risk for therapeutic failure from those at high risk. Treatment for the low-risk disease is chemotherapy with methotrexate, while those with high-risk disease are treated with etoposide, methotrexate, and dactinomycin alternating with cyclophosphamide and vincristine (EMA/CO) chemotherapy.

Related Pearl: Risk factors and FIGO staging of Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia

Risk factors

  • Older age
  • β-hCG levels > 100,000 mIU/mL
  • Uterine size that is large-forgestational age
  • Theca-lutein cysts > 6 cm
  • Slow decline in β-hCG levels
  • Postevacuation uterine sonographic surveillance showing myometrial nodules or hypervascularity may be a predictor of subsequent neoplasia.

FIGO staging:

Stage I Disease confined to the uterus
Stage II GTD extends outside of the uterus but is limited to the genital structure
Stage III Lung metastasis with or without genital tract involvement
Stage IV Other metastasis

questions.text: Identify the type of MRI image.
questions.solution:
The given MRI is a T1-weighted image as the CSF is dark/hypointense, white matter is white, and grey matter is dark.

Many pulse sequence techniques are used in MRI, but the most classic ones are T1- and T2-weighted imaging.

In T1 images, CSF is dark/hypointense, white matter is white, and grey matter is dark.

In T2 images, CSF is bright/hyperintense, white matter is dark, and grey matter is white. (water is white on T2, so is CSF)

The following images are T1 and T2 images:

 

Fluid-attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) is an inversion recovery technique that nulls fluid from T2. So, CSF is dark, white matter is dark, and grey matter is white. 

The following shows FLAIR image:

Short-tau inversion recovery (STIR) is an inversion-recovery technique that nulls fat. So, fat is black.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old woman underwent a total hip arthroplasty via the posterior approach. Postoperatively she has difficulty climbing the stairs and rising up from a sitting position. The doctor observes a loss of extension at the hip joint. Which of the following statement/s is/are true regarding this case?

A. Superior gluteal nerve is injured.

B. Internal rotation of the hip is affected.

C. The injured muscle is inserted in the gluteal tuberosity of the femur.

D. On examination, a positive Trendelenburg sign is noticed.
questions.solution:
Statement C is the only true statement.

The clinical scenario of difficulty while climbing stairs, rising up from a sitting position and loss of extension of the hip points to a palsy of the gluteus maximus muscle. Injury to the inferior gluteal nerve supplying the gluteus maximus is most commonly iatrogenic following a total hip arthroplasty via the posterior approach.

Gluteus maximus is inserted in the iliotibial tract of fascia lata and gluteal tuberosity (Statement C) on the posterior femoral surface. It is the primary extensor of hip joint and helps in lateral rotation (Statement B) and abduction of the thigh.

The nerve supply is by the inferior gluteal nerve (Statement A), the injury of which leads to atrophy of the muscle and weakness in the extension of the thigh. The patients typically have a gluteus maximus lurch and cannot stand up from a sitting posture without support. The gluteus maximus may be tested by extension of the hip against resistance, in the supine or prone position.

Statement A, B, and D are features of injury to the superior gluteal nerve supplying the gluteus medius and minimus.

Origin and insertion of the gluteal muscles are mentioned in the pearl.

Related Pearl: Gluteal Muscles

 
Gluteus Medius
Origin- Outer surface of ilium between anterior and posterior gluteal lines.
Insertion -Oblique ridge on the lateral surface of the greater trochanter.
Gluteus Minimus
Origin- Outer surface of ilium between anterior and inferior gluteal lines
Insertion -Ridge on the anterior surface of greater trochanter
Gluteus Maximus

Origin - Posterior aspect of dorsal ilium posterior to posterior gluteal line, posterior superior iliac crest, posterior inferior aspect of sacrum and coccyx, and sacrotuberous ligament

Insertion - Primarily in fascia lata at the iliotibial band; also into the gluteal tuberosity on posterior femoral surface
